reviewText: This was a decent film although there were some big expectations of viewers making their own connections to what I considered vague ideas. reviewText: Brad Pitt is typically great in this show. Not the usual, tired zombie apocalypse flick. Zombies are lightning fast and humans transform in minutes. Many intense, graphic and suspenseful moments from start to finish. As far as zombie movies go, definitely one of the best I've seen.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Director Marc Forster's film "World War Z" is a hit! I was very much surprised and impressed by this film. I liked it! The fast running, surging, and piling zombies worked within the context of this films story line. It was not stupid like I thought it would be. It was very well done. The Zombies in this film are very scary just like you want them to be. They do this really terrifying teeth chomping thing accompanied by horrifying screaming sound effects that cause goosebumps and chills. This film is very intense and very stressful at times. Nothing dumb here. Brad Pitt and all of this films cast has done a wonderful job making me believe the world as we know it was coming to an end. "World War Z" is about a zombie Pandemic that almost wipes out mankind is based on author Max Brooks popular novel by the same name. "World War Z" screenplay is penned by Matthew Michael Carnaham, Drew Goddard, and Damon Lindelof. If you enjoy ZOMBIES, and want to see a bloodless, gore-less fairly clean film, this thriller is for you! Give this film a try. You may like it! Enjoy!Release Date: 21 June 2013Running Time: 116 minutesRating: PG-13 for intense frightening zombie sequences, violence and disturbing images.Action/Drama/Horror/Sci-Fi/ThrillerGrade: B+
summary: Stressful, scary "World War Z" is NOT a gore-fest!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I really loved the zombies in this movie.  Their antics, their spastic movements, and especially their clacking teeth provided plenty of comic relief to an otherwise tense film.  Brad Pitt is the hero (what else?) as the world fights back against a zombie epidemic.  Once you're bitten, you turn into one, so the Zombie population is rising like geometrically while the population of real people is quickly disappearing.  It's the UN that saves the day (don't get offended, UN haters, it's just a movie).  Although itself infested by zombies, one World Health Organization facility -- with Brad Pitt's help -- finds the cure.The best action moments of the film come as zombies attack the walls built around Jerusalem especially to keep them out.  They form themselves into human (well, zombie)  ladders to breach the wall and start biting Jews, Arabs and Christians with a genuine sense of equality.  It was heart-warming to see that all religions were equally doomed.  Pitt's series of Indiana Jones escapes from death were exciting enough to overcome the ridiculousness of the plot and keep you on the edge of your seat.It's a horror film, but it has a great sense of humor.  The good guys win in the end -- but that's probably not a spoiler for anyone who's ever seen a "creatures invading the earth" movie.  But those zombies can be truly hilarious, and make the entire experience worthwhile.This 3-D version, like the current crop of 3-D movies, is subtle with few minutes of head-ducking effects.  But, as with all the new crop of 3-D movies, the effect is used more for depth and beauty than for shock effects.  I'm not sure if this film was shot in native 3-D or just converted, but either way, it did a good job of conveying depth and included a few "duck your head" 3-D moments.  It was definitely a fun ride.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: A fast moving action film that works surprisingly well - the action certainly conveys the sense of a remorseless and overwhelming enemy. The reaction of both civil and armed forces seems unusually rationale for a Hollywood film. The film does feel rushed towards the end and leaves quite a few loose ends unresolved. Was this supposed to be a longer film? Or the first of a two part series? Either way, aside from the scrappy and rather abrupt ending, the film is very watchable. This isn't a blockbuster but it is a very decent zombie flick.

reviewText: For the millions that loved the photographic greatness of "Inception", this movie will hold their interest. While the zonbies are cable of catching numerous adults, the main character and his wife outrun them accompanied by three children. Photographs in an elevator are supposed to be frightening and aren't. The blame is placed on a virus that kills most and after injecting oneself with a deadly toxin, the zombies can't "smell" their victim though earlier they found their victime by sound. Come on. You can come up with a better story.

reviewText: Let's start with the biggest Problem with this movie.... PG13. Translation, a diluted version for the masses. To make any zombie movie worthwhile it must be R rated. No bones about it and I will explain why.I Read the book and was aware this movie would take a different approach but I was a huge fan of the book and thought even a different take would be worth watching. Wrong. The book was done through the perspectives of various different people in different parts of the world. The different perspectives all progressed through the epidemic until the end of the epidemic from the accounts of various survivors. Every story was suspenseful and creative. The characters were rich and authentic and the material was all R rated.This movie takes the Disney turn and makes it all about brad Pitt. The sad CGI attempts did not help things any. A great example of how ridiculous this movie was is in the beginning where pit and his family meet another family who offer them shelter. The family have a little boy named Tommy. After the family declines Pitt's offer to join them they die at the hands of zombies. All except the boy who miraculously survives.What made this completely fake was that the boy never shed one tear after his parents die horribly and PItt shoots his dad in the head. Tommy is just fine and happily joins family. This was the most glaring example of how this movie has been diluted for the masses and I can name many more throughout the movie.Had they made this movie true to the book and with an R rating for mature subject matter you might have the next epic zombie flick. But alas, they chose to sell tickets to the whole family . So for goodness sake, don't name this movie by the book. Call it something else.
summary: Please don't call this Movie World War Z
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This is an action thriller more than a typical zombie movie. It starts off strong with a lot of action sequences. The hero, Brad Pitt is engaged to find the source of the infection that has turned much of the human population into zombies. He spends the rest of movie following his instincts and coming up with a solution to the zombie problem which is imaginative, but not very plausible. Many questions about the zombies remain.However, if you watch it just for entertainment value and don't take it too seriously, it's an okay movie.
summary: Good action, plot could be better
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Whether it's aliens from Mars, nuclear annihilation, giant killer asteroids, or confusing tax laws, we seem to always find new ways to promote massive, apocalyptic trends in pop culture.  Trending now, is zombies, zeds, whatever...This is a cool movie.  Yes, it falls back on the use of massive digital effects to sell the story in many scenes, but at least this time, the scenes really need it.  In other words, Hollywood's propensity for using CG instead of real actors made sense here, and built a world wracked with zeds.The story wraps up too quickly, but that's understandable.  I can't judge the video and sound quality here though, as it was a streamed rental.I read about the differences between the theatrical and unrated versions, and didn't see much that would make the unrated version unrated.So, if you like zeds, Brad Pitt, or are an end of the worldaholic, this film is for you.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Love this movie, The zombies are so much better than when you watch Walking Dead.  The story revolves around United Nations employee Gerry Lane (Pitt), who traverses the world in a race against time to stop a pandemic that is toppling armies and governments and threatening to decimate humanity itself. World War Z still brings smart, fast-moving thrills and a solid performance from Brad Pitt to the zombie genre.

reviewText: This movie is action packed! Actually, if the pace wasn't so frantic, you'd probably take the time to notice the truck sized plot holes, and lack of character empathy development. reviewText: I originally had low expectations for this movie (even as a huge fan ofthe Walking Dead, I'm feeling "zombie-fatigued"). But the idea thatzombies are both fast and "swarm" (like ants crawling on top of eachother) to climb a huge wall is a unique twist that could make thismovie fun to watch (written May 2013).And it ended up being a blast. It introduced an original story-line tothe zombie-apocalypse genre. First, an origin to why the zombie plaguestarted. Second, the potential for a cure? And lastly, Brad Pitt as thebest dad/survivalist ever. If I had to pick my team to battle thezombie apocalypse, I'd want Brad on my team, no matter that he is 20times more handsome than me. (written July 2013)Afternote: If you saw the movie, don't read the book. In this rarecase, the book falls short of the movie. The book is told in"documentary-style" based on memos etc. that recall the events "after"World War Z. The movie tells it in real-time which is how it should beexperienced.
summary: Brad Pitt (suprisingly) keeps the zombie-apocalypse genre fresh and alive
Title: World War Z

reviewText: The movie starts out good enough, but the whole ending bit is lame and uninteresting.  They should have stuck to the book, or at least not have made such a blah movie.  A lot of people really like this movie, I don't understand why.  I like Pitt and the Israeli soldier girl, but the ending of the movie ruins it all for me.  I can forgive them for all the zombie movie cliché's but not for the lame ending IMHO.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This is a PG 13 zombie film. That is the biggest strike against it.  You have to start R rated to carry the actual horror of this concept. Cannibal zombies are gory.  Sadly this movie had one of the best Zombie stories ever written as it's basis but failed to live up to the source material.  There were nods, the story does a bit of globe trotting and we see various reactions to the zombie plague.I don't want to have to announce spoilers so while I could forgive the rating and the it being a movie adaptation of a better book I can't forgive the story.  The grand reveal is a bit trite, I didn't believe it and if you can't sell me on your wonder science then you've lost the battle for this movie.I might actually give this a 2.5  I didn't want the time I spent watching it back and there were some neat bits here and there but I won't give this movie  a 3.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This review relates primarily to your decision to buy the 3d version or not. As loudly as I can, do not waste your money on 3d and simply savor the regular blu ray version.  Sadly, the 3d version adds nothing.  This is an incredible movie, no doubt, but the 3d really doesn't even deserve the name. The only difference between the regular and the 3d is that you have to wear the annoying glasses to watch the 3d version. Definitely rush to buy this movie, just learn from my mistake and content yourself with blu ray.
summary: Awesome movie but skip the 3d version

reviewText: I knew I was going to love this one when I saw the previews, and boy, was I right! Great action movie, this one grabs you 5 minutes in, and doesn't let go till it's over.  My only complaint, and it's a very small one, was that it was another zombie movie.  I'm getting kind of zombie'd out. But the really good story and surprise ending made it well worth overlooking the zombie factor. I bought this one on Amazon.com because I watch it a LOT. Nothing make doing laundry easier than having a good movie to watch while you're folding, right? Definitely a winner in my book!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I like movies. I like movies better when people try to make them well, e.g., put effort in to the narrative structure, create situations with tension, drama, in the case of this movie, horror, gore, whatever. You don't watch a zombie movie for the sweet parts. I also paid twenty bucks for the privilege of watching this movie, from Amazon. I could tell, after ONE MINUTE, the thing was going to suck. There's old studly, cool, Brad, with his low key, half stoned expression, making breakfast for the kids. With his long hair. In a beautiful middle American house. With a gorgeous kitchen. And a stunning wife. Yup, just flippin' me some pancakes. Oh, and BTW, he's a chief investigator for the UN, where he goes to a lot of "bad places." Ooookayy. The chemistry with the kids is almost zero- it's more like, 'hey, you're gettin paid- let's pretend, ok?' The brief flash of "genuine" emotional exposition I saw was when Pitt, the UN investigator steps out of a car before an imminent zombie attack, to find out what's wrong. There's a cool looking black guy, nicely turned out, also looking confused. "Hey," Brad asks him, "you need help?" "Nah, I'm cool," the guy responds. It was the expression on Brad's face that seemed to get at the core of who he was- an actor who seems himself as streetwise, hip,  cool and an operator. A UN investigator with connections to high levels of government? REally? The plot setups were so lame I tried three separate times to watch the movie and failed. Each time.
summary: How did this movie get made?
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This film was exciting and surprisingly realistic - it seemed so viable a scenario when we screened it - anyway, Brad Pitt was great as a scrappy UN Investigator.  Overall, A timely film, a jewel amongst a host of awful zombie films.  Rent it, Buy It. Enjoy it.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This was a movie without a point. The action was jerky; the plot line (if there was one) moved erratically; and the conclusion felt like a tack-on in order to end the movie in its allotted time.On the plus side, the computer generated graphics weren't as bad as the story line.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: It's almost better to watch this movie without having read the book first, so you can enjoy it on its own as a decent zombie flick that focuses more on humans than zombies and gore. After you've enjoyed the movie, go read the book and be prepared to be blown away by one of the best pieces of zombie literature ever written. It would be nice to see a big screen version of the actual book, but it's probably better suited to a serialized mini-series on tv. Still, lack of much synchronicity with the book aside, the movie is highly enjoyable and that's why i gave it 5 stars and recommend it.
Title: World War Z

summary: This is very similar to the movie "I Am Legend" ...

reviewText: it's been almost a week since I saw this movie and all I can say is--Wow!. It is still with me even now. I can't get it out of my head! Action, excitement and horror all mixed into one movie with very few contrivances (Except For Israeli Airplane Sequence).This movie now has me wanting to buy the book and I will do that as soon as I complete my other readings. There is not much that I can say except that this movie was a remarkable production! Brad Pitt knows his stuff! I can't believe that there originally were problems with the production and script. In the end I can tell you this movie is a more realistic version of 28 Days Later, and if one has an imagination, an addendum. Buy this movie on DVD and you won't be disappointed!A. Nathaniel Wallace, Jr.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I could have also done the World War ZZzzzz... but I am sure that's been done to death.+ There are a few action elements of this film that make it interesting,+ and none of the performances are terrible.- But it is ultimately a feeble, derivative, and repetitive film.- When the same exact scenario repeats it self 5 times in a film, it's hard to get a new reaction.- There are too many moments where suspension of disbelief depends entirely on ignoring any semblance of real world behavior or logic.- Predictable and ultimately uninterestingThe movie is so lazy, it left me with little energy to give it a more in depth review.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: this movie was so disappointing and i blame it all on the book! The book was such a better story than the movie was. The movie was a pretty typical zombie story. Nothing particularly significant or interesting. The book on the other hand was so interesting and well written. The book didn't have to rely on gore and typical zombie imagery to bring the story across. This was just a big ol zombie movie. BORING. I might of liked this more if I hadn't read the book but I believe watching this movie would of made me not want to read the book. So glad I read the book. Giving this an extra star because I do really think that Brad is a good actor. I always like him, even in this. I just couldnt get past how much this movie was not the book.Biggest issues I had were how fast the zombies could move, and how they made it over the wall in Israel.. my assumption on these is fast zombies are scarier (yet somehow in the book the slow zombies were scary enough) and the movie had to make America be the ones who figured the zombies out.
summary: Book is a million times better

reviewText: Not your typical zombie movie where everybody is blasting everybody.This is a intelligent movie and instead of giving you a movie with a big ending you get a moviewith the big stuff throughout the movie. Title: World War Z

reviewText: When I saw the trailers for this film it looked like one giant explosion after another with massive hoardes of zombies at every corner and Michael Bay ooze all over every frame.  In fact, I really had no desire to see the film at all, despite the fact that the source material was said to be an inspired work.  When news broke that the film didn’t really follow the book, it kind of solidified in me a reason to stay far away, and then the film itself was delayed (which is usually a bad sign) and with my wife opposed to all things zombies I didn’t have to worry about her Brad Pitt obsession to force me into a theater.I wish that I had seen this on the big screen.Yes, despite no real desire to see this at all, friends talked it up and so I wound up renting this the other night and I have to say, I loved this.Like, a lot.It takes something special for an action film to win me over in this way.  Yes, I enjoy the genre, but most of the films that come out of it are so generic and formulaic and redundant that you need only see one or two of them in a year, despite the fact that a good fifty are made each year.  They just keep coming and coming.  Zombies are all the rage now, but I have yet to see a single episode of ‘The Walking Dead’ and the last great zombie film I saw was Boyle’s masterpiece ’28 Days Later’, and that was way back in 2003.  Needless to say, I wasn’t anticipating much from this, even with my friend’s heavy praise.Where ‘World War Z’ succeeds is in the staging.  I brilliantly makes this more than an explosive mess of chaotic jump scenes.  Instead, it balances out the action with true suspense, keeping the audience in true fear, not manufactured terror.  I can’t stress enough how rewarding this was.  I prefer a film that can get under my skin as opposed to one that throws everything in your face, and this film’s laboratory scene is one of the scariest in recent memory.The film follows an epidemic that reaches global proportions and threatens to wipe out the world.  Gerry Lane, a former UN employee, gets semi-forced back into service when a young kid with a bright idea needs a transport to Japan.  Things get muddled and soon Gerry finds himself mankind’s only hope (sort of) so he travels the globe in search of the answers to stopping this disease transforming the world into undead.Yes, there are some really big scenes here.  There are some breakneck paced sequences that show countless zombies racing down streets and clambering all over one another in order to feast.  They slam into buildings and cars and tear into flesh and they basically clutter the screen.  But those scenes are not what ‘World War Z’ is about, at least not entirely.  There are many softer, smaller, quieter, scarier scenes that make this a very strong addition to the genre.  The plane sequence is breathtaking, and I already mentioned the lab scene, which is the best in the film.  The character development is minimal, but I like that the film doesn’t shy away from taking a harsh approach to the situation.  The ending could be deemed a cop out, and yet it is a lot better than magically curing the world.In fact, this film kind of reminds me of what would happen if you took Boyle’s ‘28 Days Later’, fused it with ‘Contagion’ and gave it a glossy, Michael Bay, veneer.In other words; this film is VERY entertaining.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Interesting movie with more than just zombie shoot-up action. Instead of an evil coporation or devious military experiment, the movie seemed to make it realistically believable if an event like this could happen. Good acting with action sequences interspersed throughout the movie to keepthe flow of the movie going. I am not always a fan of zombie movies, but I did read the book and the movie adaptation was done pretty well considering you have a two hour movie to get the book across.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I've heard a lot of reviews written by fans of the book by Max Brooks and many of them are negative, because they were expecting to see the book made into a movie. Simply put, this is not the same story from the book, however it's still a great zombie film. In fact, it's easily one of my favorite zombie movies of all time. If you're a fan of zombies, whether you've read the book "World War Z" or not (I recommend reading it btw) you will definitely have a good time watching this film. While there's not a lot of gore as in most zombie films, the zombies are pretty creepy and there's lots of 'em and there's enough tension to keep things interesting throughout. If you're on the fence about seeing this movie, let me give you a small nudge to check it out. You won't be disappointed. Just don't expect to see the book made into a movie.
summary: This is not the book on film!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: There are problems with this movie, let's be clear -- it could have been longer, there could have been more backstory, I could have cared about the protagonists more. But let's be clear -- those problems don't detract from a frightening, chilling, icky, fun, crazy time full of some of the most claustrophobic, spine-tingling, eerie sequences I've ever seen in a blockbuster. From the moment the side mirror snaps until the last time the door closes on the isolation chamber, this thing is nerve-wracking good fun.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Good action movie, many action sequences and pretty good acting.  Spoiler alert:  the ending of this movie was very soft for all the action that the first hour brought.

reviewText: Vampires , Ghouls and of course Zombies , whereas nineties was more Science Fiction , Star Trek , Babylon 5 which in my opinion a hybrid show, Really loved this movie , I would hazard to say fun , and big lLawrence of Arabia fighting Zombies , What they used call RoadShow Movies, these types were widescreen or cine-rama .Hollywood had too compete with a Big Box with tiny screen called television. Title: World War Z

reviewText: To me, this was going to be the movie of the summer. Alas, Pitt decided to rewrite the entire last 3rd of the film to make it "family friendly". So a promising beginning ends up with a feel good ending that has more holes than a made for TV movie (the original ending was much darker and MUCH truer to the zombie canon). Pitt was an artistic coward, and in the name of "family" chose to neuter this film down to an enjoyable but seriously flawed action picture that happens to have zombies. Perhaps the unrated version will at least show us a zombie actually killing someone instead of just running around aimlessly.
summary: A zombie movie for people who dont like zombie movies
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This review contains spoilers...This movie started of off with promise. The idea of fast-moving zombies gave a new aspect to an old story, and since I have small children I empathized with the father trying to help his family survive. Some of the graphics were spectacular, the wall in Israel scene was worth the whole movie. However, the chemistry between the husband and wife was non-existent and I didn't care one bit about their relationship. They killed off the most interesting character (the young scientist) before you could even give the man more than a half-smile for his witty observations. The zombies were campy and silly when they shouldn't have been. And the 'solution' in the end was ridiculous and full of loopholes. The only reason I give it two stars was for the wall and the young Israeli soldier.
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Saw this in the theaters last year....lots of action, CG and sound affects in familiar geographic places to keep your pulse up.  It's a highly probable plot of a spread of an Ebola-like pandemic, except that it results in plenty of zombies.  A little improbable, since all organic beings have to eat and excrete something to supply their energy requirements even if they were partially alive to "hear" potential targets,  They don't eat each other, because the movie plot would less viable when all the good healthy folks would have to do is to wait, and the problem would become extinct.  But no, they "live" by transmitting a virus to an inexhaustible pool of healthy people.  The hero keeps his head and eye for details amongst the panic and chaos....and saves the day.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: World War Z was announced and the fanboys staged a s*** show. Never having read the book, I avoided the backlash. This is a good thing. As a horror movie fan, there isn't much more that the audience can ask for from such a flick. The ending is rushed and comes to a premature halt, but we should be willing to let that slide. This is the start of a trilogy, of course! How many times do we get to see Brad Pitt lead such a blockbuster effort, especially of this type, nonetheless? Not many... Seven, Interview With A Vampire... That's it.World War Z borrows from many other genre films before it, but the influence of George Romero was most evident. Many scenes bare similarity with Day of the Dead, an oft-forgotten entry in Romero's "Dead" franchise. The beginning shares the white-knuckle suspense of Zack Snyder's Dawn of the Dead remake, and then moves onto 28 Days territory. The zombies here are unique in that their behavior is not humanoid, instead they act like ants, climbing and swarming all over themselves in order to overcome obstacles. They move super fast, and frequently throw their entire bodies at their victims, descending on them like bloodthirsty flying squirrels. The global scale of the epidemic is evident, though not as much as some viewers would like. Keep in mind that this is not Contagion. If the film was made to the exact specs of the book, it could have ended up the disjointed mess that was that Matt Damon flunker.Brad Pitt does not play an invincible killing machine. He is UN, so he is much more cool and diplomatic. The Unrated version is very action-packed from beginning to end. Brad Pitt shifts from focusing on his family's safety to focusing on the larger issue of how to stop the outbreak. His character shows what a cool head can accomplish in the instance of global disaster. The third act is more of a one-on-one showdown instead of the epic climax everyone had been hoping for, but overall the movie does a good job of bringing some novel ideas to the big screen. A great addition to zombie movie canon, a slap in the face to all fanboy haters.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: very good book.  engages reader in a variety of different point of view withe respect to a world wide catastrophe.I also watched the movie which has no correlation to the book.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I never like zombie movies because they are impossible to believe.  The argument that someone dead all of a sudden becomes alive is silly.  However, in this movie, an infection similar to rabies that spread when infected individuals bite other people is more believable.  Adding well known organizations to the drama such as the World Health Organization also is a plus.I would recommend this movie as the best one so far of its kind.
summary: First Zombie movie with a bit of sense
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Having a named star like Brad Pitt expected a interesting and entertaining movie - this movie is too long and not very interesting.  The story line is blurred in the beginning of the movie - and not until sometime into the movie you get the issue that the movie is attempting to state is the world wide problem - a feature that is not fully explained throughout the rest of the long movie.  Best part of the movie was the mention of Camp Humphries - a Army base located in South Korea.  Expected a better movie - but unfortunately for I, this was NOT the movie I anticipated in viewing.
summary: A Long But Boring for the Most Part Movie.

reviewText: This was a extremely poor rendition of the Walking Dead.  It could have been much more realistic in the way people turned into zombies. But I kept wanting this movie to come to an end to put it and me out of our miseries.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I'm a fan of zombie movies with my favorites being all of the Resident Evil movies and Zombieland.  Sorry to Walking Dead fans, but I just couldn't get into the show.  Basically this movie is about a guy who has connections within the government and a family to protect during a zombie apocalypse.  The typical zombie movie cliches "how did it happen?", "is there a cure?", and "hopeful future" are still intertwined in this movie.  However, they're presented in a way that adds plenty of action without taking away from the storyline.  All in all, I would recommend this movie.  There are some pretty good zombie scenes, edge of the seat action, and a few jump scares.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Global zombie apocalypse that starts fast with just enough back story to get things rolling and keeps a frenetic pace throughout. Visually amazing and although a lot of the characters lack dimension, Pitt does a great job and easily carries the film and even in a supporting role, Mireille Enos is fantastic. For those wanting an non-stop action film, there is more than enough here, but for genre fans it does work on multiple levels as well (a whole discourse could be done just in zombie comparison vis a vis Romero). The ending isn't your typical happy ending with everything tied up in a neat package nor, to its credit, does it try to answer all the questions it sets up but intentionally leaves you feeling slightly discomfited. Guaranteed you'll have fun thinking about it afterward and playing 'what if' and 'what's next'. Even though I'm not a 'fast zombie' fan, this is a great addition to the genre and worth adding to your collection.
summary: Great addition to the zombie genre
Title: World War Z

reviewText: If you are NOT a WALKING DEAD-type of fan, you will not enjoy this movie.  So, do not bother to submit a review.  I really dislike it when someone enters a review BECAUSE they do not like the genre of the movie.  THAT IS ABSURD.I saw this movie and loved the role Brad Pitt played.  I thought it was an exceptional performance.  The ONLY thing I did not like was the co-star, his wife.  I do not think she is a very good actress and I do believe Brad Pitt held up the entire movie with his exceptional performance.I did not read the book, nor will I as I never read one and then go see the book's movie, or vice versa.  I believe that by doing so, you are comparing all the time.  So, if I read a book and then go see the movie to compare its authenticity in story and/or intensity, I KNOW I will be disappointed, so why should I set myself up for that?I absolutely loved this movie and will buy it here at Amazon shortly.  I think the Director did an exceptional job and the screenwriters nailed it.GOOD JOB, BRAD, as I do not normally like him in anything he stars in and I sometimes wonder why he chooses the scripts he does.  Brad Pitt has changed my mind about his acting abilities because of this movie.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: As a fan of Brad Pitt, I was expecting a lot more from "World War Z".  The movie falls flat, with a mostly irrelevant supporting cast (especially Mireille Enos) and contrived action scenes.  I was unable to reach a "willing suspension of disbelief", when watching this film.  The manner in which Brad Pitt is shown to know more about zombie behavior and global epidemiology than virtually anyone else in the entire world symbolizes the lack-luster effort that apparently went into adapting this screenplay (from what is generally regarded a very good novel). Even the zombie action sequences are mostly disappointing (except for the opening few minutes, which were done well).  Stuff just jumping out at you and making loud noises does not translate into suspense and horror.  Skip this one, in my opinion.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I liked this movie very much.  My piqued interest is not so much for Pitt's role, but for the way in which the zombies conducted themselves and the way in which they spread their plague.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Brad Pitt plays a UN scientist who has come home to spend time with his wife and two daughters when a "virus" breaks out that causes people to turn to zombies, bite others, and on and on! "Patient zero" was never found, but Pitt (along with other scientists) figure out what makes the zombies tick and these zombies are unlike any other zombies in other zombie movies! The action is hard and in your face. The resolution is profound. Loved this movie!
summary: World War Z - A wonderfully different zombie movie!

reviewText: Before we jump in, I saw this movie before reading the book.  At the time of this writing, I am almost halfway through the book and am very much enjoying it.There seems to have been quite a bit of backlash because this film really has nothing to do with the book it is based on.  And when I say based on, I mean they share the same title.  That really is the only thing they have in common.  There are a few bits of dialogue that are taken directly from the book, but that's about it.  I like to consider myself a bit of a zombie aficionado, no expert mind you, but I like a variety of zombie pictures from Dawn of the Dead to Resident Evil and 28 Days Later.  This movie fits in well and adds a few twists and turns that make it down right fun to watch.  I thought Brad Pitt did a great job.Now, if you only enjoy the classic, shambling slow as molasses zombie movies, this is not the movie for you.  These are sprinting acrobatic jump over cars and eat your face off zombies.  It definitely adds tension when you see a fast moving river of zombies racing through the streets and alleyways.  The story, I thought, was engaging enough and this movie is now in my rotation of semi regularly viewed zombie movies.  I believe the movie stands on its own merits and shouldn't be compared to the book.  The book is amazing as well, but a movie version of the book would be confusing if not downright boring as the only central character is collecting stories from around the globe meaning the entire movie would be quick flashbacks with characters you've never seen before.Personally, I find most synopsis of the plot in movie reviews to be annoying so I tend to focus on the "if you like this, than you will probably like that" approach.  If you enjoyed 28 Days Later, or generally are not opposed to fast moving zombies and you are not looking for a direct adaptation from the book, I think you will enjoy this movie.Before I leave you, if you happen to find yourself living through some kind of zombie apocalypse know this.  You MUST find the closest thing to Brad Pitt's character and stick to him like glue.  Going off on your own or doing your own thing will end very badly for you and your friends/family.  Going with Brad doesn't guarantee your survival of course, but it improves your odds and should add a hell of an adventure before you're killed off or turned!
summary: Great Stand Alone Zombie Picture... not an adaptation of the book!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: The film starts out nicely with panic in the streets. We have to wait like everyone else to find what the problem is. Soon our potential fuzzy-faced hero will have to make a moral decision. It looks like the world is at "steak."We chew our fingernails as the plot thickens. Is there no way out?I enjoyed the distraction of the movie and the few predictable twists and turns. There was nothing spectacular or extraordinary in the presentation. The DVD extras showed the producers were proud that they displayed the bitees as a virus with one purpose to spread and survive; at one time this may have been a new idea. In this day and age everyone portrays virus strewn people as vicious vectors.

reviewText: Hollywood production mogul$ once again believe that throwing a lot of money, and back to back, same old same old "special" effects into a movie will carry a poor to non-existent script and make up for mediocre at best acting performances.  I waited for this to release to Prime instead of jumping on the pay per view or purchase bandwagon - I am so glad I did as there is really no substance in an over worked plot that skips around disjointed from any tied in points.In this spin / rendition of world plague / apocalypse we have some mysterious virus that unleashes against the human population, some do-gooders within the various governments with a supposed knowledge of what is occurring don the cape of evil slayer and travel about to the rescue attempting to first discover where the virus started from, what it is, and how to defeat it.  Y  A  W  NYet, somehow public insurrection and mass hoards, million upon million, can just not quite break down a simple door to claim the last holdouts - although it is never brought out to just what end this is supposed to accomplish as the unleashed virus by mother earth to eliminate the human pestilence  just turns them to killer zombies that do not die...so what is the point, why not unleash a sudden death virus?Brad Pitt...well at least the last name tells the story minus the "s" as the acting, if that is what it was supposed to be just stinks the place up (no pun intended).  Sure, underlying back story of love is woven into the sub-plots, only to be sub-par.Do not get sucked into a single big name actor, it does not carry the movie or the plot, a monumental waste of time - anything that releases to DVD the same month it is released to movie houses should tell you something.  Somebody was trying to cash in on the Zombie craze way to late, with way to little script and story line.
summary: Earth Fights Back Against Humans - Creates Zombies:  And that is as far as the story line ever gets
Title: World War Z

Zoombies are taking over the earth and you get Brad Pitt battling zoombies in different contexts: downtown, in a darkened airplane hanger, in the rain, on a plane etc. Too many battle scenes and not enough development of the underlying story about where the zoombie plague came from in the first place. Title: World War Z

reviewText: I'm reading the book right now and it is far better.  In fact, I would say the movie has very little in common with the book other than the title and there are Zombies in it.  There are several things that bothered me about this movie.  I'll try no to spoil anything for those who have not seen it.  First of all, there are the Zombies themselves.  They move fast, which makes them more interesting.  I did like that part about them.  This way, you don't have to dumb down the characters too much to give the Z's a chance.  However, there is no evidence in this movie that anyone is ever eaten by one.  None.  That really makes them less scary.  They bite you and move on.  The main thing that makes a Zombie terrifying is the fear that you could be eaten alive and torn apart by one.  Take that away and what are they?  Not much.  A pack of Pit Bulls or a bunch of Fire Ants become more scary.  That's part of the problem with a PG-13 Zombie flick.  I don't like gore at all, but they could have found an imaginative way to give the impression that people were being devoured.  I know "imagination" is a bit hard to come by from Hollywood these days. The other thing about the movie that's puzzling is Brad Pitt's character.  There is nothing special about him.  There is nothing there that screams out that he's THE guy to solve this problem.  Anyone can do what he does in the film.  The only impressive thing he does is provide first aid to a severely wounded soldier.  Big deal.On the positive side, you do get some very good actions scenes and special effects.  Competent actors all around and some good thrills.  Story could have been better, but it's not horrible.  The characters in it are a bit better (smarter) than the usual morons you get in your garden variety Zombie movie.** SPOILER *** One thing that really ticked me off about this movie is the trailer for it.  If you have seen it then you have seen the best parts of the movie.  They should have held back some of their best scenes.
summary: Decent movie, but a bit of a let down.

reviewText: This movie seemed to me, to be missing a lot of exposition.I never read the books so I can only go from what I saw in the movie, and I've watched it a few times just to see if I missed something the 1st few times.I liked the start of the movie, with the whole New York collapsing thing  and the chaos that ensued but as the movie went on ... It  jumped the sha...Zombie a few times before the end.  Korea part was okay, science guy inadvertently killing himself IN A ZOMBIE FLIC was dumb/lame/weak writing (you pick).  (random thought, why didn't the SF guys just get on the plane as well? They didn't want a chance to get back to America? Zombie outbreak and no one wanted to go Home?)The real flaw came from the Isreal part (no clue why this caused international outcry for the glorification of Isreal) because it was stupid ... the whole part ... nonsensical.  So Israel built a giant wall .. fine I can accept that! They let in the Palestinians so they wouldn't have to fight them as zombies later ... fine!  The zombies massing on the wall because of the singing ... WHICH WAS QUIETER THAN THE CHOPPERS (which weren't Apache gunships) flying overhead?  Then somehow the zombies gained super zombie strength to do two things.  One, not be squished by the incredible weight on top of them as they piled up the wall. Two, not be smashed to a useless pulp when they jumped from the top down to the ground below.The Airplane part was really the second Zombie jump in a row.  Where/When/How did a zombie get below? How did no one around the flight attendant notice? and how freaking convenient that Pitt and the wounded Israeli soldier survived.  Honestly, they should of let the plane land, zombie pops out as they unload cargo and everyone in England dies ... This would of continued the interesting trend of Pitt's character killing everyone around him everywhere he goes as soon as he shows up.The England/clinic part was pretty good in all honesty.I just didn't get the cure part.  Meningitis was a mask for the zombies? Then what about everyone else who suffers from a disease?  Why don't people with STD's get a pass from the zombies?I loved the Dawn of the Dead remake. Why you ask? Because it was a simple OMG zombies everywhere lets just try to survive and escape.  Because of that there weren't very many issues/plot hole created.  WW Z just tried too hard to do too many things and  it didn't come together well.  I'd say, wait for it to hit the $5 bin or it to appear on netflix.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: With over a thousand reviews, I am not likely to say anything new about "World War Z", so let me compare it, favorably, to "Pacific Rim", which I saw the night before I watched Brad Pitt and Co. "Z" is just inside the realm of possibility. There is no Zombie disease, but the notion of a pandemic is entirely too possible. That sliver of possibility makes all the unlikely occurrences easy to accept, once you go along with the basic premise. In contrast, the premise of "Rim" is pure Sci-Fi. Pure imagination. There have been several good speculative stories written about robot design which indicate that the best design for a killer robot would look much more like an Abrams M1A1 tank than like a Terminator. Even the underlying premise, of a dimensional portal between two tectonic plates is largely fantasy. Pandemics we can buy easily. Dimensional portals, not so much."Rim" is lots of gorgeous eye candy. "Z" turns your bowels to water at more than one place. The story runs from hope to hope denied to more hope to more hope denied. I came close to turning it off at three places, but I stuck it out. There is only one improbability in the plot which annoyed me. In the real world, it would have been colossal bad luck. But why put it in a fiction. Well, for the very same reason. It is the first lift of hope, brought down almost to despair, and the film is hardly 1/4 over.The movie is a well-choreographed roller coaster, with an amazingly plausible solution at the end.It may be the kind of movie you do NOT want to watch alone, and maybe you do not want to watch on Halloween night.

reviewText: I only knew two things about this movie:  1) My husband wanted to see it and 2) Brad Pitt is in it.  I don't normally care for Zombie movies, but this was good.  The movie kept our attention to the end.  It wasn't as graphic as it could have been, but definitely not  recommended for children.  These are not your typical slow-moving, stiff, Halloween zombies; Walking Dead zombies, they are not!  This movie doesn't have a clear start of how the people became zombies so you are thrown into action quickly, and there is no clear ending of how to get people back to "normal."  Brad Pitt and his family are the main characters at the beginning but the movie shifts to Brad being the focus of how he is going to save not only his family but the country/world from this certain terrible fate.  I don't think it should be compared to War of the Worlds, which was bloodier and darker in my opinion.  There is suspense in this movie and visible fear of the unknown.  No, it's not realistic but it's not supposed to be.  Since I didn't have any expectations about this movie, I was pleasantly surprised.  It is certainly not Brad's best movie, but it was nice to see him in an action zombie movie.  Overall, we were entertained and enjoyed the movie.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I'm sorry, but this movie was really dumb.  ***Spoiler***  In the very begining of the movie, there was a scene where Brad Pitt gets out of his car and the camera pans out and we see that there are cars jam packed bumper to bumper for miles behind his car.  Also we can see that there is barely enough room for the Cop on his motorcycle to squeeze in between cars to get to Brad to tell him to sit back in his car.  Not a second passes after Brad closes his car door does the officer on the motorcycle get hit by a MACK TRUCK going 80 miles per hr.  Ok, I just finished telling you there was barely room for a motorcycle in-between the cars that are backed up for a mile, so how exactly does a MACK truck pick up 80 mph speed and not hit any cars before hitting the cop on the bike?  C'mon man.  If you can buy that BS I guess this movie is for you.  If you have even half of a brain this should bother you.  I haven't even touched on the "Zombies."  ***END of SPOILERS***Ok so they aren't Zombies but they are.  Explain to me how if you are an old lady that can barely walk, but if you get infected now you can run at lighting speed and jump off the sides of cars?  And I thought Sharknado was preposterous.Watch "28 Weeks later".  A much better film.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I just couldn't stand watching anymore, after seeing the first hour, and that only because I wanted to see why Brad Pitt and David Morse, two of my favorite actors, would choose to be in a zombie movie.  Morse's acting during that first sequence was fabulous.  Pitt?  Well, he's okay, but the role he had, was just move move move, very little dialogue.Filmography, 5 stars;  directing and film editing, 3 stars, see next paragraph;  special effects, 4 stars (less, for the zombies), screenplay, -1 stars (NO CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT, so no empathy with the characters), and film premise of zombie infection, -1000000000 stars.  Sound?  -11111111111 stars, either too loud or too quiet;  and puleese, someone remember that most folks will be watching this on monitors or LCD/LED TVs, so don't shoot everything so dark we can't see what's going on.Movie opening didn't allow audience to get comfortably empathetic.  Too fast.  It's like the opening episode of Falling Skies, which was also all movement -- idea to make you experience the thing, but puleese directors, give us characters we ATTACH to first, before laying on all that action which no one can follow...This thing could have been so much better with a different premise and better screenplay, which actually had a plot you could get into.  The slight sotto voce idea that Israel got protected first could have been done better, and came off instead as either a cheap insult or a cheap miracle.Not even worth finishing, but I'll force myself, since must attend computer registry cleaning;  then, will come back and re-rate, if required.  Believe it or not, they're making a sequel!  So there must be a lot of zombies who liked the first one.EDIT: finally finished watching.  Didn't reword the assessment above.  The last half was hoakey, half-baked, full of discontinuity, rushed.  Can't believe they spent 190 million to make this picture.  Again, the filmography and editing were quality enough, but the CONTENT was just plain awful, and of course the premise is so dumb, it demeans everyone associated with the film.  But it broke even at the box office, so the dummies are making a sequel.  Which, I'll never watch.  Once was enough, even while cleaning my computer.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: SPOILER ALERT!  I honestly cannot say why I thought this might be worth watching.  Brad Pitt?  Special Effects?  Apocalyptic theme? Mebbe.  But then I often find myself unwittingly lending further credence to the aphorism A Fool And His Money Are Soon Parted.  Okay, so if by having skipped most of grade school you can bring yourself to believe getting bitten by anything other than a pit viper can bring about an instantaneous metamorphosis from normal biology to a state of "undeadness" (whatever that is), then, by all means, continue watching.  You will be treated to all the cliche characteristics of monsters who've been around for a hundred years virtually unimproved by any creative person's imagination:  gray, loping, limping, groaning, wrything, slobbering corpses with an inexplicable lust for the flesh of the as yet un-zombified.  (No, actually in this movie they appear to have been enhanced with turbo speed gear, compared to the standard zombie's slothful gait.  The better, I suppose, to make it "possible" to catch and infect the thousands of CGI extras it takes to make such a sucky movie these days).  How is it that in every disaster film there is always an escape route for the protagonist's vehicle through thousands of disabled vehicles? So, will someone please explain to me how Pitt's character is able to get from the deck of an aircraft carrier onto a plane the size of a C130 Hercules without first having to return to a mainland airport?  And why would you land the dadburned thing in a zombie-infested Korean facility without intending to rescue the few remaining military dudes?  Ah, and if you yourself were a zombie, would you have the forsight to hide away in the pantry elevator of a wide-body jet so that later you could wreak havoc in the economy section?  Why is it that the protagonist is always the lone survivor in the inevitable horrific crash of a fully loaded plane?  Then, when it seems like all hope is lost, is the day always gloriously saved by such implausible gimmickry as is desperately employed in this drivel?  Mebbe.  Is it just all in good fun? Not at these prices.

reviewText: Brad Pitt continues making quality films although this is probably a blockbuster in his recent film roster.This new film is supposedly went through a lengthy and troubled production(refer to Vanity Fair's article)but the resulting film is very satisfying as an edge-of-seat entertainment.It was probably due to the backings of Pitt's production company "Plan B" under Pitt's direction to "fine tune" the film.Zombie movies are overdone but this one is different.It comes with a coherent and possible scenario of the cause of virus outbreak that turn humans to zombies spreadingso fast that the world couldn't cope.It is basically a run and chase film with several intensely written and directed action sequences that linked the film together.Although the concept of Brad Pitt alone who saved the world is a bit over the top but the resulting film issaved by a satisfyingly intense action thriller from start to finish with Pitt leading a fine supporting cast.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This was great movie but it is not a classic zombie movie so if you a looking to see 2 hours of the undead devouring people then this is not your movie. Although nothing in the movie is over the top great, it managed to not have any flaws in execution. It didn't make any false claims about being a typical zombie movie and I don't understand the criticism of this movie. It either comes from people wanting a zombie horror film and not getting one or from the one obvious thing in this movie. This movie is accurate in its portrayal of Israel and therefore offensive to some who are plainly anti-Semitic and want Jews unjustly portrayed as evil....for what reason I can not figure out.
summary: A good movie that happens to have zombies as a topic

reviewText: After highly anticipating WORLD WAR Z realism kicked in quite soon, as a) the movie was announced to be targeting a PG 13 Rating from the MPAA, b) there didn't seem to be a good script which resulted in rewriting and reshooting (never a good sign!), c) the Chinese FORCED the filmmakers to change the origin of the outbreak because they were offended and the filmmaker actually did it and finally d) all hope rests upon a U.N. agent (the U.N.!!! - one of the most incompetent and useless organizations in the world), which makes this movie a laughing stock.PG 13 and zombies don't mesh! I am sick of the studios' obsession for trimming everything for family entertainment. In the 80s/90s everything needed to be trimmed down for an R rating, now the R isn't good enough either. GREAT zombie movies like DAY OF THE DEAD (the Romero version, NOT the crappy remake) need to be GORY and BLOODY as hell! That's what zombie fans wanna see, not this yawner. O, it's got Brad Pitt in it! Yawn.To HOLLYWOOD: Zombie movies - Brad Pitt + NC 17 = Happy campers!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: A different twist on a Zombie movie. Imagine people change very quickly and when they turn they can move very fast.  Not your typical change after a bite and eventual death.  No, it's more like a rapidly spreading virus.  No shuffling Zombies here, they can come fast and in waves.  More intense than many typical Zombie movies and even more helpless feeling of fighting the spread of the disease.  At least rent it if you enjoy Zombie or horror movies.CA Luster
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: this film deviates substantially from max brooks' novel upon which it was based.  the book was incredible from start to finish.  it told the zombie wars as a form of history by visiting all the countries' battle sites after the war was over. the film handles the zombie war as it is occurring and brad Pitt has to find a way to fight the virus.  the strength of the film is in the sheer physical showing of what it would be like to be overrun by zombies,  you have never seen zombies like these. it seems as if they have rabies.  once they have it, they move differently.  they can move very, very fast. and they can pile up so as to become ladders to get over walls or battering rams. the cities they are infesting are well depicted too. there are a wife and two children who are left behind. they were missing from the novel and they don't add much to the movie. brad Pitt is on camera for virtually the entire film and that is necessary as he holds the film together.if you don't think you need to read the book now that you've seen the film, you are mistaken.  it is a beautiful recounting of the entire war which you cannot put down until done. there is so much more going on in the book whereas the film just scratches the surface.
summary: rendering of zombies visually is the best ever

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I will start off by saying that I am a huge fan of Max Brooks' two "Zombie" books... "The Zombie Survival Guide" and the far better companion-piece, "World War Z."  Brooks created an entire world, an entire "mechanism," and entire natural history...... and this movie has almost nothing whatsoever to do with Brooks' books.  Let's just be up-front about that.  I CANNOT UNDERSTAND why someone would choose to "adapt a book" and then produce a product with only one name (and two quotes from that character) re-used (and in different context), totally change the nature of the threat, totally change the nature of the narrative... WHY?It's beyond me.  It really is.That said...  as a "zombie movie" this film isn't bad.  It's not GREAT, either, but it's not BAD.  The biggest problems I have with this movie are with how utterly ludicrous certain elements of it really are.Brooks created a disease... including the cause of that disease, a virus called "Solanum" which has been present on Earth since the beginnings of the human race, but which (until the advent of modern high-speed transportation) has always resulted in small, localized outbreaks, never in a world-wide collapse.  Key to this is that the reanimated dead are, at most, SIMPLY HUMAN.  They are not, in any way, SUPERHUMAN.  If the human body cannot do something when alive, it cannot do it when dead and reanimated, either.  And in many cases, especially as the body breaks down, these abilities become less... and NEVER become more.While Brooks' zombies never tire, exactly, they also never heal...  which means that muscle strength decreases, often dramatically, over time.They decompose slowly, because the virus (Solanum) is deadly to ALL LIVING THINGS, including bacteria and insects, and thus most living things instinctively flee from an infection, or are killed immediately if they don't flee and come into contact with it (the partial exception being humans, which are "killed and then reanimated" rather than merely killed.)But the zombies in this film are "SUPER-ZOMBIES!!!!"  (Duh-duh-DAAAAAH!!!)  They can do things no human body could do, even at its prime.  They can burst through plate glass which would be physically impossible for a living human to break.  They can climb up walls which no number of living humans could climb up.  A charging group of them can "churn" over a bus, flipping it in the process.  They can run and leap far, far faster than any mortal human can.Heck, I'm surprised that none of them were able to FLY in this film!Further, Brooks' zombies die in a process which is pretty well-established, and which makes a certain degree of sense.  From initial contact to death is usually around 24 hours, with reanimation usually happening at some point before three more hours pass in most cases.  You can imagine Solanum reproducing within the body at that sort of rate... it requires no MAGIC to happen.  But there is no microorganism ever seen, or even IMAGINED, which can reproduce at the rate seen in this film.  From twenty-four-plus hours, we now see "twelve seconds" to a fully transformed zombie.So... if you hope to be able to "willfully suspend your disbelief" while watching this film...  and if you have the slightest grasp of biology at any level...  you'll be unable to do so, PERIOD.Further, they came up with a "Deux Ex Machina" solution which was made necessary by the "SUPERZOMBIE" nature of the reanimated in this film...  which is just ludicrous and, again, totally inconsistent with real biology at any possible level.SO...  there you go.But on the POSITIVE SIDE... you have good characterizations, a reasonable amount of fairly interesting storytelling, and some real chills and thrills along the way.Yes, it's predictable.  Yes, it's trite at times.  And yes, it relies far, far too much on CGI-created visual spectacle and not enough on solid storytelling principles.  And it's one of the most scientifically laughable movies ever made in the "zombie" genre (and that's saying something, isn't it!)But... if you can put those aside, it's still a movie which you'll probably enjoy, just because you really do come to care about who these people are and what happens to them (unlike most zombie flicks ever made).I do not encourage anyone to take this seriously...  but if you want some brainless, light entertainment, it's not a bad choice.On the other hand, if you're the type who enjoys deep, multi-layered storytelling (not about "I woke up and was chased by zombies all day" but rather "what happens to human society when pushed beyond the breaking point?") you should pick up Brooks' book(s).  Or even better, get the unabridged audio book version (the abridged versions are nice, too, but to get the full story, and see how it all relates, you really want the unabridged versions).The audiobooks are really remarkable, in fact, for having a full cast presentation.  Realize, the book is written from the standpoint of a journalist recording interviews with survivors of the zombie war... aka "World War Z."  It's done in that tone... very much like you'd hear if the news did interviews with 9/11 survivors today.  The stories are arranged to tell the story of the whole war, both in chronological terms and also in "conceptual terms" (with sections describing their purpose, like one entitled "Warning Signs" and another entitled "Blame").  Each story is told in "first person" to the interviewer...  but the characters, and the full cast of big-name actors playing them, is widely varied, and no two stories are similar, really.You can enjoy this film, for what it is... but just realize, it's unrelated to the book, and the book is FAR, FAR more worthy of your time.
summary: Unrelated to the book it is "based upon" in any way... but not a bad movie if you can get past that!

reviewText: Wasn't a bad film, nor a great one.The first part, in America, was probably the best. The second part, beginning with the wizard scientist was full of "stretches". The wizard scientist gives Brad the big clue. The wizard scientist accidentally kills his own clumsy self (so fortunate for Brad the hero, no sharing needed now). The military guys in the Korean base can shoot so very accurately in the dark. Brad doesn't think to turn his sat phone off for noise security and his wife calls at the exact wrong time. The CIA weapons dealer pulls out his own teeth by hand. Before we get to Israel, I am tiring of the lack of screenwriter ingenuity.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I went to see this because my son and father wanted to see it.  I did not read the book and was pretty leery about a Z movie with Brad Pitt in it.  I don't for the most part care for zombie movies.  More than any other fictional creature, they just freak me out.  I guess I have a higher than normal fear of being eaten alive, or maybe having to kill loved ones that are now zombies...who knows?  For that reason, Z movies make me pretty squirmy.With that being said this is NOT a zombie movie.  Just as 28 days later was NOT a zombie movie.  It's an infection movie.  I don't care what anyone says, that's how what I came away with from it.I was pleasantly surprised with this movie.  I liked it a lot.  I would buy it on DVD or anything, but I'd probably watch it again.  It's pretty straight forward, so don't think you could really miss anything the first time around.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: As zombie flicks go this one was ok.  Nothing overly great, nothing overly bad.  it was worth the Amazon rental fee.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: The movie was truly a nail biter. It starts fast and keeps moving. Pitt does a great job as the father of a family caught out during a zombie outbreak. These are the fast vicious type zombies, not the slow stupid ones. I really did enjoy it, maybe it deserves 5 stars I don't know...its right on the edge. The only criticism is how fast the whole thing goes, the guy never sleeps through what must have been days of one harrowing escape after the other. Of course it is a zombie movie so we have to suspend disbelief. Definitely worth watching, cant wait for the sequel.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Don't go into this expecting a theatrical depiction of the book. You'll be disappointed.If however you can separate the two and view this on its own, you'll be fine. Good popcorn movie with loads of action, tense moments, some realistic snafus (like the scientist accidentally offing himself and the badly timed sat-phone call) The effects are solid, the combat and 'Zeke' rampages well done, the script above average.I submit that every actor EXCEPT Brad Pitt does a fine job, from the boy in the apartment to the Israeli female soldier to Mireille Enos. There's depth and credibility in all their performances. Mr. Pitt however seems to have joined the 'I'm a Name so I don't need to act' guild. Shame, as he dampens what would otherwise be a thoroughly enjoyable experience.
summary: The title is all they have in common.

reviewText: When I first saw its trailer in the theatre, I thought it's interesting. Well, the movie was much better.The suspense was very intense from the beginning till the last 15 minutes. It vividly illustrated the term "breath-taking". Many times, I found myself briefly holding my breath because things happened so suddenly, quickly and terrifyingly.It also skillfully portrayed the word "chaos".The special effects looked so real that they made the film more chaotic and horrifying. They were done on a large scale. I had never seen anything like this before. For example, there were scenes from a chopper looking down on to the ground. I could see thousands of people being attacked by zombies. People were fleeing in panic in every direction. It happened to many countries. In another scene, I saw thousands of zombies piling on each other while scaling the border walls.Interestingly, there was no bloody scene. The horror was not built on blood. This made it's more distinguishing.Besides Brad Pitt, the acting of others was engaging too. For instance, in the last scene the actions of the people in the last building were believable.It also depicted family love. It's touching even though it's briefly done.Of course, it had many logical holes but they did not affect its entertaining value.The best thing about this picture was the theme. I thought it's "UNITED WE STAND, DIVIDED WE FALL". It subtly and yet effectively proved that nobody or no country could solve a global problem by himself or itself. We needed help from everybody regardless of their gender, race, age and nationality.UPDATED JULY 28, 2013According to boxofficemojo dot com, below are the financial figures of this picture:Release Date: June 21, 2013.Production Budget: $190 millionDomestic: $186,941,000+ Foreign:  $269,500,000= Worldwide:  $473,020,000That's a staggering amount of money.If you love a movie with Meaningful Plot, interesting Suspense, Terror, and Special Effects, this is a must see.In short, it's one of the BEST that my MONEY CAN GET.
summary: One of the BEST that my MONEY CAN GET in terms of Suspense, Terror, Special Effects and Meaningful Plot

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Brad Pitt did a great Job as producer / co producer.  This movie was the first 'zombie' movie that I found convincing, tense, and entertaining in quite some time.  The extended cut is the one to get.  It has a bit more gore which actually helps the movie in key area's.  The story is actually believable and there are times that feel gripping and tense...as there should be.The effects were quite well done.  The cast is very good.  Production value is of course top notch.I really can't think of anything about the movie that I didn't like...?  The zombies in this movie were refreshingly new in certain ways that make for a more believably dangerous scenario, and the whole premise of how things happened was actually credible in terms of how it was presented, whereas, in most movies of this genera this is not the case.It's definitely worth the rental, and worth buying IF--you're a zombie movie fan or Brad Pitt fan.  I would say, that the only improvement to this movie might have been to include a few more interactions between Pitt and the Zombies but still, it was pretty good as presented.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: We saw World War Z in the theaters (3D) and it was a really great movie experience.  This movie is pure action and suspense...never boring, never dull.  The term "fast paced" is an understatement when applied to this movie!However...perhaps therein lies the problem.  Could it be that this movie is a little TOO fast paced?  I think it might have been better if the movie had slowed down a bit in parts, so we could get to know the people a little better - know what they are feeling.In the movie, Brad Pitt plays a retired United Nations employee named Gerry Lane who is pulled back into service to travel the world in a race against time  (okay, a little cliché, but whatever...)  He must stop a zombie pandemic that is threatening to wipe humanity off the planet! In this pandemic, a person will turn into a ferocious man-eating zombie just 12 seconds after being bitten.Ahh yes.  More zombies!  More apocalypse!Brad Pitt does a fine job in this movie...but then, he always does.  It wasn't his fault that the writers did not include much character development.  In the movie, his character has a wife and two little girls - all wonderfully acted...however, I longed for more....I wanted to get to know these people better.Yes, the movie was fast paced.  The zombies in this flick are literally MANIC, frenzied masses.  These are not the slow lumbering zombies of past movies.  People could get away from those zombies!  Some might say that these "modern" zombies (reminiscent of the crazed creatures in I Am Legend)are scarier than those slow moving zombies of old.  I might politely disagree.  The old style zombies created more suspense.  Will the person get away or not?  The viewer didn't know.  Plus, the old style zombies seemed more disturbingly....human, as opposed to simply CG creations.However....that being said, the movie is still very watchable.  There is not a lot of blood and gore (like on The Walking Dead) so don't expect that.  This is a more "high-tech" zombie flick.  It's good - the acting is good - and the plot is suspenseful.  The first time you watch, you will probably be on the edge of your seat the whole time.So even though I had a few complaints about the movie, overall I would recommend watching it.  World War Z delivers great movie entertainment. I won't spoil the ending for you, since the element of suspense is what the film is based on. We even bought the movie after seeing it in the theater.
summary: Zombies and Brad Pitt together - not a bad combination!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Turned it off and didn't watch the whole thing
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Had no idea this was a zombie movie. Saw that it was new and decided to watch. New twist on where zombies come from and how to get rid of or in this case become invisible to them.

reviewText: This movie is Epic when it comes to Zombies and such! Never seen anything like it, yet hope to see more just like it! Keeps one on their toes, this one!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I enjoyed the book "World War Z" so wasn't getting my hopes up for the movie. I rented it on Amazon and though not at all like the book, it was a tremendous zombie movie (or zekes as they are known in the movie).Brad Pitt did a very credible job as Gerry Lane, former United Nations employee that is called back into service during the zombie pandemic.Mireille Enos does a great job as Karin, wife to Gerry and mother of his children. And Daniella Kertesz plays Segen, a wounded Israeli soldier, very well.Special effects were over-the-top good from the individual closeups of the zombies to the mass hordes that are seen.I was very glad, too, that closed captioning was available in English since I'm partially deaf.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This was a zombie apocalypse movie that attempted to explain the zombie infestation with science. I am not a big Brad Pitt fan but he was OK in this role. I would not classify this movie as outstanding but it was a fun watch. The special effects were top notch, the story line was good (in a land of the walking dead kind of a way), and the acting was good.I rented it and will probably buy it when the price comes down in a year or so. I would definitely give $10 for the blu ray.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: As far Hollywood movies go, this is a realistic depiction of what could happen if the scenario "zombies" were to infiltrate our society. Fast paced action along with crossing political lines and dealing with foreign policy during states of emergency also help break the ice and move conversation along at informal social settings amongst like-minded friends. It is a movie I would watch again for pure cinematography and selected action sequences while carving out some break time for a little snack or R&R.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This was a fast paced zombie thriller. I would have liked more detail, even if the movie was longer. The only thing I didn't like was that there were a few scenes that were identical to The Walking Dead, on Sundays at 9PM, on AMC. I am hooked on that series. That is why I gave it a 4 out of 5 stars. Otherwise it was a great zombie thriller. Not a gory movie. Would recommend for 13 plus.

reviewText: After reading about the re-shooting of the majority of the third act of this movie, I was surprised to find myself enjoying this film at the cinema enough to purchase it. Title: World War Z

reviewText: Dubbed the largest budget zombie flick of all time, there is much expectation surrounding "World War Z". Brad Pitt's production company bought the rights to it in 2007 and has been working toward bringing it to the screen ever since. First of all, calling it the largest budget zombie flick of all time isn't really saying that much since zombie flicks are pretty much the territory of low or no budget filmmakers to begin with. Then you throw in Brad Pitt and put it into the middle of the summer blockbuster season and expectations go through the roof.So, what should you expect? Well, sooner or later, the zombie genre is either going to infect the entire country or drown itself in over-saturation. There are 8 zombie movies slated to release in 2013 and there were 25 released in 2012; most of these are done by low or no budget filmmakers, but the number of zombie movies out there borders on the ridiculous. Lets also not forget the highly successful "Walking Dead" television show. "World War Z" is a step up in quality, but is it all it's cracked up to be?Well just because it is part of the summer blockbuster season doesn't mean that it is chalk-full of action and events. It is a drama in its purest form. Many of the most action packed or awe-inspiring moments are revealed in the trailer and many of these trailer moments spoil some of the best surprises. Fortunately for "WWZ" though, its best moments aren't those heavy CG moments that are revealed in the trailer, but a simple scene where three lightly armed people have to navigate a building that is half infected or the moments that Gerry Lang (Brad Pitt) reveals that his true motivation is his wife and daughters.Despite a couple of really coincidental moments that caused me to roll my eyes a bit (including a plane crash caused by Pitt's character and of course his seat is the only thing that survives the crash), "World War Z" is well written, fast-paced and well performed. To compare it to other zombie movies is like comparing Pepsi-Cola to a lemonade stand; both are good, but one has more money. To compare though, this zombie flick may focus less on the gore and blood than others and Brad Pitt is a tremendous actor that makes this zombie flick better just by his mere presence.There's a catch to enjoying "World War Z" though; maybe two of them. First, you have to love zombie movies because it isn't anything more than that. Secondly, you have to lower your expectations. The movie isn't going to dazzle you in any way shape or form. "WWZ" is a human-interest story with the addition of really intense fast moving bloodthirsty zombies.
summary: OVER SATURATED GENRE AND NOTHING NEW BROUGHT TO THE TABLE
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This is one of those very rare occasions when I actually liked the movie better than the book (and face it, it would have been very difficult to adapt from the book too closely).Of course there are a few holes in the plot, and the ubiquitous suspension of the laws of physics and biology, but not so much that it was a serious distraction.  Brad Pitt did an excellent job, and all other actors did great jobs in their supporting roles.  As long as one doesn't attempt to over think the science, or doesn't expect strong correlation with the book, they won't be disappointed.  Watch it with the idea of being entertained, and if you even remotely enjoy the genre, chances are very good that you will like the film as much as I did.
Title: World War Z
