reviewText: I love zombie movies and I've even read some zombie books World War Z being one of my favorites. And unfortunately the movie nowhere near delivers the intellectually impressive look at the zombie apocalypse that the book does. If you haven't yet do yourself a favor and read the book it is great.Also if you get a chance check outThe Zombie Survival Guide: Complete Protection from the Living Deadit was awesome and even practical.Now the movie is it a good zombie flick it's okay that's all I can say. It struggles to identify itself even as a zombie movie with how the zombies act. And at certain points I was left scratching my head as to what actually was happening and why on-screen. But it was a good movie I like zombies so I gave it three stars. But I'm just sad that they could have done so much with the WWZ source material that they missed out on. And the ending is a letdown in my opinion.With thanks for reading.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Let's get one thing straight: this is not a zombie movie.  It might be called "World War Z," but it bears no resemblance to the book.  They might use the word "zombie" in the movie, but the attacking creatures are more like the aliens in Alien 2 than reanimated corpses.  As a bit of a zombie connoisseur I'm disappointed in this film, and as a Romero zombie traditionalist the notion of a fast "zombie" challenges my suspension of disbelief - it's like putting a holodeck on the Millennium Falcon.  You just wouldn't do that!But for those that didn't grow up with Romero or Fulci zombies I think you'll find World War Z to be a rip-roaring action flick with something for the whole family.  This is also not a horror movie so you can just as easily sit back and watch it with dad this Father's Day as you could with your kids.World War Z is not a horrible movie, but if you want fast "zombies" in a zombie movie I would recommend instead the 2004 remake of Dawn of the Dead.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Saw this in a movie theater shown in 3D and a great sound system, and, for the most part, enjoyed it there.  But even while watching it I felt more like I was just in a long amusement park dark ride, where things keep popping out at you as your ride car ambles through on a track, rather than in a movie theater watching a film with an interesting story and characters you care about.  Characters are introduced to keep the plot moving forward, but are never fleshed out (pun intended) except for the lead character, Gerry, played by Brad Pitt.  So, while the action is formidable and the CGI effects are truly amazing, it never really grabs you in the gut or heart, and it's obvious it was meant to.  My recommendation, then, is to be sure and see it in a big-screen, great-sound-system 3D movie theater if you're at all interested in it--it will not play well on a small screen (which in my opinion includes even the biggest screen home TV, even if it's a 3D model).
summary: Forgettable fun in a theater in 3D, but that's about it

reviewText: Not bad, not bad at all - certainly not as bad as the detractors make out. This is a large-scale zombie film with some great FX and a decent storyline. The few criticisms I have of this film relate to the color and sound - the colors are consistently washed out, all greens and browns. It is not what one would call a vibrant looking film but filled with muddy colors. Even the sunlight looks rather dusty and brown. The sound is also of the mumbling quality. Another drawback is that the first half of the film is focused entirely on the children. Now listen, I have nothing against children but this is a zombie film, and virtually every scene has Pitt running around with his kids in his arms. These little whiners were starting to get on my nerves. We all know Pitt is a great father but for God's sake, does he have to play one even in a zombie film?

reviewText: This film is a perfect illustration of why the British film industry shouldn't hire Hollywood mega-stars to prop up their boring scripts.  This is the Downton Abbey of zombie movies.  You feel nothing, and I mean NOTHING for any of the characters in this disaster of a disaster film.  The protaganist's family is the most annoying, useless stage prop I've seen since the "Pancakes!" kid from Cabin Fever.  I take that back.  At least "Pancakes!" garnered a head scratch or two.  While we're talking kids, Dakota Fanning in "War of the Worlds" ain't got nothin' on the wailing daughter riding the shopping cart in this movie.  She SHRIEKS going up stairs, she SHRIEKS going down stairs.  She does nothing but SHRIEK.  Even the zombies were too annoyed to get near her.  It was enough to make you pull your hair out.  Everything about this movie rubbed me the wrong way.  The last 30 minutes of this film was so boring, I started to nod off.  YOU SHOULD NOT BE NODDING OFF WHEN YOU'RE WATCHING A ZOMBIE MOVIE!!!!  World War ZZZZzzzzzzzz...  Please, someone ask Brad Pitt to never act in anything with a CGI budget of less than $10,000.  I can't be the only one who noticed that zombies would randomly disappear from the dogpile (they probably ran out of memory on the 486 computer they used.)  I can see why this bombed in the theaters.  This should be an Amazon Prime freebee.

reviewText: Being an avid reader and a movie lover, I learned long ago to divorce the two. I tend to look upon them as being related but not the same. This allows me to enjoy one or the other, both or neither; but based solely on each version. If you have read the book and are thinking of seeing the movie, (or vice versa), I suggest you look at them as being related.The movie is intense and well made. It is fast and heavy action with less gore than I expected. The zombies are freaky creepy. The zombie ant hill gives me nightmares. The acting was good. I'm not a huge Brad Pitt fan so his being a pretty boy made no difference to me. I think he did well and was believable. Overall I enjoyed the thrills and chills. I vote it up for a good time and will watch it multiple times. I like the uncut version better though really there is not that much difference. I really only noted the chase through the alley as being the easiest difference to spot; in the uncut version it is longer and more intense. In my opinion, definitely worth having.I enjoy the multiple ways to watch in this package and believe it to be the best deal. But them my family uses all the various ways of watching.
summary: Don't Expect The Book. Enjoy The Movie.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Without reading the Max Brooks authored book that the film is based on, "World War Z" is just a $200 million zombie movie that had a ton of issues during its filming process. It's already developed a reputation for agitating longtime fans of the book since the trailers have already revealed that the film is nothing like its source material. It was expected to be as disastrous as the apocalypse the film predicted, but early reviews were surprisingly positive and offered a little beacon of hope in an otherwise dark tunnel.As a Muse fan, it was a welcome surprise to find out that lead singer Matthew Bellamy contributed to the film's soundtrack. What's disappointing about it is that it only seems like Bellamy contributed music to the opening and end credits while everything else in the middle mostly revolves around really moody piano arrangements.It takes little time for the world to be turned upside down, which is probably for the best. Hearing about how Gerry quit his job at the UN to make pancakes for his family or Gerry complaining about his family not knowing how to put dirty dishes in the sink isn't exactly a riveting experience. What's most impressive about "World War Z" is its size. You can literally see this virus destroy huge cities with vast populations. The creatures they become move in numbers like ants, sprint at full speed, and will often lunge off buildings or walls built to protect cities without hesitation. While the events are intense, the zombies are awkward. They throw their heads against car windows to try and get the warm, pulsating, fleshy center still found inside trying to survive. The raptor-like squawking is complete overkill. Their constant chattering and ant-like movement can be chalked up for trying something different, but the squawking seems pointless unless they were using it to communicate which they don't.Coming back around to the size aspect, the atmosphere of the film is really strong at times particularly in the apartment complex when Gerry and his family are trying to reach the roof; those claustrophobic hallways with the flickering fluorescent lights and flares being their only hope is unforgettable. There are moments of intelligence, as well. Their solution to the outbreak is fairly clever. The dialogue shines at times. Andrew Fassbach's (Elyes Gabel) speech about Mother Nature being a serial killer is fantastic.The film can't decide if it wants the viewer to sympathize with humanity or get lost in the swarm of zombies as Brad Pitt searches for a cure. The first 30 minutes or so are gripping and contain hints of intimate human relationships, but once Gerry embarks for South Korea it's just this wild goose chase while everyone who isn't Gerry just sits around and rots. Some scenes from then on have memorable moments, but feel like filler overall. It's also extremely disheartening to be watching a zombie film when there are no headshots shown in the film. If "Warm Bodies" from earlier this year wasn't proof already, "World War Z" throws the rules that zombies once had out the window. Humanity should falter in the face of oblivion during the apocalypse in zombie films. That's kind of the point. Without that sense of hopelessness, it just winds up feeling like another walk in the park."World War Z" doesn't end. It's the end of the world and the film stops in the middle of the story. At just under two hours, the zombie fan in you will wish for an extra 30 minutes just to witness some sort of closure. The blockbuster film isn't awful, but it doesn't have the balls to be a real zombie film. It deserves credit for always having a strong female character in every setting Gerry found himself in while a few of the ideas and some of the writing is commendable, but the film has too many noticeable issues; too many cooks in the kitchen without a satisfying recipe for disaster. Semi-entertaining for what it is, "World War Z" doesn't accomplish anything "28 Days Later" didn't 11 years ago for 1/25 of the budget.
summary: In case of emergency stay ninja quiet

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Brad Pitt has gone from youthful sex symbol to versatile actor and producer.  His biggest project to date is this filmic adaptation of Max (Mel's son) Brooks' novel, World War Z, chronicling a massive, worldwide zombie apocalypse. For a subgenre that has ranged from classic horror, (Night of the Living Dead), to science fiction, (Resident Evil), to modern updates, (Dawn of the Dead remake), and parodies, (Zombieland and Shaun of the Dead), this film represents a rare depiction of the zombie invasion as a global, mass annihilation.  Previously, these films focused on a small group of survivors (TV's The Walking Dead) with a news blackout and no idea as to the magnitude of the infection.  After publicized problems with the screenplay and director Mark Forster's (Monsters Ball, Finding Neverland) rough cut (particularly a climactic battle scene), a new ending was shot, and the result is a remarkably engaging film.Gerry (Brad Pitt) and his wife, Karin (Mireille Enos), ready their two daughters for school and get caught in a traffic jam in downtown Philadelphia. Suddenly all hell breaks loose and panic sets in amid an invasion of zombies who are bent on mindlessly attacking and converting humans into the undead.  As cities fall worldwide, the infection spreads exponentially with startling speed as the family flees to Newark for supplies and a lifeline from Gerry's former UN boss, but while the family finds a brief refuge aboard a US Navy ship, Gerry is called into service to find the source of the infection or risk having his family kicked off the ship as non-essential personnel.  Tracking down random clues across the globe in such disparate locales as South Korea, Israel, and Wales, the trail for a cause and potential cure proves challenging as time runs out on humanity.In many ways, this film, which shares much in common with pandemic tales as Contagion, Outbreak, and The Andromeda Strain, is more a thriller than horror, and that's not a bad thing.  Rather than relying on gross out murders and graphic blood spattered effects, this film looks at the bigger picture without sacrificing the more intimate moments of sheer terror, not an easy balance.  Don't let that PG13 rating fool you!  Some scenes are suspenseful and agonizing as the threat of zombies is ever present.The film, particularly in the Newark apartment scenes and an unbearable moment of truth at a World Health Organization lab, is like one big funhouse ride where the scares are just around the corner.  Other memorable set pieces include the opening pandemonium in Philly, which is well crafted and builds to an alarming level, a walled in city of Jerusalem stunningly challenged by a growing sea of undead, and perhaps the best moment, a horrifying passenger plane flight from hell that starts innocently enough but quickly devolves into an impossible situation.The film takes the scary notion of fast running zombies from 28 Days Later and adds even more lethal traits as in their ability to not only swarm like insects, but to hurl themselves with great ferocity at their intended victims even through car windshields.  Their victims aren't devoured as in other films, but rather a bite turns them into more zombies almost instantaneously.  They are also real sensitive to sound as Gerry learns at the worst possible moment.What distinguishes this film above most others is its smarts.  The script, while written by many hands, still shows an intelligent approach to a devastating crisis, and the dialogue never sounds phony.  Further, the film is like one big mystery with nature's clues in full view waiting for Gerry to piece together a solution.  Some of the plot points are a bit open ended and push the limits of plausibility, but things move so swiftly and convincingly, that most won't mind.The supporting cast is effective in brief roles with a strong turn by Daniella Kertesz as a soldier.  But this is Pitt's show, and he is the right leading man who has the presence and charisma to carry even a zombie film. Being able to improvise and display cool under pressure, he is the ideal savior that the world needs.  Perhaps his Gerry is guilty of being too perfect, but he does it so well.(It is amusing to note that Gerry and his family become guardians of an orphaned boy, and one wonders if Angelina Jolie was smiling at the parallels with her and Pitt's real life, nuclear family.)With a mega-budgeted production, the CG effects are a standout especially when creating the hoards of zombies, and there are many effective camera shots with some particularly startling, overhead views.  There is also great use of sound effects that add to the visceral chills while the brooding, pulsing music score (Marco Beltrami) complements the tension.A thrill ride from beginning to end, World War Z is a thoroughly entertaining, scary epic that takes the zombie lore and heightens the stakes with an impressive budget and a star turn by an actor/producer at the top of his game.
summary: World War Z Takes Zombies to a New Level
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This was a fairly straightforward thriller, one thrill and chase scene after another, that wasn't filled with gore and sex.  The first "zombie" film I've ever seen.I think Brad Pitt commented that this was the first movie he's made recently that his children can see. I'd still wait until they were 13 and over because the topic/views of killing and death, as well as the simple politics that flow in the film, are more suitable for teens and up.

reviewText: When I read in several publications this movie was in production and starred Brad Pitt I thought " At Last " a high budget horror movie.While the storyline and acting are good it fell way short of my expectations for one reason ...  it's a PG-13 movie.Zombie movies are a unique genre of horror in that they need to be rated R in order to convey the real horror and fear by graphic depictions of people being bit and then changing into a zombie and finally graphically depicting the killing of a zombie.All of the ingredients missing in this movie which frankly left me yawning.If you have not seen this movie and are thinking of purchasing it I highly recommend you rent it first lest you be disappointed and out of twenty dollars for your DVD purchase.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: At first I was unsure about getting this. "Another Zombie flick" I asked myself. OK Brad Pitt stars, but? Then there was a price deal and I decided to add it to my library on Amazon Instant Video. I loved it! Plenty of "zombie" action if you like that. The storyline  is different in a way. Compared to other "zombie" flicks there is an actual mystery/suspense element to this one. A twist. You follow along as the Pitt character, a UN investigator coming back from retirement, tries to track this infection to it's source in order to create a cure. I won't spoil it for you. You'll have to watch to see what happens. All in all an enjoyable movie!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Entertaining. Not as dumb as most Zombie movies. I am not a fan of  Zombie movies but this one is somewhat watchable.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: As soon as the word came down that Brad Pitt's production company, Plan B, outbid Leonardo DiCaprio'sproduction company for film rights to Max Brooks' utterly superb zombie novel, World War Z, I knew this film was doomed.Furthermore, when word came down that the film wasn't going to follow the format of the book, any lingeringhope I had that this film might even be mediocre was squashed.  And I was right.  What a monumentaldisappointment this film is in every way, beginning with the company that secured the film rights all the way to the endof the movie.  I know Max Brooks probably got a very nice check from this movie deal, but I'm willing to bet he'sshed a tear or two over how the film turned out.  Pitt's stale acting, the incohesive and contrived storyline, and thelack of character chemistry make for a very unnerving viewing experience, particularly for those of us who lovedBrooks' novel.  If you really want to experience World War Z, and are willing to forego watching the movie, really yourbest option is to read the book.  The book is not only a hallmark within zombie literature, but it's also a great readregardless if you're interested in this genre.  In other words, skip this dud of a movie and go right to the novel.  Andthen if you want to see the movie, do so.  And you'll more than likely agree with my review.....
summary: It doesn't get any worse than this, folks.  Atrocious is a good word for this film....
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Quite possibly one of the best movies of the year.  So many people have criticized the movie for not being like the books.  Get over it!  Film is an entirely different medium and art form.  This movie was exactly what it needed to be.  Thrilling, exciting, well written and well acted.  The special FX were fantastic!  This is a zombie horror film for the masses!

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I read the book World War Z and found it to be very nice. If I remember correctly, World War Z came from the Zombie Survival Guide which are both written by Max Brooks. If you read the Zombie Survival Guide first, the best part was at the end when Max Brooks explains various times in history when zombie incidents occurred. The stories followed to the letter how one is suppose to survive according to what Max Brooks written in the first segment of the guide. Later Max Brooks released a separate World War Z novel that is based on interview-like stories from various survivors who explain how the war unfolded and how humanity came out on top. The book is written in a way that takes a journalism approach to what unfolded as told by various people who participated in the event. It's so well written that it's very hard to tell if Max Brooks is actually writing about a real event, or if it's fictional.With that in mind, I wasn't sure what to expect with the movie World War Z. The movie concentrates on a single man and his effort to figure out what causes the epidemic and how to shut it down. His reason behind figuring this out is a bit selfish as he wants to protect his family and don't want him and his family losing the protection of staying on a aircraft carrier. His search goes around the world from Korea, to Israel, to Wales, and various other places. The point is this movie attempts to show a worldwide issue with zombies.The movie plays out surprisingly well. I personally found it good. Other zombie movies tend to focus in on gore and a group of survivors who kill off large population of undead. This movie isn't quite so in following that typical formula. It does have its gore moments, but the reaction from people tend to be a bit more realistic. Matter of fact, Brad Pitt's character is extremely vulnerable and he doesn't really even know how to fight them and many times he comes close and he's tries to avoid them as best as possible.The movie has some surprising support characters. When Brad Pitt first arrived to Korea, he met with some Army Rangers and Navy SEALs special forces to guard him. They were quite well done and while watching, it felt intense as they combat the zombies and attempted to get Brad Pitt's character airborne. I felt in some cases too many of the characters bravely gave up their lives. In just a span of five minutes, two special forces operator in Korea just knowingly killed themselves with little reaction or remorse from anyone.My favorite support character would have to been Daniella Kertesz's character who is a Israel security force. I felt they made an excellent pair and felt their relationship to aid each other was very sincere. Not to mention she was the only character that survived being with Brad Pitt the longest to the end.Overall the movie was surprisingly good. The ending was so-so but overall the entire movie had a nice touch and I felt that it didn't fall victim to the typical zombie movies that plague the market today of just blasting away at everything and everyone and somehow surviving in the end after a few of the party member being brutally eaten. The movie doesn't quite follow the book as the book isn't based on any single character but as a whole. I felt the movie sort of followed the book lead in that it provided a lot of different support characters each fighting off their own war against the zombies. Overall the movie is a good spin off of the book and I personally enjoyed it. Highly recommend watching it.
summary: Read the book and for years heard about the movie

Title: World War Z

reviewText: The zombie genre has alot to live up to. A few bonafide classics, a number of movies of varying degree inbetween, and a whole lot of terrible, never should have wasted the celluloid atrociousness. This movie is no classic, but is way better than alot of the zombie fare.Good acting, a fast moving plot, and a big budget that you can see in some of the fantastic, large scale special effects, are both refreshing, and something you don't see enough of. In fact, the big budget is the greatest thing this movie has going for it, and you get to see hordes of zombies, all over the world, and massive military intervention. There are a few clever twists, and it's nice to see a zombie movie get the big budget treatment. That said, there was little to no backstory, they cut the gore down to get a PG13 rating, and the whole thing ends a little too nice and neatly for a good horror movie. Definitely no classic, but worth a watch.
summary: Some nice elements, worth a watch, but no classic

reviewText: This reminds me a lot of Independence Day with Will Smith, whereas you have a killer cast and huge budget with an old story.  The difference is that Independence Day didn't pull this maddening camera crap, whereas they get so close and spastic that you can't tell what is happening, even with replay, slow-mo, enlargement, and a translator from the production crew.  And are we through with zombies yet?  Now that we tweaked them to run, why not drive cars and fly planes?  How about a major wrap with hybrid zombie vampire werewolf whatevers?  Digression . . . the film holds your attention and has some fear factor - Pitt is always watchable - but it wasn't worth an early fee I paid for being hooked by enticing trailers.  To quote Pitt in Killing Them Softly, "It's not a country, just a business."  Now gimme my money back.  Lesson learned.  Next time I'll wait till the fee drops.
summary: Big Budget, Good Cast, Old Story, Bad Action Sequences

Title: World War Z

reviewText: A lot of folks believed this film was destined to fail. From the release delay of six months, to the rewrite of the entire third act, it looked as though the adaptation of the popular novel would turn out to be a massive failure, almost to the tune of $200 million. However, despite these problems, not to mention the extensive reshoots and rumors of heavy disputes between the director and lead star, World War Z is an entertaining and smart epidemic thriller that boasts a strong lead performance from Brad Pitt and some eerily intense action sequences.The story revolves around former U.N. employee Gerry Lane (played by Pitt) in a race against time as a deadly and mysterious pandemic threatens to wipe out the human population. While the world struggles to hold on, Lane traverses the globe in a search to discover the origin of the disease in hopes of creating a cure.I have to say, I didn't have strong hopes for this film. I'm in the minority of people who didn't enjoy the book, and after reading about all the issues during production, I was expecting this to be a total flop. I was pleasantly surprised when I saw the movie for myself, however, as the production team made some great choices that ultimately saved the film from being a disaster. From what I've read, the entire third act was redone, and is one of the strongest parts of the movie. Instead of the original ending finding Gerry in a massive showdown with millions of zombies in Russia, the rewritten script leads our protagonist to Cardiff, Whales in a much smaller, and creepy, setting. This leads to a much more intense climax that is a welcome break from the absolutely massive set pieces earlier in the film.As mentioned earlier, Pitt is very good here, not only as the smart and resilient U.N. worker, but also as the caring father and husband who ultimately just wants his family to be safe. His wife, played by Mireille Enos, is also very good in the movie, although I think she could have been given more to do.Overall I was very surprised how much I enjoyed this film. Don't believe all the negative news that came along with this movie; do yourself a favor and see it for yourself.
summary: Despite Multiple Production Issues, This Film Is Entertaining and Intense
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: When all is said and done, this movie is about Brad Pitt telling us we all need to work together and sing together under the U.N. banner as our savior.  This happens after his many miraculous escapes from not just limping slow moving Zombies but sprinting and athletic Zombies, who can climb high walls and buildings, fall down and fling themselves anywhere and get up and run again.  It seems to me that maybe this Zombie virus might be a good thing for out of shape fatties like me who have to worry about a heart attack.  I say, down with national sovereignty and the FDA drug approval process.The film is also a disappointment in that like the other famous actor, Tom Cruse in “War of the Worlds” with the Martians and other movies of the same theme the hero and his family are saved from all the massive death and tragedy that everyone else experiences after many miraculous escapes.  What is it about movies with big budgets and famous actors in movies about worldwide destruction, the main character and his family never suffer any loss?  These movies remind me of my growing up years where every action TV show ended with the good-guy winning and he and all his family and buds are standing around and smiling together with some happy song in the background.  Why is this?  People will not plunk down $15 dollars to watch a movie with all kinds of special effects and worldwide destruction and famous and well-known actors if the main character and his family suffer any death or tragedy?  I am glad I do not plunk down good money for movies like these.
summary: Praise for the UN our savior

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Originally, this was going to be a "Children of Men"-type dirge, with Brad Pitt's character Gerry Lane going around the globe (how? one wonders) interviewing survivors of the zombie apocalypse in the manner of a report to the United Nations.  Parallels to social problems like climate change were to be drawn.  It was to be a political allegory.  Evidently everyone involved was prepared for Oscar nominations.Oy vey.  While traces of some of that still exist in the final product, we're thankful nevertheless that the suits at Paramount finally insisted that director Marc Forster & co. steer this zombie movie back to its popcorn roots.  We're also thankful that Pitt struggled through all the pre-production heartaches (too numerous and well-documented to list here) to get this entertaining film made.  It can be truly said that the opening action sequence, with Pitt and his family stuck in traffic in downtown Philly when the zombies attack, is destined to be considered a classic.  There a few good jump-scares.  I also liked the global sweep of the film, as we follow Pitt to Korea to Israel to Wales.  (Wasn't actually shot in all those places, of course.)  But some of the usual problems that come with too many script rewrites -- rewrites done after much of the film was finished -- are evident.  For instance: mid-way through the film, we learn that these zombies go "dormant" if they're not stimulated by sound.  But earlier in the film, a gang of zombies try to bust through the front-door of an apartment of a Latino family who have been quiet as churchmice.  And as for the movie's solution to the zombie epidemic?  I won't spoil it, but let's just say that someone might pour a glass of milk and *take a sip* before realizing that the milk has gone over.  There won't be an invisible shield around that glass.  So ... not very logical.  But then, we learn that our good friend Damon Lindelhof, writer of that epic piece of illogical crap known as "Prometheus", rewrote much of the third act.  Figures.Speaking of illogical: are these things really zombies anyway?  I thought you had to be dead first to qualify as a zombie.  Instead, people turn into funhouse horrors within 30 seconds after they're bitten, and they're not killed beforehand.  This makes the creatures something else, in my opinion.Oh well.  All in all, this was a fun thrill ride.  4 out 5.  Oh, and if you liked it, good news: Paramount is busy right now working on a first draft (that they'll not actually use) for the sequel.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: We'll just got back from the premier of WWZ and thought it was a great movie.  I'd give it a 3 1/2 stars but Amazon does not give this option.Descent plot, great action throughout and a good ending to save the World.  I think I would have preferred to have a different opening to it before Pitt and family got hit in Philadelphia.  They said the white house got taken down, Washington DC whipped out and the president killed so that probably would've made a better opening scene even though it would not show show Pitt in the opening scene.I thought the director did a descent job as well.  I had read several times the ending was entirely reshot as the original was too complicated.Their was a scene taken off our very own Walking Dead that will not be a surprise to many when you see it.If you could label the movie something it would be like "Dawn of the Dead" zombies on speed though.  Swarming Hordes were very impressive on the big screen, but the majority of these scenes were displayed at least in segments on several of the trailors.We'll I hope for a good unrated DVD  to follow, director cut etc....I think most will come away saying it was a good movie but just didn't blow them away.  I think some of walking dead episodes could be labeled as blowing you away however.  So for the amount of money spent I think the crew got an extended vacation in several countries in the process and maybe bigger pay checks then they should have?I do have to commend them on doing such a movie showing the lack of gore and blood.  This was a big plus and should show others it's not really needed as most movies portray it these days.Go check it out!!
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: The fist half of "World War Z" was a watchable but not terribly original zombie flick.  Visually it was a stunner but was lacking in the story area.  If you are looking for great acting the only character who was fully fleshed out was Brad Pitt's playing some kind of former U.N. envoy.  I found myself longing for George Romero's "Dead" trilogy, "Shaun of the Dead", or "21 Days Later".  It's at the midway point when the film stops concentrating on killing the zombies and focuses on finding a cure for the pandemic that the proceedings come to life.  I found myself on the edge of my seat as opposed to slumped in it as I was earlier in the film.  Anybody with the patience should wait this one out because it takes time to get started.
summary: Comes Alive in the Home Stretch

reviewText: I got excited for this movie every time I saw the movie trailer somewhere online. It started out great and interesting and it kept that pace through the movie until Brad Pitt goes to a research facility to share a theory about a possible cure.From there all the suspense and excitement went out the window. I could tell that everyone in the theater lost the grip of suspense the movie had on them when people started snickering at some of the zombie acting.There is never any exciting answers or battles once Brad leaves the facility. No memorable story or grand finale scenes to leave you thinking. So the movie ends and you are left with the idea that the story is not over. Then comes the credits. Lame. So I was let down by the amazing trailer.Not a title worth owning but something worth watching on a movie night when there is nothing better to watch.
summary: Notice how the ratings are not mostly favorable. It was a let down. Wait for rental!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: We'd heard the hype, and how well this movie had done over the summer, so when it became available, we decided to give it a look. The most positive thing I can say about renting it is it saved us the cost of going to the theater to see it, and we didn't have to shell out the bucks to own it. It's worth a look, but that's about it.  It did hold my interest, but my wife only barely made it through, fighting off Mr. Sandman about halfway through. As has been covered in detail in other reviews, there is a lot - a LOT - that you have to be willing to overlook; an eager willingness to suspend your disbelief is needed to get you through this movie. Oh, sure, if you want to accept every premise and every scenario without question or analysis, then I can see why you'd like this movie. But if you have even a slightly critical eye, you're going to spot the plot holes and improbabilities from a mile away, and many of them will nag at you throughout the movie. No spoilers here, but suffice it to say that there's at least a half-dozen spots I can think of off the top of my head where you'll find yourself saying, "Really? You really want me to believe that?"  All that said, if you are in the mood for some really well-done zombies, and an improbable round-the-world hunt for a cure for those zombies, and you don't mind putting logic and reason on the shelf for a couple of hours, then give this movie a shot. Just don't say I didn't warn you.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: It is not the worst zombie movie out there, but it is also not the best. This movie tries to bring a new spin on zombies with quick running, biting, and infecting, but this does little to make a very predictable, and not very exciting movie good.  There is plenty of action, zombies running every where, but that is it, mostly running zombies and Brad Pit running from zombies,  except when he is riding a squeaky bicycle.  I could go through a whole list of plot holes and just stupidities but lets just leave it at from the very beginning to the end they always seem to do things the hard way and never use any common sense.  If you like zombie movies in general, this can entertain, but despite big name actor and budget, at the end of the day,  it is only another zombie movie and just an average one at that.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: World War Z lacks the grit and "bite" required for its type of genre outing.  Despite its emphasis on zombism as a pathogen, its infected are just a little bit too refined, and inhumane.  The film is usually looking at them from 3000 feet, literally and metaphorically, which detaches the audience from the horror of the scenario.  The characters are also pretty flat.  Brad Pitt is a patriarch, and his wife and daughters are vulnerable.  Everyone else is a bureaucrat, a soldier, or a refugee.  The film intends to serve some kind of National Geographic version of zombie horror film making and loses story in the process.
summary: Oddly Sterile Zombie Picture With An Undeserved Happy Ending

Title: World War Z

reviewText: The best thing that could be said about "World War Z" (the film) is also the worst thing: it's inoffensive. They have effectively homogenized zombies. Herein lies the major problem: zombies = horror. If you're making a zombie movie it should have some scary things in it. The average horror fan expects this. While many aspects of the film work the bland presentation speaks to the motivation of capitalizing on a popular trend and emasculating it to the point you can get the youngsters in without parents complaining.The problems arise in trying to capitalize on a genre without really understanding it. In the theatre the final zombie confronting Brad Pitt was drawing derisive giggling. It was making facial expression similar to that of Ron Jeremy (those of you old enough to recognize the reference will understand the silliness) while making chattering noise similar to that of a dolphin "laughing".Another problem was that the zombies were constantly falling. They were falling over edges, off roofs, over each other: no chance to send one sprawling was spared. A minor distraction comes in trying to anticipate what they're going to fall off next.The best way to get a feel for what you're up against in "World War Z" is to take "28 Days Later" and drop it in a blender with "Rise of the Planet of the Apes". One has to expect this, though, the film is rating PG-13 (which was probably their first mistake). A properly done zombie movie is not for the whole family. Hell, it's not for most adults.They make a nodding concession by having one of the soldiers say, "You can put a few rounds in their chest to slow them down but the only thing that seems to work is to get them in the head". The problem is that they drop with shots to the chest. It seems the fear of ratings made the producers avoid explicitness you can find on primetime TV.What saves the film is the pacing. It moves along keeping attention easily by presenting believable characters and not becoming complacent.The best way to view this will be through "Pay Per View". The cost in the theatre was ridiculous for what was delivered. If I decided to go for the home copy it will be a year or two after release when it's lowered to the more appropriate price tag of $10.00. Anything else would leave me feeling exploited for a second time.***Spoiler***Part of the problem with homogenizing a genre is breaking the rules that makes it work. Brad Pitt finds a solution to the problem (not a cure) in the idea that the undead are trying to spread the infection. What ever side of the zombie debate you fall on (fast or slow, smart or stupid) nobody has dared to take the scare out of them by suggesting you can just inoculate against drawing their interest.
summary: At Least You Won't Fall Asleep
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I really enjoyed this movie & it left me wanting more.  This could be taken 2 ways but in this instance  it's meant as a complement.  The storyline was well developed as well as the main character.  The remainder of the cast were as they were meant to be, supporting roles.  I believe these zombies are the best to date.  I'm a huge zombie fan & have an extensive collection of Zombie movies, mini series, & tv series.  The most important features of a Zombie as far as I'm concerned are make-up & movement.  The make-up wasn't as gorey as most other Zombie flicks but the movements were extraordinary.  They were extremely fast & they had ticks which to me took them to a whole new level.  Nothing like a full on global Zombie Apocalypse!  I will watch this movie many more times which makes this one a keeper.  This is the only Zombie movie I've seen where they actually came up w/a solution for the problem.  You'll have to watch & see to find out because there's nothing worse than someone giving you spoilers of a movie you haven't seen yet.  I gave this movie ★★★★ stars because I felt the make-up could've been better.  My guess is the Zombies moved @ such a fast pace they didn't feel the need to go into great detail as far as the make-up was concerned.  I wholeheartedly recommend this flick to any & all Zombie fans.  I  would like to recommend a great Zombie mini series called DEAD SET.  It's takes  place in England & the majority of the film takes place on the Great Britain Big Brother  set.  Both make-up & movement are extraordinary.  Make sure if you're in the US that  it's in the Region I format or else it won't play on your dvd player.  If you have a multi  zone player then it won't matter what region it is.  World War Z - Buy it !  NOW ! ! !
Title: World War Z

reviewText: When I saw that Brad Pitt was to be the leading actor I figured the movie would be chock full of P.C. bull blaming probably former President Bush for yet some other catastrophe despite the fact the mans been out of office for half a decade.What I found was a thrill ride of a movie featuring probably my favorite theme, "Zombies". There was no blatant political correctness and in fact if anything the military was shown in a positive light. Though Mr. Pitt may be the first and only U.N. employee to ever accomplish anything his heroics sure did a lot of bacon saving in this movie.In short I'm glad to see Mr. Pitt in something non melodramatic for a change or cast in some idiotic love-comedy. Oh, and there was probably the worst movie I have ever seen that Mr. Pitt was a lead actor in that also featured Kate Blanchette.......cannot think of the name of the dreadful movie but what almost became an international incident came down to be caused by two Middle Eastern children stupidly playing with a gun and accidentally shooting the usually very talented Ms Blanchette....on a bus....going somewhere for some reason....I think it was a tourist related trip (though why anyone would choose to take a bus ride through the lunar terrain of that part of the world escapes me, perhaps it was just to get out in the world and eat left handed while your wife gets treated like a dog).Back to this movie. The only thing that disappointed me was that it was too short. It was so much fun I could have gone another hour without even thinking about it running too long. Great fun, well done in every way and from what I have heard the entire movie was all accomplished by the efforts of Mr. Pitt. So, despite the fact that we probably agree on nothing politically my hat is off to you Mr. Pitt and thank you for the entertaining and VERY exciting movie!
summary: I was really expecting to be really let down.......not!

reviewText: "World War Z" (2013). . .We enjoyed this one - I thought it was a good, intelligent zombie flick, more in the hyper-realist mode of "28 Days" and "The Walking Dead" rather than the camp horror of the George Romero franchises. I'm not normally a big Brad Pitt fan, but I found myself drawn to his surprisingly understated (though impossibly hunky) NGO-veteran hero. The pace of the movie's first two thirds was intense, and intelligently built on the audience's familiarity with the conventions of earlier zombie epics. I also liked how all the characters responded to the crisis believably -- while the mobs around them panicked, the main players made methodical, rational choices, and their reactions seemed to ring true.The frantic pace of the movie's start and its terrorism allegories gave way to a slower-paced, pleasantly surprising and anti-climactic third act, which settled back into a more conventional zombies-as-public-health narrative... I'm sure a lot of the negative reviews here an elsewhere have to do with the relative lack of gristle and graphic mayhem, which fans weaned on the bone-chewing gore of "The Walking Dead" will consider a shortcoming. But there's room for all kinds of zombie flicks, and this one had a nice, epic scope, along with an admittedly soft "Hollywood ending." This didn't ruin it for me, although I can see where other folks are coming from. It's a thrilling blockbuster, though, and definitely worth watching. Grrr. Argh. (Joe Sixpack, Slipcue movie reviews)
summary: Fast-paced, intelligent zombie flick. Give it a 4.5.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: What a lost opportunity. WWZ was such a great book, it could have been a great movie or mini-series.Instead, Brad Pitt purchased the rights and made a vanity vehicle out of it, thereby ruining it for all of us.  WWZ was a serious approach to horror literature, and made the most of the zombie genre. I was so looking forward to a great film adaptation.If 'The Walking Dead' is an example of the right way to treat this genre, then 'WWZ' is exactly the opposite.

reviewerName: D & L Nolan "Dan, Lynsey & the little ladies"
reviewText: Wonder how many women put their two-cents in on "World War Z"? Probably not too many. I am female, late-twenties and my idea of some good "scary" movies are "Jurassic Park" and "Deep Impact...(try not to eye roll.) Thrilling, gives you some chills, but doesn't leave you staring at your ceiling at night trying to translate if the popping sound of the ice maker is actually an intruder fixing to slay your family. Get me, ladies? Oh, and I 'used' to think zombies were extremely lame.The Unrated version of WWZ is significantly more graphic than the version I saw in the theater, but certainly nothing I couldn't handle. A few heavy cringes...that's all. However, it literally grabs you and doesn't let go. The large segment in the lab, is one of the more thrilling movie scenes I have ever endured. It is crazy good. I thought Gerry Lane was a touching, smart, and pretty bad-a** character and his love for his family was a beautiful part of the film. I am certainly no movie critic and am not judging on authenticity from the book, but from a woman's perspective this one shouldn't be missed!
summary: A Zombie flick a woman can enjoy!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This movie is just another virus / zombie movie in an already crowded genre with some decent acting and action scenes to help keep it going. I particularly liked the scenes of zombies climbing over each other to scale walls.Here are a few things that make this film slightly different, but not better than other same type movies.1). The main character has to travel to various locations in his mission to find the answer; so at least you experience different settings and are introduced to new characters along the way, not that any character is all that important to the plot.2). Lots of zombies but no gore, Zombies want to bite you but not eat you. So, this is like a bloodless zombie movie.-- When the zombies are shot etc, the director makes a point of leaving out the splatter.  This concept of no visual blood letting, did not seem to distract from the film suspense or sense of danger.  One scene in particular has their hand cut off, but you only see the action of this being done and never the effect of the hand falling off or bleeding out, etc..3). Once bitten you have all of 9 seconds before you turn.  In other zombie movies it may take a few days. So, this infection spreads like wild fire.4). The main character (Brad Pitt) brought across a true feeling of "family". At the very start of the movie, his family's needs to be protected from the zombies, You can sense he has the parental nature in his acting which the movie captures well.Overall Thoughts:I have seen this same type of film at least a dozen times with a similar plots; of avoiding being bitten, while trying to save yourself,your fiends, and fight your way to discovering the answer to save the world. This movie has the same concept as most all of these type of films, and did not set itself a distinct.If you watched "I am Legend" with Will Smith you notice a difference; I am legend had infected vampires who lived underground and came out at night looking for the main character will smith, while will tried to find a cure in his basement.  In this movie "world war z" the main character travels to locations avoiding zombies while looking for the answer.  All these viral infected zombie movies have the same premise, and once you see a few you may find it harder and harder to enjoy the next remake, which was the case for me.This is why some SCI-FI movies have such a wide rating scale, some 5 stars others 1 or 2 stars, because if you only were exposed to one other similar movie, then you tend to become more engrossed in the movie and its characters and may rate it higher.  I rated it 3 stars because the plot seem lifted from "_______ ______ zombie movie, with a different director and actors.So is this a bad movie?  No not really. It suffers from the fact that many other movies have been done already and in some cases they did it slightly better.

reviewText: A friend of mine talked me into trying out this one.  I was very unsure, having been just about "zombied" to death--and most of them not good at all.  I was pleasantly surprised by this one.  I have not read the book, so this review is based solely on what I watched at the cinema.What starts off as any normal morning becomes anything but in a very short while.  Brad Bitt, with wife and two daughters in tow, begin some sort of holiday, but a monkeywrench is thrown into their plans almost immediately because of an outbreak of some sort of virus that is turning people into crazed maniacal zombies.  There is no known "Patient Zero," no idea where the virus originated, and certainly no cure.  Pitt's character used to work for the UN in some sort of capacity, and he and his family are saved and taken out to sea for protection.  Pitt is asked to head up a team and search for the origin (and cure) of this disease.  Along the way, there are stops in South Korea, Israel, and Belarus.  Pitt's character comes up with an idea that might just save the world--or at least give it a little time longer to work on an antidote.  I won't give anything else away, but I will say this was one zombie movie that at least I could buy the premise.The acting is this movie fared much better than its script.  The plausibility of Israel seeming able to defend itself against the zombie attack long before anyone else and then not knowing to put the kybosh on their "hoedown" was just a little unbelievable.  And I left the movie wanting more--much more.  Coming in at just under two hours, you would have thought the story would have all been there, but the movie seemed to end just as it was starting to take off.  I'm sure most of you wanted more blood and guts (there is very little of this, by the way), but I was okay with the story taking precedent over the effects.World War Z is rated PG-13 for language and violence, and believe it or not, there's not that much violence.  I recommend viewing the movie, but I just wished it would have been a little better.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Ill admit, I cheated. I watched the movie before I read the book and that can have a huge impact on whether you like it or not. The two have little to nothing in common, and that can be a good thing and a bad thing but why cant both be good? They both are good. I do believe they need to make a movie from the book but it may have to be too intelligent for the average summer teenager crowd (the book is too sophisticated and intelligent for the Kardashian-honeyboo crowd). However, the movie isn't too shabby either for just a suspense-filled, exciting, well-acted popcorn pleaser. If you go in thinking its gonna be like the book, you'll prob. hate it, but if you see it as a separate entity, then its a rather tense, thrilling fun little gem of a movie. Never been a Pitt fan, but gotta admit, he does the leading man-hero thing quite admirably here. A Timberlake or Tatum wouldn't have worked, but Pitt makes a believable and resourceful hero and does it well. And gotta admit, The tough as nails Israeli soldier is prob. my favorite character in the movie, other than Pitt. Something about a tough, without trying to be, badass woman is extremely attractive and the Israeli actress is perfect for the role. Other than "The Conjuring", WWZ was the only movie I spent money on this past summer, and it was a delightful choice.
summary: Movie and book are different, love them both

reviewText: Strip away the title and any associations with the source material and this is a mildly above-average action/horror hybrid. It's nailed the gritty, vivid tone I expect of a dawning modern zombie apocalypse - the panic, confusion and outright helplessness of civilian life at ground zero - but does gradually get carried away in terms of scope. Brad Pitt as not just humanity's last great scientific hope, but also its vigilant watchdog and bombastic action hero, is something of a reach and smells like several characters were mashed together for the sake of simplicity. In a few instances, World War Z tests the waters of political and social reactions, enduring themes of the novel, but these are contrived token efforts at best and certainly not the film's forte. It's generally content to simply flush the screen with crumbling cityscapes and spitting, sprinting, screaming infected hordes, both of which perform quite well. At moments it's intense, shocking and borderline iconic, but storyline depth is an Achilles' heel, and most of the third act plays out like a bland, predictable obligation.
summary: A Competent, if Mostly Forgettable, Zombie-Squasher
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I missed out on that whole era of Brad Pitt Americana - you know, Brad Pitt fishing, Brad Pitt aging in reverse, blah blah, it's sort of this vague shadow of him taking over for Robert Redford minus the essential Sydney Pollack.The zombies were okay but not as exciting and shocking as The Walking Dead and the timing of WWZ's release fills the gap between a very good Season 3 and the yet to premiere Season 4.  And on its own, this is a filler movie that acts as a prequel, kind of the boring Pilot episode that prepares for the far more awesome ACTUAL war described in the better bookWorld War Z An Oral History of the Zombie War by Brooks, Max [Three Rivers Press,2007] [Paperback].I won't be purchasing this film.  I couldn't even watch it a second time when I rented it on cable so I'm glad I didn't pay to see it on the big screen.
summary: surprisingly a little empty - not too soulful despite echoing WW2, Band of Brothers type of nobility and wherewithal
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This movie had lots of action and lots of zombies, so those who are really into that kind of thing might be willing to overlook some of the holes in the plotline. Brad Pitt, of course, was probably meant to be the draw for this movie, and it was really good in the beginning when everything so unexpectedly started happening. Lots of action and scenes of Pitt trying to keep himself and his family safe. But once he was sent on his special mission, too many things started falling apart in the plot and it became difficult to keep up with, what the heck was he supposed to be doing anyway?But I guess, if one is an action movie lover, and you are willing to not care about the seemingly holes in the plots, one might enjoy just sitting back and watch this thing.
summary: Good if you like anything Brad Pitt is in

reviewText: Big dissapointment for a summer "blockbuster". The film starts off smartly and keeps you at the edge of your seat in the beginning when the plague first hits philly and Pitt and family get their first encounter with the zombies. Once on the run they get lucky until Pitts old boss sends a helicopter to pick them up and deliver them to an aircraft carrier on the eastern coast. From there the story gets more and more unbelievable as our hero jaunts across the world trying to find the origin of the disease and survives everything from multiple attacks to a plane crash. South Korea, Jerusalem, Wales. Our UN inspector is made of steel and figures out how to defeat the zombies. By infecting humanity with H1N1 meningitis!! Because the zombies wont eat an icky diseased person. Really?? Have not read the book, was hoping for a good zombie film and recieved instead a huge dissapointment. Wait until the rental and you will be thankful not wasting your money for this at the cinema.
summary: World War Z- for Z rated.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I am not a professional nor a 'semi-professional' movie reviewer. (As some I've read here on Amazon) I simply watch & will tell home viewers what I liked & disliked. "World War Z" (Unrated Version) is a movie I REALLY liked! I had to watch it twice, due to my missing a fact early on in a scene. I thought there was a HUGE error in the movie! LoL! I knew there just could NOT be such, and the movie was so good, so thrilling, so exciting, such down right fun; I fought, 'Why not watch it a second time and see what I missed?" I found it of course, and a few other things for that matter!This movie starts out with a bang, a REAL bang, gets your adrenalin going from the very start. My heart was beating very fast & I was sitting up straight in my chair within the first five minutes! After that it never truly lets up on that constant feeling of a thrilling apocalyptic scare ride! There is a 'Real Story' that coexists with the end-of-the world plot also, no worries there; so this isn't a simple one dimensional story. (Brat Pitt, father, hubby, save the world, blah…blah…blah…No! It is a GOOD Story!)The thing that hit me most about this movie was that the idea, the  plot-actually COULD happen! And that scares the living daylights outa me! There are new and unknown viral and bacterial breakouts found around our globe every day/week/month. Check online @ the CDC/NIH! LoL! (No! I am NOT a conspiracy theorist! HA! No worries there! Neither am I one of those 'Survivor' type people-although I know a few!) I am however a Medical Researcher…. This movie IS close enough to reality to be just a tad….. scary! Enjoy it…. (While you can…! Whoo--Whee!)
Title: World War Z

reviewText: What I didn't like about this movie is how it gives no explanation as to how the zombie infection begins.  It just jumps into the lives of a family who's lives are normal one day and then turned totally around the next by people who are becoming zombies out of thin air.  If this was supposed to be a scary movie - it wasn't.  Sure it had some good action scenes but I probably should have read the book first.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Although action packed, this offering is not all that everyone is saying it is. Essentially what it is, is a pandemic movie that takes away all the human elements of the zombie horror genre into such an unlikely scenario and taken away the humanity, the gore or any likely "scaryness" from the movie at all. It's like Pearl Harbor, or Armageddon with none of the scares. It is so far away from the realm of zombie survival horror, it's not even funny. While entertaining I was in no way impressed with the superhuman abilities of the computer generated zombies? There is no evidence as to if they are alive or dead and they also have the ability to detect weather of not you have a terminal illness! Laughable. I have been watching this genre since it's invention and World War Z is no pinnacle to it. It's more like a footnote. Why is no one noticing this?
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I am a fan of zombie and rage virus movies. I read the book, though it has been over five years. The pacing of this movie was slow and there was not enough suspense to keep the viewer engaged. I did not have high expectations after seeing the trailer for the movie, it seemed like it would be another horrible adaptation of a good book. I would like to split this review into two parts, positives (or things that did not seem bad or stupid) and cons (things that did not make sense).Pros1) Protagonist is a former member of the UN armed forces. Yes the UN does not have teeth and is not a well respected military force. However they do have a military force, it is made up of volunteers from the military of member countries. So no I do not think it stupid that the protagonist was a former member of the UN. He was most likely in the US military and then volunteered. He also was likely in vary dangerous combat areas along side US military, he had to have been trained in combat,2) It is not strange to look for patient zero, and to look for a cure. It was identified as a virus of some sort so trying to find its origins makes sense.3) The scene in Israel, I thought was done well and was the closets thing to the book that I can remember. No the zombies did not get smarter. They were dormant. There was not enough noise next to the wall to get them to think there were none-contaminated people on the other side. When the girl started singing and the other people started to join in. All the zombies awakened and rushed. They got lucky in that a good number rushed one area piled on to each other and were able to climb over the wall.4) Him and the Israeli soldier survived the plane crash. He was horribly injured which would likely happen.5) Using H1N1 to as camouflage  was pretty neat. Considering the closets things to zombies we have so far is a fungus that infects certain ants controls them so that it can spread but it tries to only spread to health hosts.5) The kids, acted realistically, one was scared to the point of silence the other to annoying cries. The hispanic kid  was important in that it showed Brad Pitts character wanting to help those who helped him. That kids was either very lucky or terminally ill.Cons.1) That the doctor brought to South Korea died so early on.2) The change from Russia is a black hole to India is a black hole was annoying.3) The length of time it took for the back of the plane to become infected and break out into chaos. The virus takes seconds to show signs and 10-12 seconds to complete the transformation. Unless for some reason the dog was the carrier it would have been known within seconds that one of the passengers was infected.  Not the hours it would take to go from Israel to Cardiff.4) The teeth thing the zombies do.5) I understand making one look terminally ill, but it would be hard to travel long distance while sick with H1N1 , unless they found a way to make your body show signs of being terminally ill without actually being terminally ill.6) Why did ingestion of the zombie blood not infect Brad Pitts character?7) Pacing was bad, not enough character development, not enough suspense.  Action scenes okay but could have been done better.
summary: Boring and met my low expectations. There will be spoilers
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I've never read the book this movie is supposedly based on and after watching it, I really don't feel the need to do so.This movie had me in a quandary from the moment I heard about it.  I love Zombie movies but I am not a fan of Brad Pitt.  Unfortunately, he is the star and there is no getting around that.  Fortunately, he is quickly swallowed up by the frantic action and really doesn't provide much of an impact as an actor.  Anyone could have played his part and with the very same results.  Pitt's character is a standard hero doing the standard things that heroes do in action flicks.  There were absolutely no surprises in that regard.  The plot is embarrassingly simple following a set of stock circumstances used many times in many films.  The real star in this movie is the special effects/zombies.  And they do not disappoint.  The rest is hack work, but even knowing that I still liked this movie.  It's thoroughly enjoyable.  I'm glad I bought it (Pitt notwithstanding).

I appreciate the fresh take on the worlds response to the invasion, including the piece about the city that escaped infection by undergoing the largest social exercise every conducted - in a 24 hour period officials orchestrated the removal of every citizen's teeth!Check it out!  I loved it, my wife loved it, you'll love it.

reviewText: If you need to waste a good number of minutes out of your life, this movie is for you. Apparently Brad needed to get away from the wide and kids so he took this project on as a sort of vacation. It's just too bad it doesn't really deliver anything except Zombies. It starts right out with Zombies, created by some strange but really undefined whatever. Minutes after this movie starts you hit with death, destruction, mayhem.... It continues all through the movie....and did I forget.....Zombies ?!?!?!? They flow like water all through this movie. The only part that may take your concern is when Brad has a brush with a Zombie.... We'll you're waiting for him to turn or whatever. The ending....Well if you made it this far then maybe you should watch it to find out for yourself. This was an overdone, poor storyline, no story, action, shoot Zombies and that's about it. The overall development looks like something a High School CInema class could put together and frankly I believe they could do a better job. Really, take a drive, go out to dinner, or take a walk in the park as it would be a better way to spend the minutes your going to waste on viewing this ZOMBIE movie.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: The stunning visual effects alone is worth watching this movie, which happened to be the first movie I watched on my new Amazon Fire TV (smooth...very smooth streaming).  But the plot has issues and a bit insensitive.Right off the bat the New York City traffic is thrown into chaos by humans turning into zombies, who stampede towards any stimulation they hear or see. That would be everywhere in the City. Hoards of zombies rushing like it's the day after Thanksgiving at Midtown Manhattan Macy's and no one is caring about the sick or homeless along the way; perhaps an apt metaphor to current state of consumerism. The protagonist, played by Brad Pitt, whose sole job is to protect a neurologist from Harvard, fails to protect the latter from killing himself two seconds into the movie. It's up to Pitt to save the day. Most of the World seems to be taken over by the growing number of zombies, except in one country that has the strictest entry through its walls and double--triple--visa check points: Israel. This is where the insensitivity comes. Outside the wall that Israel has put up to keep the Palestinians out is an enormous swarm of zombies that looks like an ant-colony trying to scale the wall. So, are these zombies supposed to be Palestinians? Very insensitive (see the movieOmar (Subtitled)for a more intelligent critique of the shameful wall.)  What's more Pitt really doesn't do much in Israel, except fly in a Belarus commercial airplane. As if it wasn't enough failing to prevent the neurologist from putting a hole in his head, Pitt blows up a hole in the plane turning the jet's engine into a meat grinder and his luscious blond hair tosses and swerves in its full glory amidst decompression. Would I be giving away the ending if I said Pitt saves the day?Minus the many silliness in the plot, it is taut and fun to watch, and mercifully short under two hours.
summary: might make a good shampoo commercial

Title: World War Z

reviewText: In his novel, World War Z, author Max Brooks, created a telling of a zombie infested, post-apocalyptic world. Rather than a traditional narrative, Brooks told his tale as a collection of individual recollections of the ten-year war against zombies. When the film adaptation of the bestselling book was announced, I was excited to see the book brought to life, but wondered if such an adaptation was even possible. How could the filmmakers adapt a book with so many characters and such a large scope.The answer . . . they don't. Rather than attempt to chorale Brooks's writing into the constraints of a film, the filmmakers use little more than the title and the idea of a zombie apocalypse in this "adaptation". With Brad Pitt playing a former UN employee who is called to jump back into his old lifestyle for the sake of his family, the filmmakers wisely choose to focus on a central character and his struggle to survive. I guess when you have Brad Pitt starring in your movie, you better use him!The film opens as Pitt, accompanied by his wife(Mireille Enos), prepares to drive his daughters to school. On this drive, the family witnesses the zombie outbreak firsthand, narrowly escaping the danger of the streets. Desperate to safeguard his family from the attacks, he calls upon his old friend at the United Nations, and agrees to help search for the origin of the outbreak in exchange for his family's asylum. They are then flown to an ocean based command center, where Pitt learns of the apparent virus that causes people to turn to zombies. As the film progresses, we follow Pitt as he visits numerous places around the world, each affected by the outbreak.World War Z is directed by Marc Forester (Finding Neverland, Quantum of Solace), who brings a fast pace and edgy tone to the story. It is very difficult to make a zombie seem threatening. Indeed, there were moments in this film where the zombies are almost laughable. But the filmmakers, deftly find a way around that. By allowing the actors to play their characters straight and develop genuine emotional stakes, the threat of zombies becomes more urgent and threatening.Before its release, World War Z was mired in production setbacks that included a massive rewrite and reshoot of it's third act. The result is an ending that foregoes the normal summer blockbuster conclusion of intense action and special effects. Rather, the film ends with a intimate, suspense laden scene that intelligently concludes the movie, while artfully and organically leaving the possibility for a sequel. Despite a complete departure from the source material, World War Z manages to remain smart, intriguing, and most importantly, entertaining.
summary: An Intelligent and Unique Zombie Film
Title: World War Z

reviewText: After watching World War Z, I tried to understand why so many people panned it. I couldn't see it. The production is first rate. There are many great tense and scary scenes. The cast is very good. The story is epic and given a proper landscape with some truly dazzling and memorable moments.My only criticism of this film is that it ended somewhat abruptly. Thus the half star taken off.But maybe this is a zombie film for people who usually don't like zombie films. I don't. I liked one zombie film before this one and that was Zombieland. And while that was a more tongue firmly planted in cheek type of film, this one is serious and very realistic.In a year filled with surprising films that I did not expect to like, this one is the newest addition to that list.Richard Roeper said it best. This film is entertaining as hell.

reviewerName: Fabulinus "To err is human. To forgive for no...
reviewText: I would never have had much interest in this movie if it had not been for the barrage of good, professional reviews when it first hit theaters.  I’m not one to always go on the advice of a movie critic because obviously personal taste as well as going to see a movie simply because a particular actor/actress is in it can (*sometimes – lol) trump whether or not the movie is actually “good”.  World War Z was very good.Though unrealistic (then again, what zombie movie is realistic) the storyline was solid, the acting was good and the movie wasn’t super gory… many zombie flicks rely on gore to get people’s attention instead of good acting and a satisfying narrative.  Brad Pitt is just an OK actor in my opinion.  He pretty much stands in the movie the whole time being “Brad Pitt”, but it worked – lol.  I also found World War Z sensibly suspenseful, which I like and appreciate.  The story didn’t have gory zombie-like creatures jumping out at you from around every corner.This movie is definitely worth renting and the solution to the movie’s “dilemma” is unique (lol).  I enjoyed it immensely.
summary: I don’t like “Zombie” flicks… I liked this one.

reviewText: I am the first to admit that I LOVE inspirational, feel good, happy endings! World War Z is none of these! However, even though I am not the gaga usual type over Brad Pitt...the man can act. I think this was well written, well executed and somehow seems feasible. There are some, did that really just happen moments. Some Wow, that makes sense moments and one, really?? moment. But, overall I am glad I saw it and really quite satisfied with the story. Like I said, this is not a GI Joe action flick, it is more of a thinker action flick. It goes fast, starts immediately, which ads to the intensity. It does not slow down for you to have that sensitive moment....there is no time, THESE ARE ZOMBIES MAN!!!!

Title: World War Z

reviewText: There is virtually no plot in this kinetic exercise, which finds Brad Pitt running from zombies world-wide as he investigates the outbreak of what appears to be a virus that causes people to become the undead. A former lead investigator for the U.N. (there's a confidence builder), Pitt is blackmailed into his globetrotting sleuthing by the U.S. Navy, which more or less tells him his family will be turned over to the zombies if he does not cooperate. Who or what Pitt actually is is never really made clear (he is not a doctor, so why is he the man for the job?), which makes the actions of everyone else in the movie so puzzling. People who've just met him sacrifice their lives to save him or give up their seats on aircraft, because he is from the U.N., just like the real world (not). Somehow everyone instantly knows that this is the-one-man-who-can-save-us, yet his own actions undercut this vision. I mean, if you are escaping riots and civil unrest in Philadelphia, would a sane person make their destination Newark, NJ? Physics don't seem to matter. A giant cargo plane is instantly refueled from a single fuel truck and able to fly from Korea to Israel, despite having landed "on fumes". A battered airliner leaves Israel in a hurry and manages to make it to Wales before anyone realizes there are zombies on board. Pitt and his Israeli companion both instantly recover from massive wounds that would fell a rhinoceros, and are the sole survivors of a catastrophic plane crash.The zombie attacks are pretty routine, except for the long shots, but these are so cartoonish as to be laughable. The film is one long chase scene until the end, when everything slows down and it sort of just stutters to a halt. The outbreak? Never solved. The war? Nope, left the door wide open for a possible sequel. From the opening credits, it appears the original cut of this movie had a political message about global warming, but they cut it out, leaving virtually nothing else but running and shooting.
Title: World War Z
