reviewText: WORLD WAR ZI will admit that I was not really into seeing this flick when it was first announced. I like so many others who have read the book let that get in the way before even viewing it. Yes I know, that is not the way to go about things, but come on. There were so many problems with the filming of this movie so I thought I would wait. So when I eventually gave in and went to see this I was pleasantly surprised.Gerry Lane [Pitt] is a U.N. investigator who ends up having a pretty bad time. It turns out that he is right in the middle of a worldwide zombie outbreak. It also turns out that he is the guy that has to help find a way to stop this outbreak. In exchange his family will be kept safe but it is a race against time, so in order to save his family he has to save the world. It is just another day in the life of Brad Pitt err I mean Gerry Lane.I will go ahead admit that I was wrong about this film, sure it is not really like the book and left out some of my absolute favorite things but that is ok. I hear that a second one is being made now so hopefully some of the setting that were not used will find their way into that one. I did enjoy what this movie did use and even how something’s were changed. Now of course I am sure most people would say that Israel was probably the best scene from the film. I can see how some would think that but I really loved the when they were attacked trying to get back to the plane on his first trip. Not the plane in Israel but when he was with the soldiers in South Korea. That entire time there is easily the creepiest portion of the film, so it is easily my favorite.Now I have not really been a huge fan of the running zombies, sometimes it is great like the first “Return of the Living Dead” but other times I am just not into it as much. Here I get that they were going for the chaotic experience so it makes sense to do that but I feel like it could have been more suspenseful with the slow plodding ones. Still it did make for some entertaining moments and over all I think it worked. Director Marc Forster did a good job with this film as did the writers as they created the highest grossing zombie film ever if I am not mistaken.Now on to Brad Pitt who in all honesty did a good job here as well, in fact he did a great job. With that said even with a great performance nothing about his character stands out. I have read other reviews that have said the same thing so I know I am not alone but I think that is what makes it work. An actor like Pit usually steals the show with that not happening here you are more into the story. I don’t know it could just be me but I think it works. Everyone else is just as god as Pitt but the story is the real standout character here.You get some behind the scenes stuff as bonus features but I would have loved a commentary to hear all about the troubles of the shoot or even the “Battle of Moscow” stuff that was left out. Still this ended up being a very entertaining film. The unrated cut adds extra scenes and little more gore but not enough to make it any less watchable for the younger viewers.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Clearly, the zombie pandemic is alive and well in the world of entertainment.  These creatures aren't just a new sensation, they've be relevant in film for quite some time now and depending on whom you ask, zombies originated in film at least as far back as the 1930s.  Regardless, zombie films have come a long way and evolved into a genre all its own, typically bordering on horror - but without a main protagonist to specifically lead the mayhem (unless you'd like to make a claim for George A. Romero).  With the recent success of the highly popular AMC drama, The Walking Dead, and the Resident Evil franchise, not to mention comedies like Warm Bodies and Zombieland - it would appear the undead are preparing to continue their reign of terror for quite some time.  And, you know zombies flicks are at the height of their popularity when Brad Pitt decides to sign on for a leading role.Based on the novel of the same name by Max Brooks and directed by Marc Foster (Monster's Ball, Quantum of Solace), World War Z stars Brad Pitt as Gerry Lane, a former United Nations investigator called back to action to investigate the origin of a "zombie" academic.  Originally reluctant to take the assignment, Gerry decides it's in the best interest to (reluctantly) leave his family and attempt to find a cure.  However, finding an origin or a cure becomes difficult when every major city in the world becomes devastated by zombie outbreaks - leaving Gerry with little options other than to keep moving from city to city.  Mireille Enos, Ludi Boeken, James Badge, and Fana Mokoena also star in supporting roles.The film wastes little time, quickly turning to chaos on the streets of Philadelphia.  To be honest, the first half hour of the film feels like early episodes of The Walking Dead as we follow Gerry Lane, his wife, and their children, as they run from zombies on the street, through a building, and eventually face-off with them on a rooftop.  Essentially, that is what goes down in the first few episodes of The Walking Dead.  But, this isn't a Walking Dead comparison, and the fact that World War Z resembles a massively popular TV show is definitely not a bad way to start a film.  Zombie films should start off small, in a secluded area and then balloon from there - as the film does.World War Z might just be the grandest (in terms of visual scale) zombie film ever made, with all major cities falling to an unknown disease that kills people and quickly reanimates them in death as flesh eaters.  Most zombie films don't take the time to provide a grand scale look at major cities, often simply focusing on one specific city and a small group of people trying to survive within it or at least escape from it.  This film takes Brad Pitt's character from one end of the earth to the other, beginning in Philadelphia and moving to South Korea, Jerusalem, and finally a health lab in Wales.  There's no shortage of travel, nor are there many scenes without a zombie trolling around.You may have noticed from the synopsis or various advertisements that there is zero star power other than Brad Pitt.  This is - from beginning to end - a film dominated by Brad Pitt.  As he moves from one location to the other over the course of the film, he usually loses his supporting cast along the way (which shouldn't be too surprising).  Pitt portrays an observant character focused on the goal of finding answers, basically because he is blackmailed into it as a means to protect his family.  However, it is rather far-fetched to see the lengths army officers and other nations go to in order to protect him.  Evidently, Pitt's character really does mean a great deal to the survival of the human race - but that portion of the film is hardly understandable.  Far too many people lose their lives at the expense of allowing Pitt to move from one part of the globe to the other.  And, his character always manages to squeak his way out of danger.If you didn't follow the film's production news (and most people don't), World War Z had quite a bit of footage needed after the completion of filming to fully explain the ending.  Even though the ending is relatively simple and climatically uneventful, it would have been much, much worse without the added footage (basically the final 45 minutes) to fully explain the film's ending.  Sadly (mainly due to the lack of bloodshed), the film simply goes through motions of coming to its simple conclusion.  There are virtually no scenes where you're on the edge of your seat and frankly, the film's final stanza lacks the appropriate amount of drama for a zombie flick.  For once, people actually act sensible when dealing with a group of zombies - which is admirable, yet still pretty boring.As far as zombie movies go, World War Z isn't the best and it isn't the worst.  Still, the positives greatly outweigh the negatives.  The film is so full of action that it almost doesn't feel like a full-blown zombie flick.  It's not you traditional film about people hiding out and spending a film looking for salvation.  This film is about one man's goal to protect his family by investigating a global crisis - which just happens to be zombies.  Overall, Brad Pitt does an admiral job fighting off the well-designed villains - all while indicating he might even be back for some sequels sooner than later.The bottom line:  if you're a Brad Pitt lover, this might be an iffy choice.  It will depend on your devotion to him and whether or not you can handle a borderline horror flick.  However, if you're a lover of The Walking Dead or simply enjoy action-packed zombie movies (minus things constantly popping out at you in typical horror movie fashion) - this film is for you.  You certainly won't walk out of this film disappointed.  In fact, you'll walk out looking forward to a promising sequel.Grade:  C+FNDNreview.com
summary: Brad Pitt (really?) takes on zombies in 'World War Z'
Title: World War Z

reviewerName: Frank Scoblete author of Confessions of a Way...
reviewText: I hate fast zombies. Dead muscles shouldn't be able to move quickly. With that said, "World War Z" is one terrific movie. The zombies are more like a raging body of red ants, swarming over everything. This is an epic tale.The film works on many levels. The zombie attack is vicious and fast with landscapes full of the crazed creatures. The world is overwhelmed in a day or two. The sequences of attacks are overwhelming. Into this mix is the personal story of our hero Gerry Lane, played perfectly by Brad Pitt, and his family. Can Gerry figure out how to defeat the disease? Or is mankind doomed?I put this one right up there with the top five zombie movies of all time: Shaun of the Dead, Dawn of the Dead (both versions), Night of the Living Dead (both versions.By the way, I also loved the book but this movie is not the book. Doesn't matter, it stands proudly on its own.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Bradd Pitt just turned 50. Bummer. And it seems to show in this move--the pep and zing you've come to expect from him is sadly missing. The story however, had some great turns and it will keep you on the edge of your seat. There's drama aplenty. I have heard that it doesn't adhere to the book of the same title, but until I read it I can't tell if they've done a better job of telling this gripping story; I suppose I'll revisit the issue at that time.Even with his lackluster performance, Pitt continues to show why he's a movie star. Every one else put in a good effort, you definitely get sucked in and for that, four stars.
summary: Pitt's star is fading, but not quite yet ...

reviewText: This is simply Walking Dead on steroids. Higher intensity and higher speed, it really is an "A works, so let's make B just like it" Hollywood cliche. The characters are pretty flat, there is no time for development because there's too much action. The wife and kids are rather dull and don't inspire much sympathy because their whineyness keeps endangering people. There is a little hispanic boy they save and tow around, but we know nothing about him. The energies of this film are scattered thin.

reviewText: Even Brad Pitt couldn't save this noisy, incoherent, no-story bomb. To criticize this thing's "script" gives the word script a very bad name. Hint: There is no script! Title: World War Z

reviewText: I really did not expect much of this film last summer, not being much of a Brad Pitt fan or of director Marc Foster, the man who directed one of my 5 least-favorite Bond films: Quantum of Solace.  Furthermore, like many, I had heard the stories of a confused script and a new ending forced to be filmed.  However, upon seeing the film, I found it to be a gripping and intense experience.  I watched the blu-ray unrated version yesterday and my opinion hasn't changed.This is an epic film of a world catastrophe going from Philadelphia, (actually Scotland) to North Korea to Israel (actually Malta) and a tense conclusion in Wales.  Like so many of the films of today, this film would not have been possible without CGI, particularly the scene of thousands of zombies climbing over each other to get over an enormous wall protecting Jerusalem. (Probably the type of wall we could use along our porous southern border.)Unlike The Walking Dead, where the world suffers a similar disaster, these zombies do not shamble along, they run and run fast.  And they bite, thats the way the zombie virus is spread. Pitt is surprisingly good (and he should be since he is one of the film's producers.)  I also like Mirielle Enos as his wife.  I've enjoyed her on the AMC series The Killing, and since she is always so grim and depressed on that series, it is nice to see her play a normal role and actually smile here (although, to be frank, the events of this film do not really give one much to smile about.)As stated, this is an unrated cut.  There were some scenes that did not seem too familiar to me although I have to admit that I don't remember what they were.  The picture and sound on the blu-ray were fine.  The special features consisted of several relatively short documentaries on the making of the film. (This is not a Peter Jackson film with 10 hours of special features.)  The "making of" documentaries were fine and just about everyone was interviewed with the exception of Pitt.  (I guess he was too busy.)In conclusion, this is a very exciting, fairly violent and bloody epic  that keeps the suspense and your interest up throughout.  As stated, I did not expect all that much of it, but it turned out to be one of my favorite films of last summer (right behind Star Trek and Man of Steel.)  Check it out, you won't be bored.
summary: Far Better than I Expected It to Be.

reviewText: My first recommendation is: don't watch this on an airplane!  I loaded it up on my Kindle Fire HD and watched it on a recent trip - and found myself contorting into funny positions so that other passengers wouldn't be subjected to the mayhem on my screen!  I also just about jumped out of my skin when the airplane hit some turbulence in an intense moment!All-in-all, this was a great zombie flick.  I'm not a particularly big fan of movies in that category, but I found that the plot, effects and acting in this one kept my attention throughout.  I can also report that it was recommended to me by my college age daughter who is also not a particularly big fan of zombie movies - and she very much enjoyed it.It is not grotesque (or not as graphic anyway) as many movies of this type are.  Nor does it have as many of the deeply suspenseful moments.  You can think of it as living up to its title - it is plays more like a war movie than it does like a horror movie.Probably a good movie for anyone who likes suspenseful shoot-em-up type movies.
summary: Very Good: Move of a War Movie than a Horror Movie

reviewText: (spoilers) I went to see this film mistakenly believing that it had a plot! A rabies-like pandemic spreads, in which the infected seek to bite healthy people, spreading the contagion. A basic rip-off of '28 Days Later' the film has an underlying theme, I believe. This is a 'desensitization' film, in which the audience gets so used to seeing humans shot, burned and beaten that it pushes audience members to want to kill. These films are put out to push people into wanting war and killing, as the entire aspect of the screenplay has to do with military interaction in killing. I suggest NO ONE go see this film, as it has no redeeming value whatsoever!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Bottom line----great adaptation on the Zombie idea.  It's one of the better plausible "this looks like it could really happen" feel (not that anyone would want that!) without the film being a horror genre B movie fail, or low budget, poor quality production.  This movie is going to give "preppers" another reason to stockpile canned soup and bottled water.No spoilers here....I'm an armchair movie director/critic  just like a lot of other people out there.  Movies are not just entertainment to me.  They are a source of inspiration for my own original writing in the horror genre.  I like the quality of a good storyline over the shock value of blood-n-guts anyday.  This movie delivers just that.I think the success of this movie is due to Brad Pitt.  Don't get me wrong....I'm neither a fan or critic of him, but let's face it----he's an extremely popular actor.  With that comes a big budget for the movie, and it shows every step of the way.  There's not a lot of other noticable faces in the film; no A list co-stars opposite of Brad Pitt.  The film literally latches onto his shoulders and he carries it every step of the way.  This is not a bad thing, mind you, in my opinion.  Actually, I feel he has been much more dynamic in other character portrayals, but he delivers nonetheless in this movie.  That being said, the supporting cast is spectacular.I'm one to believe it all starts with the director.  Also delivering in this film with equal credentials is director Marc Foster (Monster's Ball, Finding Neverland, Quantum of Solace, Kite Runner).  There's a great story being told here through his vision.  The movie may be about another zombie apocalypse, but make no misunderstanding: this is a fantastic dramatic approach that really brings a fresh new idea to an otherwise been there-done that movie monster.The film has a great look; the cinematography captures a feel and vibe that is most convincing.  It really sells the idea, or at least to me it does.  High action scenes are brought to you from a human element perspective and not just a bunch of big gratuitous bangs.  There's a couple of spots where the film made me question the reality delivery, but nothing that brought the experience to a halt.I want to be more specific about the film, but it would certainly spoil your viewing.  If you like zombie movies, this is one to keep in your collection right next the classic Romero film, Night Of The Living Dead.  They're nothing alike except for the common thread of zombies.  But, World War Z is very similar to the Romero film in that is gives a groundbreaking idea of a new direction to go in with a movie monster.I WISH I could have come up with the idea!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I admit I only watched this because Brad Pitt was in it. Somehow I thought this fact would make the movie more intelligent or interesting. But it didn't really happen. Like most movies of this sort, you become anesthetized to the killing and violence to the point that it doesn't even matter anymore. The emotional connection is gone, and you just have to wait around for the wrap up. This movie has some good tense scenes, like the chase scene in the lab, where it tries to build some tension, but that can only happen when you feel some empathy for the characters about to get annihilated. Remember "Aliens?" I wish every director who wants to make a zombie/alien/superhero movie would watch that one and see how it's done.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Apparently it is a good thing that I didn;t read the book before seeing the movie as many people felt cheated by this movie adaptation of the book. Before the movie was released I had heard rumors that there was trouble with the final product, that Mr Pitt was not pleased with the way things turned out & had gone in to make some changes. True or not, you can see the problems in this movie pretty easily -- plot issues that just make no sense more than anything else.His wife impulse calls him while he juuust happens to be in the middle of trying to be QUIET while getting back to his plane in Korea which results in many good guys dying-- Brad knows the Zombies are attracted by noise but he takes his sweet time telling the Israelis about it! OK maybe he was jet lagged. Too many such contrived/silly moments. I am not a watcher of Zombie stuff so the implausibilty of fast moving Z's didn;t bother me at all. In fact I thought it was about time someone came up with some speedier undead. It made theattacks visceral & pretty damn horrific. Bad stuff tends to happen quickly even if the buildup to it is slow. I actually felt that the movie itself took off too fast.........one family scene then BAM Philly goes to heck in a hand basket in 5 minutes. Have your popcorn ready before you click Play. Yeah maybe Brad turns out to be the luckiest guy on Earth -- pretty much everyone dies around him--but his acting isn;t overly macho & he IS used to being in touch'n Go situations so I didn;t have a hard time believing that he could be so cool under pressure. And I thought the story-line of him & the Israeli woman soldier was done very nicely. It's tough to be noticed as a supporting actor in a movie like this but I thought the soldier in Korea, the UN contact, the UN plane's pilot, the WHO Lab workers & many others all did fine jobs. Even with all of its flaws this movie was worth the $3.99 rental fee & we watched it 3 times in 48 hours & each time it got a bit better & a bit clearer. The Zombbie pile up at the wall was both silly and impressive. But the best scene is at the end when things slow down enough to allow for human interaction & a slower build-up to tension. The sad creepy jaw-snapping Zombies make the human moments even more gripping. The ending was kinda obviously "tacked on" but by that point you really do not need or want any more "action"! You want to be talked down by Brad & allowed to settle a bit. So really I'd rate this 3.5 stars with the warning that I am not a Zombie connoiser, did not read the book & didn;t set the bar too high to begin with & thus wasn't overly disappointed with this movie.

reviewText: The movie was OK but it did not make the grade of "I will look at it a second time."  This will not become an Action Thriller or Science Fiction Thriller.  Some hint at what drove the infected people to attack or suspense.  Once infected there were not indications that the infected dined on anything other than fresh not infected people.  Yet they appeared to just stand aro0und waiting with no eating and worst of all no indication of water consumption.  So how did the infected survive without water?  There was no indication that a cure to aid the infected was in the works.  The only thing that helped was to infect those not infected with some other bad but controllable disease.  Mr. Pitt and the cast did a good job of acting but the details were simply to vague or not there at all.

reviewText: The production values make this a film worth seeing. If you are into a class tale of apocalyptic zombism, then WORLD WAR Z will entertain. The reality based narrative style of WORLD WAR Z impressed me. The acting also, is top notch. Brad Pitt is very convincing and very engaging in his role.  His screen presence alone is a big factor why this film works. Along with the excellent production values and director Marc Forster's very artistic eye for storytelling (QUANTUM OF SOLACE, MONSTER'S BALL, FINDING NEVERLAND) this film is rather exceptional.
summary: Tale of Apocalyptic Zombism Exceptionally Told
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Love these types of movies.  Well written, plausible, and very interesting from start to finish.Brad Pitt gives a very good performance..
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Ok, first of all, I have a zombie phobia.  I quit watching all zombie media about 5 years ago, because I would have really bad dreams about zombies afterward.  My daughter told me that this might be one I could actually watch without being bothered, and BOY, was she right!  Paid 99 cents to rent this, so I'm not upset.MINOR spoilers ahead.  I am really shocked that so many people liked this movie - especially all those saying this was "fun."  There was nothing "fun" about this.  It alternated between boring and ludicrous, with nothing much else in between.  I gave it 2 stars because it's not the worst thing I've ever seen.  Brad Pitt wasn't terrible, but he seemed tired and lacked any believable intensity in the situation he was in.  I still don't have any idea who he really was or why he was needed on the "mission" to...what?  Find out where the zombie disease came from, I think.  And I know he worked for the UN, but again, no idea why they needed him in particular.The story in general was pretty ridiculous.  I mean, I'm sure you have to suspend disbelief in general to believe in zombies at all, but nothing here was believable or logical.  The worst part was that Jerry sees two - literally TWO - people who the zombies don't attack and then figures out how to save the day.  And when he tests out his theory - OMFG.  I'd love to spoil the ending for you, but I won't.  But it's just absolute utter nonsense.  He does something absurd and 2 minutes later...boom.  Day saved.  Ridiculous, if you know anything about science at all.If you're bored and have nothing better to do and this is still a cheap rental, sure watch it.  And maybe you'll be like one of the folks here who thought this was the best thing ever created.  But don't hold your breath.
summary: Yep, worth about what I paid to rent it.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: too much information in too little film, and when a film spends that much time explaining it isn't enteraining.  too many gaps, too many people who figure out one thing but miss the very obvious.  the sound bringing all the zombies to the wall, but the helicopter did not get them to move away, it's very loud?  injecting a lethal amound of meningitis and then walking away?  why did he suddenly smell wrong?  what about gout?  or a broken finger?  the illness had to be a virus, how did it modify the dead to be amblitory and able to hear and smell if a person was healthy or not?  a mini series would have been a better venue.
summary: the story was too big for the film
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This was a good movie, but not as action packed as I thought.  You could see it happening, a little more realistic than the classis Zombie apocalypse.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I have been a fan of the Walking Dead, and this is like an extension of that.  Awesome!  Pitt does an outstanding job as usual and the twist with the family was great.  I don't know how they got those swarms of zombies, but it was something else.  Highly recommend/
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I had so much high hopes for this one and was looking forward to a great Zombie movie. As a fan of the Walking Dead, I was looking forward to at least something on par with this TV show. Sadly, this movie lacked background, purpose and a plot. Brad Pitt has never been one of my favorite actors but even his performance was sub-par in this one. The story never pulls you in. Things are happening with no explanation and the plot makes no sense. I think some in hollywood simply think that putting zombies into a movie equals success. Nope. What makes The Walking Dead so successful isn't the Zombies. Its character development and the human condition surrounding the end of the world. This movie lacks all of that and simply has Brad running here, there and everywhere as some sort of "expert?" that is never really explained.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Good movie, not what I expected, but better. Brad Pitt does a good job as well as the other actors. I'm surprised, but I would recommend this movie to friends. I think you'll like this film.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Wow.  I loved this movie.  With all the new diseases popping up and new varieties of bacteria coming out, the story line is presented really well to interlock with our possible future.  Very fast moving. Excellent special effects.  I understand there is a sequel and will be going to see it as soon as it is out.
summary: Great movie. Fast paced and good story.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Nowadays it's hard to NOT see or read Zombie themed movies, tv, or books that have a different slant --This movie DOES. It's really frightening if you really let it sink in that a REAL Pandemic could occur and what would you do if it really did happen? This movie is so creepy not because of blood and gore- but because it possible with all the superbugs evolving in our world. Don't think too hard on this or you'll be digging bomb shelters and loading up on rations along with trying to remember all those prayers you haven't said in years!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Ok movie, I like sci fi and plots about the future.  I must have like it, but can't remember what it was about now, so it must have been just ok...worth watching, but not remembering.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: The movie was enjoyable, but the characters to me were emotionally rather flat as portrayed by the actors. Not as exciting as I expected, but it was still entertaining.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: While the premise follows that of the Steven Segal movie about a biological outbreak, this is much better.  Characters are more relatable and more like us.  The special effects are done so that they aren't as noticeable as such. This was an enjoyable movie with  an ending that can be an end or maybe not....
summary: I don't usually go for those zombie movies, but this one was worth it and more.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Great Zombie movie. All the characters were interesting and the well played. Had us on the edge of our seats a few times.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I was rather amused by my reaction to this movie.  One side of my brains was saying it bordered on ridiculous and kind of sucked...but all the fast-paced action might fool people into thinking it was good.  The other part of my brain was going, "Oh, wow! He was on an airplane, and suddenly everybody was getting eaten by zombies in coach--so the rich people tried quietly build a wall of suitcases to keep them out, but then a guy dropped it and alerted the zombies that there was meat in first class!" That part liked the movie and thought it was cool.My conspiracy theorists side, which I didn't actually realized I had until I watched this movie, was bellowing the whole time how this movie was probably being promoted by the government.  It subtly touched on prejudices we all ignore and pretend we don't have.  The zombies were a metaphor for all the undesirables, and the government is getting us comfortable with the idea of getting rid of people by making movies.  Yeah, I know--it's crazy.The part of me that likes to look at tabloids when I'm grocery shopping, particularly for any pictures about the Jolie-Pitt children (who are pretty much the only people I recognize in tabloids, as I've failed to live up to the vow I made when I was a kid to remain current and never become one of those uncool adults who don't know who the current singers and actors are), was looking at Brad PItt and saying, "God, he's old! Is he really that old?  Or is it raising all those kids that did that to him?"
summary: I Liked It Despite Everything (Spoiler Alert)
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Without spoiling the movie, I will say this -- there are parts that are very well written and acted.  There are parts that are just padding for time and did not advance the plot, which I just fast-forwarded through.  The special effects were special, for the most part.  Big thumbs up for the people who played the zombies, because they really committed to the role.
summary: Ended up fast forwarding through parts
Title: World War Z

reviewText: BY the title I mean that this movie starts off with a bang.  There's no wading through an hour of character build-ups you just get right down to business, which is great because we're not watching this for character back story we just want to see the end of the world.  So the movie gets started fast, keeps you going on a thrill ride fairly well without any lags in activity. Pitt does a good job with his character.  Overall a decent zombie movie with big budget effects, nothing particularly new to the genre, but not bad overall.  I would say I'm glad I rented this instead of paying big bucks in a theater, as a rental it makes for an entertaining evening at the right price.  Is it like the book, no, only loosely.  It goes with the typical Hollywood Action/thriller script, one fairly average guy just wanting to protect his family thrown into overwhelming circumstances and only HE can save the world in the end, thank god.Bottom Line:  It's a zombie movie, but it's not all that gory if you're really not into zombie movies normally. It's definitely better than a grade B flick, has a good budget for effects is overall entertaining and Brad Pitt as the hero.  For the price of a rental it's definitely worth it.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This is another Zombie end of world as we know it film.  That being said, I found it to be one of the better films and the story line was good.  Pitt did a good job in his part and the supporting cast as well.  It is nice, to find a film with this subject that really is a film and not just a rehash of those made decades ago.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I liked it, but kind of the same old zombie flicks that are going around and this tends to be just another one that is making money off the trend.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Brad Pitt and Mireille Enos star in this 2013 sci-fi thriller based on the novel.A man is sent to find the source of a lethal virus spreading across the world.This isn't bad, but could've been better and Pitt is good in it. This Blu-rayset not only has nice picture and sound, but theatrical & unrated versionsof the film plus some neat featurettes.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Word War Z starts with a sort of novel approach to the zombie thing but it never develops into a good story.  Its a zombie movie, so we expect some chasing and chewing but endless combat scenes overwhelm a potentially interesting story line and any acting talent Brad Pitt might lend to the movie.  The cause is revealed too fast and the solution too quick and simple, with the rest of the moving given to action scenes.  This would have been an OK Saturday night SciFi Channel TV movie but for a big screen production with Brad Pitt in the lead it was a total disappointment.  If you are doing a dissertation on the history of zombie movies I guess you will have to watch it, otherwise just go for a rerun episode of Walking Dead.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I am not a zombie movie fan, but I did like this one and the story line was very good. The special effects were great and the zombies were menacing. Because of the violence and intense nature of the story I would not recommend that young children watch this flick unless you want them to have nightmares for weeks on end. It is very entertaining and suspenseful and I do recommend giving it a look. It's the first zombie movie I ever bought and believe me, I never buy these kinds of movies, but this one is worth it. Enjoy it without the kids.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I originally had no intention of seeing this, however my nephew recommended it and he has excellent taste. This review is about the PG 13 version. I understand there is an unrated, more violent version, but I don't see that it's necessary. I personally love that the "gore factor"  was kept to a minimum, making this more of a suspense/action thriller. Also, although there's the inevitable CGI effects, they're also kept to a minimum. The story's the main thing here, which makes this movie so enjoyable. There are good characters, whom you hope will survive, and that's so important. I think the rating is "spot on" for this movie. If you sent the younger children to bed, this would actually make a pretty good "family film" for the evening. I watched it with my 86-year-old mother, and she enjoyed it. Check it out!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: The story line is weak and Brad Pitt should get a haircut. He just did not seem like the right actor for this role. He seem kind of lazy and did not act natural to his surroundings.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Excellent movie, is more suspenful than horror, in fact, it has almost no blood or gore, very rare for a zombie movie.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Totally an action flick.  It seems that I kept seeing the SAME ZOMBIES over and over.  Every scene with zombies seemed to have this one particular redish haired zombie that I zeroed in on and looked for, and found again, in many scenes.  I think they cloned the zombies, maybe with computer graphics, huh?Not as good as that Woody Harrelson zombie movie.  I think I like Woody better than Brad.OK OK I came back and changed from ONE star to THREE stars because Brad Pitt is in it and the acting was better than most of these kinds of movies and because 0 of 3 people liked my review.  This was a gift to me from my son and on a boring late night one weekend we weakened and watched it.This town (Atlanta area) is filled with zombie lovers, what with the filming of The Walking Dead just down the road.  Zombies totally escape me and I don't understand the fascination with them; at least vampires are sexual in nature.
summary: Hate Zombies but Brad Pitt is tolerable.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This is just a movie about Brad Pitt stumbling around from one place to the next looking for a way to fight all the zombies. Not much in common with the book and that is very unfortunate. The book had a better story line than this and in the days of sequels and remakes we could have expected the book to be turned into two or three movies very easily. Kinda sad to see this as what Hollywood would rather do.As a zombie movie its not the worst I have ever seen. Its more like a 28 Days later type of movie than a Dawn of the Dead type of deal. Watch it for free? Sure why not. Pay to go see it? Wouldn't bother unless your a Brad Pitt fan.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: a lot of it is very predictable like zombie movies Their actually infected with  rabies. Fast paced movie  and pretty well made.:)
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Apparently this movie went through a lot of re-shoots and re-edits to make it better and the work they put into it shows.  Not too much pre-amble before the action kicks in very near the start.  Some genuine scary and tension-filled, edge-of-your-seat moments; you really feel like you're in the middle of it.  If you can't get on board with the notion of people becoming zombies then you probably won't get into it.  I'm not a typical zombie-film-lover and I really liked this movie. A lot of action too.  A tension-filled, worthwhile movie experience.
summary: The rare title I've rented more than once
Title: World War Z

reviewText: loads of fans of the book slag this off. I haven't read the book so I saw this with a fresh mind. I was absolutely blown away! This is an intelligent and bloody good afternoon, with the lights out! Highly recommended.

reviewText: sweet zombie flick. Fun and exciting story that draws you in, leaves you wanting more! Brad Pitt did an excellent job in this movie.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I guess it's my time for a romance with the zombies.  NOT!!!!!  I will always love vampires; werewolves are a close second.Somehow because Brad Pitt was in this movie, I thought this was going to be a real, bona fide movie, not some paranormal end of the existence due to a "zombie" infecting a plane type of movie.  From watching the trailer a while ago I didn't suspect that the war was with zombies; although, in retrospect, I suppose that "Z" does stands for zombies and not a generation of cohorts:-)This had me glued from beginning to end.  What's causing those people to fly their heads through car windshields?  Why were some people compelled to help others?  Damn, really 23 year old doctor?  I had such high hopes for you, but that could and probably does/did happen in real life.  Darwin awards, anyone?I found myself holding my breath lots of times and reminding myself to breathe.  I cheered Gerry on as he made it out of Israel, survived the plane crash with metal protruding from his torso, and injected himself with (gotta watch it to see).I have an aversion to all things zombie.  I remember watching a stupid zombie movie every Halloween growing up (back in the days of VHS).  This actually had me mesmerized and I was impressed that I could be into a zombie movie.  Go 50 year-old Brad Pitt!!!  You're acting is superb and you've aged with distinction.  I can't wait for the sequel.
summary: I Can Only Be Involved with One Bad Paranormal Romance at a Time
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Forget everything you learned about zombies in Walking Dead.  This isn't that by far.  People in this movie change to zombies in seconds and the zombies are no slow pokes.  These zombies mean business.Brad Pitt plays a believable character who was tasked with helping a doctor figure out what caused the mutation and how to stop it.  Part of his payment is that his family will be kept safe aboard an at sea Navy vessel.  While trying to save the world the plane he was on crashes and nothing is heard from him, et voila, the family is now deadweight and sent ashore in Nova Scotia.  Pitt comes to a W.H.O. unit in Cardiff, Wales (did anybody else think ofTorchwood [HD] here?).He figures out something about the zombies, don't want to be a spoiler here, and all's well that ends well... except, where'd the Israeli LT go?Pretty fun and action packed movie.
summary: Fast Paced Action and Fast Paced Zombies
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Walking Dead has made me into a curious zombie fan. So when six months back they started showin world war z trailers at the movies, they had my attention.I decided I will give the book a flirt but as often happens before I could get around to reading it, the film was playing and after such a bam bam trailer I decided to just go watch it. My friend accompanied me because she had heard it has shots of Glasgow, a place she used to live. She hates zombie genre otherwise. She had never seen the trailer. So the film ended and I said hmmmm.. Why did they have such an underwhelming use of 3d glasses? If you want to do 3d, do it like life of pi and great gatsby or else don't do it.Not bad. But come on its 2013, this film cost so much and this is all the director really made? This one will not make it to anyone's top 5 films of the year list, I pray it is not this underwhelming a year.Brad Pitt is alright. We have come to understand he is doing safe roles and wearing his personality down. It is almost as if the actor expects you to know him from before the start of the film. A great actor is supposed to create an impression of new ness with every single film. I like Pitt but the problem with him is he is too jaded and formulaic at times. That said, I liked him in last years killing them softly but anyway world war z should have been more than just what it's sum really was.Irrespective of what I would have heard I would have wanted to watch it. I hear there will be a sequel, we will see if it is more intense.Some film makers forget that the person watching the film may be confused because they have not read the book. They should know how to slow the pace down without boring us. This is not a bad film, just too safe and overall, not something I would hold in a heavy opinion.
summary: LACKED THE INTENSITY OF THE TRAILER.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Being a fan of the genre, I was looking forward to seeing this.  But not THIS.I would have only given this one star, except I discovered so many things I didn't know before.  Like the UN has its own naval fleet.  Like there is an international commercial airport within walking distance of Jerusalem's Old City.  Like there is a world class disease research facility near Cardiff.  Like you can blow the back off a plane and it doesn't fall out of the sky immediately, or like you can cut off somebody's hand and stop it bleeding with a rudimentary bandage.  Or that you can use a satellite phone from within the bowels of a ship.  Or that it only takes half an hour to drive from Midtown Manhattan to Newark.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I'm glad I didn't pay for this one (other than through my Amazon Prime membership) but Brad Pitt still manages to bring depth and interest even to a film about a global war on zombies. Go figure.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This is a helluva zombie apocalypse movie on a scale never seen before. It is a zombie globetrotting affair as UN operative Brad Pitt is reluctantly recruited to spearhead the problem of finding a vaccine to stop the spread of the zombie pandemic. Pitt travels from the USA to North Korea to Jerusalem and final stop Wales on to the World Health Organisation.Marc Forster handles the huge zombie invasion set-pieces on such a huge scale which reminded me of huge epics such as LAWRENCE OF ARABIA in ambition. My one main problem with this film is they took out the huge zombie outbreak in Russia!! As soon as Pitt boards a Belarus airplane infected with heart-stopping zombies that plane should have landed in Russia, instead it lands in Wales and was obvious major changes happened to the film! WWZ needed an epic running time of 150 minutes instead of 115 minutes. That Russian set-piece should have stayed in the movie instead of the cutting room floor!! I hope dearly with the blu-ray release we get an extended cut or at the very least the massive deleted scenes are on the disk.The scope of this film is very big and I could have done with another 40 minutes in the cinema watching this movie. Still what is left on the screen is amazing to behold and should become an instant cult-classic in the genre. I can easily see WWZ playing out as a trilogy. If people loved WWZ they should check out on Amazon for flicks such as 28 DAYS LATER and it's equally brilliant sequel 28 WEEKS LATER.
Title: World War Z

summary: Big name actor in regular spruced up zombie movie..Dumb Movie..waste of time

Title: World War Z

reviewText: If angst and second-guessing were natural resources, WORLD WAR Z alone could power the planet for years. Initially handed a $125 million budget but then escalating to $200 million, primarily because of seven weeks' worth of reshoots, this was one blockbuster them critics were tapping as the potential summer skunker. Detractors will surely rally around the "This movie veers away from the book" flag, and it's a valid gripe. This isn't an adaptation of Max Brooks' source material but more a hijacking of the guy's book title. The book takes place a decade after the zombie war and compiles a series of personal accounts as told by the survivors. It offers gripping insights regarding the abrupt crumbling of society, how the apocalypse impacted on a religious and geo-political scale. Brad Pitt presents us with a horror thriller that suffers some from schizophrenia. It promises to be this sweeping zombie saga but then backpedals into a third act that focuses on personal conflict. The film has flaws, absolutely. Still, I walked out of the theater with a paranoid grin on my mug, edginess in my bones. I think this movie's gonna make money, bad buzz and all.Brad Pitt has had a fantastic film career for someone so homely. Here, he takes a page from Will Smith in I AM LEGEND. He plays Gerry Lane, a resourceful former investigator for the U.N. called back into the field to locate the source of the global zombie pandemic. Gerry isn't a gung-ho sort anymore. He'd rather stay and protect his family, but he's presented with an ultimatum: either get with the program or his wife and two young girls get kicked out of the safety of the command ship, the U.S.S. Argus. So off he goes to South Korea, escorting a wet-behind-the-ears genius virologist and hoping to track down Patient Zero.My pals railed like fishwives that there weren't enough gore and blood and viscera, and they're not wrong. Way I see it, the budget had risen to such exorbitant heights that the suits freaked that the film wouldn't be able to recoup the cost. And so the hard R rating had to go because more people would attend a PG-13 picture. I'm a little surprised I wasn't as upset as my friends, but I was enthralled with the film's effective approach to classic Hitchcockian suspense. Your imagination does a lot of heavy lifting here. The first 20 minutes are as urgent and nerve-jangling an opening sequence as the one in SAVING PRIVATE RYAN. I like that there isn't a set-up. There's a brief interlude in which the Lanes go thru their breakfast ritual. But then you're dropped in the thick of things and swept along by the escalated level of panic taking place onscreen. Philadelphia and Jersey become these terrifying, claustrophobic urban landscapes as the Lanes frantically wend their way thru the surging undead and the frenzied human mobs. In the dark, in my seat, I couldn't help thinking, "If one person in this theater turns right now, we're all so screwed."It's probably a mutant super-power to be able to distance a film from its source material, to view it as its own animal. I think I have it. Or maybe I got caught up with the massive fun of watching this in a packed house, a victim of a more genial sort of mob mentality. These fast-moving zombies scared the crap out of me, and I'm sure part of that is how someone bitten can turn in twelve seconds flat. It's up to you to buy into the CG stuff. Some of the scenes are over-the-top, like how the zombies in 1srael swarm and pile like Internet trolls. The personal drama loses oomph as Gerry Lane's wife (Mireille Enos) spends huge chunks of the film with a death grip on that satellite phone, waiting for our main man to call. We maybe would've been more invested had Lane's family been placed even more under duress. It sucks that Mireille Enos isn't given better and more things to do, because I think she's good here.The third act was supposed to have featured an epic invasion of Moscow, except that that was scrapped but for a few fleeting shots. Instead the third act culminates Gerry Lane's globetrotting quest in Wales, in a W.H.O. lab complex breached by zombies. This sequence features a downshift for how zombies are portrayed. The laboratory ghouls are near dormant, one scientist's exposition informing us that, unless activated by visual or auditory stimulus, they just aimlessly mill around like broke window shoppers at the mall. What unfolds in this sequence is tense stuff, but it also resurrects the more familiar zombie tropes. There may be some nervous laughter.WORLD WAR Z, more than any other zombie film, captures the global scope of the zombie apocalypse. I loved the speed and urgency of the narrative, and how it realizes and sustains the harrowing feel of end-of-the-world jeopardy. No, it's no in-depth meditation on society's collapse. But it's a hell of a wild rollercoaster ride done on a breathtaking scale. And, as a throwaway comment, I loved the concept of the Tenth Man.A few tips on surviving a zombie apocalypse (SPOILER alert):- When driving away from a pack of zombies, don't turn around for an extended period to impress the importance of the seatbelt rule on your kids- When navigating a gauntlet of noise-sensitive zombies, do turn off your phone- Don't ever leave your bloody crowbar behind- When trapped on a plane with an oncoming rush of zombies, stacking up luggage in the aisle sucks as a deterrent
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I loved the movie it  was fast pace with good surprise plot. I would rent again and again great zombie movie

reviewText: I thought the roll Brad Pitt was a little out of his element, but he played it well and the movie was very exciting to watch. We never found out in the movie, how that virus got started though.
Title: World War Z

reviewerName: hklfilms ""May the Force be with you...al...
reviewText: To me this movie really is one of the best zombie films ever made. It tackles the genre in a different way by taking it global in a very real way. The storyline is interesting, the zombies are terrifying and seeing it from the eyes of a researcher and someone who is looking for the cure while time is running out, hopping around the globe, is a unique and satisfying take.The Unrated version is definitely more intense than the theatrical. More blood & guts and some extended scenes worth watching.You may not care for fast-running zombies, but you can't deny that the zombies in WWZ are scary in the sense that they are overwhelming.I highly recommend the flick. Brad Pitt is good in it and I look forward to a sequel.
summary: One of the best zombie films of all time!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This was not a Zombie movie as the title implies.  It was an action movie and a rather lame one at that.  I guess that the studio who made this movie and good old Brad thought that they would cash in on the recent success of The Walking Dead.  NOW THAT is a ZOMBIE MOVIE or rather episodic Zombie TV Series.  World War Z has absolutely none of the blood, gore, or suspense that we have become accustomed too over the years.  There are so many low budget, independent Zombie films that get the formula and know how to put it out there to chose from and World War Z just doesn't get it.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: After watching this movie I fell asleep with the windows open. It got windy at night and I woke up to the curtains blowing in. For a minute I thought Zombies were coming in my window. Freaked me out. This movie was so scarey because they moved so fast you couldnt out run them. And Brad Pitt altho aging a bit looked really good.

reviewText: Even if you don't like zombie movies, you can still watch this and pretend that it is about a virus that goes haywire.  There are some mild profanities (Hollywood just cannot make a movie without using such words), but none of the very offensive ones (I am not sure of the "UNRATED" version), although, if you watch it very, very, very closely, Brad Pitt almost uses the F words.  I could tell that some editing was done, but most won't notice unless you replay one scene several times [I will keep it a secret].Brad Pitt actually is watchable [I am a male, so his 'machismo' is a bit too much in some movies] and comes across as a tender father even better than Tom Cruise [an egomaniac in many of his movies] did in War of the Worlds.Even the ending gives one a sort of feeling of relief.I give it a 9.7 out of 10.
summary: A great movie which is mostly safe to watch.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: So long ago it hurts my head to even think of it, I stopped taking reviews of Zombie movies seriously.  Either you liked it or you didn't.  If it's first rate drama you're after, watch an Ibsen or Chekhov play.  If it's sentimental fluff, go get "When Harry Met Sally."  If it's thrills and chills, sit down with "The Praying Mantis" or "Tarantula" or "The Blob" or any other horrific-monster-gobbling-up-everyone-it-comes-near movie.  If it's comedy, how about "Red Dwarf?"  But if you want something that dispenses a little of each - ah!  that's where the ubiquitous Zombie Movie comes in.  It has it all - even if a given feature was not deliberately built into the script.Yes, "World War Z" has drama: it's about survivors trying to save themselves from a flood of zombies.  Yes, it has sentimentality galore: it's about a man trying to save his family. Yes, it has thrills and chills: the least sound can summon an attack from raging maniacs.  And yes, it even has comedy: the absurdity of going on a Quest to find from among billions of zombies "Patient Zero."Plus, it has some features unique to itself.  First and foremost, there's virtually no gore (and I well know how that alone sends many a Zombie movie reviewer over the edge).  In "World War Z" the zombies aren't trying to eat you, only to bite you and thereby infect you.  Second, and every bit as unique (by the way, here comes a SPOILER), is the way the danger is resolved, if only temporarily: not by trying to undo whatever precipitated the zombie onslaught but by rendering those uninfected "invisible" to the zombies.  That happens to be an ingenious plot resolution - as well as a natural segue to a sequel.Though not the screenplay itself, the "screenstory" (not sure how that differs from "screenplay) was co-written by J. Michael Straczynski - you know: the creator and principal writer of the "Babylon 5" series.  And Straczynski's no upstart just out of Creative Writing 101.  The only other thing about the screenplay/story vis-a-vis the original book worth noting is that it's like having to listen to fingernails scratching a blackboard to have to keep reading again and again that "the movie was nothing like the book" or "the movie was nowhere as good as the book."  It's like this: a movie is completely different from a book - that's why they call it a movie and not a book with moving pictures!  Of course AMC's "The Walking Dead" seems to have gotten around that by referring to its comic book source as "Graphic Novels."And speaking of "The Walking Dead," I saw a far greater similarity between that TV show and "World War Z" than between the movie and any other zombie rendering.  In fact, this provided my most squeamish moment watching the movie - because I kept thinking "Someone's going to get sued!"Now to the acting.  Let me state outright that Brad Pitt has never been one of my favorite actors.  The only movie I've ever seen him in that I didn't hate was "Thelma and Louise"; but that movie was one of the greatest ever made with or without Mr Pitt's performance.  Nonetheless, I found his acting in "World War Z" to be extremely good - "good" in this context meaning ideal for the role.  The only flaw was more in the character than in Brad Pitt's performance.  And that flaw was that no matter what happened he never lost his cool.  He never got angry or raised his voice - even when he was telling the Mossad Agent that the chanting and yelling in Jerusalem's streets was what was drawing the horde of zombies.  I mean literally, he never raised his voice, so you could barely hear him issuing his warning amidst the din of noise surrounding him.I will only comment on the other actors by saying I found their acting to be more than adequate - except that, like Brad Pitt, they almost never lost their cool.  Even when being attacked by the zombies.  Now that takes "Grace Under Pressure" to a whole new level.UPDATE:  Though I won't change my rating from 5-Star, after seeing tons of 5-Star reviews that are so obviously plants I feel embarrassed to have enjoyed this movie enough to give it 5 Stars.  Oh well.
summary: Take Neither Wooden Nickels Nor Zombie Reviews
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Almost from the start, this movie hits the ground running, literally.  In that regard, World War Z resembles most other treks into this genre, in that we enter the the story at the point where the disease begins to impact humanity--it does this fast, fast fast...  No real surprise there.  The only shortcoming I can see in this movie is, in its desire to keep momentum, it cuts out what I call lead-ins, the "back stories" or the build-ups.  What I mean is, you see a grouping of navy ships in the ocean--no zombies anywhere and all is settled.  I wouldn't have minded seeing the ships going through a sort-out--assume the virus is airborne, so some of the crews would be affected.  Perhaps show the ships desperately leaving port, booting angry zombies over the sides and with only partial crews left--in other words, show the struggle--show the lead-ins, the build-ups.  They did this a little bit with the Israel segments--a little--so that portion of the film worked better for me--show the lead-ins...  Overall, I give this film 5 stars because it does keep the viewer engaged from start to end.  Brad Pitt and the rest of the cast did an exceptional job.  The zombies are crazy scary--fast and darned angry--really angry.  Well, wouldn't you be angry if mother nature did that to you?  I'm now interested in the book.  I hope the book has the lead-ins.
summary: Nothing slow here.  Move into the fast lane, and hit the accelerator--hard.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: When I saw the trailers for World War Z, I was thrilled to see the new Brad Pitt movie! And the opening scene didn't lead me astray: Brad Pitt is with his family in the warm kitchen setting, basically cooking and saying "I love you" to his kids while his kids were smiling and saying "I love you too Brad", then Brad and his wife hugged while the kids were smiling. At this point I was on the edge of my seat watching some quality family bonding. But things just got worse.Later Brad and his family were in a car further bonding and saying "I love you" back and forth, and I was loving every second of it. Seeing a happy white American family is why I pay $12 to see it on the big screen, but then the movie took a sharp derail. Suddenly ZOMBIES of all things started appearing and the city turned to pandemonium. WHAT THE HELL!? It doesn't get any better dear readers, yes while Brad is still with his white family they aren't warm and happy and saying "I love you" to each other, instead they're all panicked and trying to survive! BOOORING! Luckily the film had the good sense to keep cutting back to Brad Pitt's reactions while the world is going to hell, because we all know the source material showing the desolation of the world and collapse of civilization needs a white vaguely Christ-like figure to react to it.Later Brad Pitt and warm loving American family are on a boat with other refugees, and a big meanie comes out and says that Brad needs to do his part and look into the cause of the outbreak. WTF! Doesn't Sargent Jerkface realize that raising a family is doing your duty (amiright single mom's?)! So unfortunately Brad had to leave his family behind on the boat, but don't worry! Because he has a cell phone and every 10 minutes he calls his family and delivers such lines such as "how are the kids" and "I'll come back to you". Finally! Something that's actually engaging, I don't care about the world, even other families that are getting violently killed! I just care about Brad Pitt's family, because they say "I love you" a bunch of times. THAT'S what this movie should've really focused on. Every time some zombie crap was going on I was pounding my arm chair and loudly demanding to know what Brad Pitt's wife and kids are up to!Thank White Jesus for the MPAA and concerned mothers across the country for guiding a movie called WORLD WAR Z about THE END OF THE WORLD into something I can take my screaming spawns to as well, because someone needs to think of the children! WON'T SOMEONE PLEASE THINK OF THE CHILDREN!??!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This movie always seemed rushed to tell the story and you never really feel connected to characters due to their stunted development.  I think if this movie was split into two parts to tell the story more fully it would have gotten a higher rating from me.  Brad Pitt is great on screen but he just seemed hollow; again due to lack of depth of his character.  Most of the others in the movie were forgotten the minute they left the scene.  I would not buy this film with it is worth a spin if you don't have anything else to do.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: If you suspend all common sense and science then you might like this absurd movie. There are so many things wrong with it that I couldn't keep up with them. Plus Pitt's character has two whiney little girls that scream and whine throughout the entire movie. Special effects somehow create more people than can be placed into one area of the world in an instant to make crowds into a weapon of the zombies. As with all zombie movies one cannot ask simple questions like "How do you kill a dead person?". Or "Why do dead people need to eat?".  Or how does an airplane that has been diverted to a World Health Org. location crash because of a zombie on board and the only two survivors can then walk to the WHO building when they don't even know where they are or what country they are in after the crash. Then the cure is to give every human left alive a deadly disease so that the  zombies do not want to eat tainted food! No one explains how the millions with the deadly disease will survive the disease. Other than that you will enjoy it.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Brad Pitt + zombies should have been a recipe for success. I still had hopes for this film, even after mixed reviews and all of the talk about the many problems that occurred during filming. The decision to go with a PG-13 rating was probably the first mistake, as much of the bite was removed (pun intended.) There was nothing frightening in this film, and Pitt seemed almost robotic. Perhaps he should have played a zombie.The one scene we all saw in the trailer that showed the zombies frantically climbing on top of each other to reach the top of a massive wall was pretty cool. But while watching it, I thought, "This is a nice little piece of CGI," and not, "This is a terrifying scene."There are much better zombie films out there, and I'd recommend skipping this, or wait until it shows up on Netflix. In the meantime, I'll happily recommend the BEST zombie film I've ever seen (actually, a British miniseries): Dead Set.
summary: If there was anything scary here, I missed it.

reviewText: This is appropriately rated with the name of the lead actor...the "Pitt(s)"!!! A sketchy plot, no scientific plausibility at all -- which is the hallmark of GOOD science fiction -- and pretty much a venue for computer graphics geeks to create scenes with thousands of these Zombie-thingies climbing walls, throwing themselves off ledges, crashing into windshields....well, you get the drift.  I'm surprised what a star at the level of Brad Pitt saw in this script, since it certainly didn't challenge his formidable talent.And another thing....where do I get one of those aircraft he flew all over h**l and back with, apparently, only one brief refueling??  AND the thing actually launched from an aircraft carrier!!  Shoo-ie! I gotta git me one of those!! :)

reviewText: WORLD WAR Z certainly got a lot of unjustified bad press before its release. Over budget and full of delays, it seemed like a pet project of a major star who had gone overboard. I hesitated to see the film and now can happily say the critics were wrong.The zombies are at it again and this time they are in every corner of the world. No place is safe, especially large cities. These zombies are new and improved. They are almost super zombies who can jump and soar through the sky yet as with all zombies, there are a few constants. A shot to the head is the only sure way to kill a zombie. If a zombie bites you, you become one of them within seconds. Zombies meander without any purpose other than to create more zombies. Got that? Then follow along.WORLD WAR Z has a brief set-up. Gerry Lane (Brad Pitt) has left his job at the United Nations and is a stay-at-home dad for his two adorable daughters and loving wife. It's a tranquil and happy, if uneventful, existence. I was never clear as to what his exact job was at the U.N. and why he left. It seems like he was some sort of investigator in dangerous war zones. It only takes a few minutes for the action to begin and things get intense and terrifying. WORLD WAR Z has begun without any sort of advance warning.Lane is called back to work for the U.N. to uncover the origin of the zombie plague, but first he and his family have to be rescued from the zombies and taken to aircraft carriers far offshore. The action is intense for a while and it does raise questions of what will governments do when the zombies attack. How will the uninfected be rescued and where will they go? The decision is made to send Lane to find Patient Zero and where the pathogen originated. The journey starts in South Korea and Lane is always one step ahead of hoards of attacking zombies.There are plenty of special effects and action in WORLD WAR Z but it almost seems less about the zombies than about inter-personal relationships and how one lives through a zombie attack. The zombie pathogen spreads quickly across through the globe thanks to air travel..though if a person bit by a zombie becomes a zombie in seconds, we see how soon everyone in a plane becomes infected so who ends up flying and landing the plane? We can overlook some flaws in the script and just enjoy a good zombie movie.Brad Pitt has certainly grown up through the years and no longer is just another pretty face. In fact, Pitt looks aged and weathered in WORLD WAR Z. Are those wrinkles around his eyes created through make-up or is Pitt going natural? Pitt does a fine job as he tries to find the weak link in the zombie chain. Is there a vaccine that can save mankind or can the zombies be stopped. Rest assured that our hero won't give up.Lane travels to Israel where the government has been able to keep the zombies out. Jersusalem is even taking refugees  until the zombies seem to work in unision to form human pyramids to scale walls. Thousands of zombies are on the attack in Jerusalem and it is pure chaos. Young Israeli solder Segen (played by a remarkable Daniella Kertesz) bravely fights the zombies until she is bit by one and Lane quickly acts to save her in a serious OUCH! moment.While watching the zombies in action in Jerusalem, Lane realizes the zombies avoid certain people. Those "healthy" individuals aren't attacked, and lane thinks he knows why, but he has to find a research facility to test his theory. Of course, that involves leaving Jerusalem and getting to another country by plane, but we know what can happen on a plane is just one crankly zombie stows away. All this adventure does make the movie fun and engaging.Although WORLD WAR Z follows the zombie routine seen in countless films and TV shows, it does breath a bit of fresh air into the genre. Fans of zombie films won't be disappointed and anyone who likes a sci-fi/action film will find lots to enjoy in WORLD WAR Z. Although it is far from perfect, WORLD WAR Z tries and succeeds in giving the viewer a lavish and thrilling zombie-fest.
summary: NEW IMPROVED ZOMBIES ATTACK THE WORLD
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: If you're a father it will bring tears to your eyes as this father tries desperately to save his family. The scenes are fresh and will shock you---if you're watching and care about this family. Many reviewers were watching only for zombies. This is the story of a father and a family.If you want a scientific and logical story about zombies, maybe you're looking in the wrong place. But if you want great acting and characters you can care about---human characters that is, not superheroes--then give it a try.I read as much of the book as I could stand, and it was trash. This film bought the title and started fresh. Kudos to Pitt and company for creating a thoughtful and shockingly fresh film.
summary: Superb and moving story about an ordinary father doing what it takes to keep his family.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Given the number of good zombie films and TV shows around, together with the pedigree of the source material that World War Z is based upon, I was expecting something really great. Sadly, this is a lazy, messy, cobbled together effort that at best might keep you entertained on a plane for two hours. It's really frustrating since there could have been a classic film in here and instead all the rewrites and budget overruns shine through.Basically, World War Z is one is the least engaging big blockbuster flicks in a while and ditches absolutely everything that made the book so hard to put down. The film is in such a hurry to get into the action that we hardly learn anything about the hero (apart from 'all he does is make pancakes' according to his daughter) and it rapidly dives into an absurd survivalist flick that's a generic rehash of everything we've seen before. It's a story that suffers from having too few significant characters (staggering, given the breadth of the book) and hopes that Pitt can carry the weight of the film all by himself.The plot lurches from one insanely bad situation to another with increasingly ludicrous coincidences that save Brad Pitt and leave every else as zombie fodder. In between surviving car and planes crashes, we're taken on a global tour connected by the flimsiest of evidence ("there was an memo with the word 'zombie'!" - seriously). Nothing Brad says makes much sense either - he advises that keeping moving is the most important strategy in a disaster, yet everyone he makes move then dies. There are completely out of place characters such as the armed druggie in the pharmacy who helps with meds and the indistinguishable WHO doctors listed in the credits WHO Doctor 1, 2, 3, etc. And while most action films escalate the tension, WWZ does the opposite with a banale finale that might have passed in one of the first episodes of a TV show but not a major film.WWZ is yet another big budget cinematic disappointment this year - I'd recommend checking out the book instead.
summary: Disappointing for fans of the book

reviewText: 5 Stars = MasterpieceTruly a zombie movie of such scope, that we've never seen the likes of it before! "28 Days Later" & "28 Weeks Later" hinted at it, with great success! But here is a film that is so vast, so all encompassing, that it captured the essence of a world apocalyptic movie, besieged by zombies, in all it's awesome fearsome, dread, panic, & mayhem! Not to mention, plenty of suspense! No, this is not your average traditional zombie fodder, with zombies all over the place looking like they should be arrested for public intoxication. You wouldn't believe a bunch of drunks could take over the world, would you? No. Neither would I believe zombies that couldn't pass the straight line walking test, let alone take five minutes to finish it, could ever be a threat to the living, but these zombies, & this zombie film, are realistic! A different breed apart!When I say realistic. This is a Zombie film, so lets keep it in context. "28 Days Later," "28 Weeks Later," & the remake of "Dawn of the Dead," are the only films that I could swallow the human race falling extinct to. The new breed of the zombie genre film. Though these are not the first zombie films to use super fast zombies. On the opposite end, traditional Zombies. There is no traditional Zombie film in existence, that could make me believe that Zombies who move as slow & are as physically handicapped as a person who just drank a fifth in two hours of 80 proof whiskey, could take over the world. On the other hand, these "World War Z" zombies were very believable as antagonists challenging the world. They were fast, feral, & hungry! They had practically the whole world population infected in a very short time. The scenes of them climbing over each other, like ants crossing water over their own drowned, to attack the living, was just spellbinding! As was the scene with the nuclear bomb going off. Miraculously potent scenes that are a direct allegory to world terrorism, but this film had scenes of personal tragedy, sacrifice, & heroism too. The lab scene was a tense personal portrait of brave martyrs, as dozens of zombies are ready to scamper over each other like rats ready to chew on our protagonist's body parts with the slightest sound. While the rest of the lab scientists & technicians looked on through video cameras with horror & hope, that they make it back. The start of the movie, where the family is running & fighting for their lives. Heart pounding intensity of human survival at it most basic instinct, protect your loved ones & yourself!When I say realistic. I mean there was no dumb moves in this film by Pitt or any of the main characters. Not like the multitude of dumb moves in films like the original "Dawn of The Dead." Not even to mention the ridiculous, it's so bad, it's good, (no, I take that back, it was not good. It was really bad!) "Day Of The Dead." This is not a film where everyone knows they shouldn't stick their hand in a zombie's mouth, less be bitten, but do it anyway. It was not filled with idiotic, lets get killed to build a body count, horror clichés.When I say realistic. I mean the way Pitt & scientist found to get around the zombies, & how they figured it out. I won't go into detail & spoil the movie."World War Z" in my opinion, is the best zombie movie ever made. Why? The acting, the direction, the editing, the plot, top flight! The combining of horror, action, & war movie genres, blending perfectly together, in an awe inspiring demonstration of movie magic! A film perfectly complimenting it's theme, the end of the world as we know it. Maybe most impressive is this. At the theater, not a single person hardly made a noise. They were totally absorbed in the spectacle of this film. No cheap jump tactics, to make them gasp, for this film needed none. No gallons of blood & buckets of gore, for this film needed none. Only the suspense & dread of what was going to happen next. Yes, you know it's a great horror film when the audience is silent. This is a thinking persons zombie film, just when you thought the zombies ran out of brains to eat!
summary: Finally! A Zombie Movie With Brains! Not One That Eats Brains!
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I delayed seeing this movie since all the trailers I saw indicated (to me, at least) it was of the same genre as many of the mindless "gnawing dead" movies I enjoyed as a much younger man, but have recently come to regard as boring.  I am glad to say it was a much better movie than my assumptions would have had me believe.  The film is not without problems.  It tries to be too many things...love story, nuclear family model, end-of-the-world apocalypse, hero vs impossible odds, etc.  All of that said, I found the overall viewing experience pleasant and rewarding.  These days, when special effects, loud explosions and shouting pass for drama, there were moments in this film that were gripping in their silent tension.  I am almost driven to find the book and read it since my Son told me it was better than the movie.  I liked it.  I think you'll like it, too.
summary: Watch it all before you decide.

reviewText: This is another zombie apocalypse movie, but these are not your Walking Dead zombies. Between the way they throw themselves around and the clacking teeth, the startle factor is enough to scare you.  But the story is pretty good too.  Definitely bothered me. I guess that's why we watch them? You can always count on Brad Pitt to pull a movie up, too. A very watchable horror flick.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: The theatrical cut of World War Z is the best.  I enjoyed watching this version, but I think that the editing of the other version made for a stronger film.  In this version, the influx of zombies (in my opinion) detracted from the storyline and the viewer's ability to bond with the family.  By telling the story from a more narrowed lens (seeing mostly what Gerry and his family saw) as opposed to multiple broad lens shots (millions & millions of zombies everywhere), the viewer has a more intense adrenaline kick.  It's worth watching, and it's really great to be able to compare this version to the first version--I certainly made me appreciate the first version even more (I consider the theatrical version a 5 star, even after over 10 views).
summary: Outstanding movie, a must watch so that you can compare it to the theatrical version to determine which you like better!
