Title: World War Z

reviewText: World War Z is Brad Pitt's zombie epic about the spread of a virus that turns people into the undead, but instead of walking they sprint and create chaos with every step. Pitt plays Gerry Lane, a former UN investigator who is called into action by an old friend when the human race is on the brink of extinction. While he risks his life to look for a cure, his family (with his wife Karin played by the incredible Mireille Enos) is on a US Navy Carrier out at sea. Nations fall, people turn on each other, and it seems all is lost. But, this is not the case as Gerry begins piecing together clues and starts a search that will change everything, leading to the "war."WWZ is a truly impressive movie, especially considering it's a PG-13 zombie movie. While I do like the gore in a zombie film, this movie proved you don't need it. The zombies were frightening, the realistic science was there, warfare is taken into account, and overall it just felt like what would really happen if the zombie apocalypse happened. Marc Forster's directing was superb, showcasing both the epic scale of a global panic and war, while showing us the smaller battles and struggles that are happening everywhere else. This movie has the perfect transition, going from the massive blockbuster to a classic zombie movie setting. When it comes to acting, it was great. There were only two moments where the dialogue didn't quite match (when Gerry talks to Warmbrunn about the wall in Jerusalem), and even though there won't be any Awards the acting was still great. The visuals were happily polished, being more realistic, especially having both CG and practical zombies, with amazing make-up. You can see my review of the musical score on the soundtrack's page (by Marco Beltrami). But then there is the cinematography. Words cannot describe how impressive it was to see all the locations and sites, especially Jerusalem. Plus, this is only the start. WWZ kick-starts what should and can be a trilogy, just showing us the outbreak, spread and beginning struggles with the undead. There is so much more to come. World War Z is not for everyone, but anyone who appreciates well-made action movies, a thrilling epic, or some good freak-out moments, this is your treat. The beginning of a new epic, and it paid off in full
summary: Thrilling, Intense and A Well-Made Beginning
Title: World War Z

reviewText: World war Z is a interesting take on the Zombie genre, It has your typical elements that you see in every Zombie Flick out there, I.E. (Mass hysteria, Zombies Chasing and Biting people turning them into Zombies etc etc.) But whats not so typical about this film is the different stories and undertones you might get, I.E. (The U.N. Being Directly involved, even how things might be different in other countries.) Over all this film is (I.M.O.) fun to watch I am not a Brad Pitt Fan but the story dose not focus just on his role but focuses on the different stories and a bit on the undertones.The story is fantastic and perhaps not so typical, the entertainment value I.M.O. is one that I watch this film and will watch this film again and again.If your a Zombie fan and/or a Zombie movie fan watch this movie at least once you wont be disappointed.
summary: A interesting Zombie Flick with some undertones....

reviewText: Nothing at all like the book, which makes sense because if you've read the book? You'll know there's no way one could make a movie out of it. The most disappointing aspect are the zombies. Being a PG-13 movie, the zombies are nearly deprived of all gore and blood; instead they make happy chipmunk noises when their teeth snap open and shut. A lot of the movie is just Brad Pitt going from one zombie infested area to another in search of clues, all while escaping certain death.2004's 'Dawn of The Dead' and 2002's '28 Days Later' did this type of zombie movie much better and you'd be better served by watching those flicks again over this sterilized for mass consumption package of clichéd zombie tropes.

reviewText: I saw this in the theater when it first came out. It  was amazing on the big screen and the sounds were awesome. I knew I would watch it a few more times so I purchased a digital copy. First, there are some parts that were in the theater that were missing from this version. I am sure in five years they will release a super special unrated uncut directors super secret version that will include the missing four minutes. Second, I had to hold the remote all of the time because the volume was screwy. I would have to turn it up to 35 and then turn it down to 15 because it got too loud. 30 seconds later I had to turn it up again because I couldn't hear the guy screaming. If it was just me I wouldn't complain. I talked to some friends who made the same purchase and we all had the same complaints. Another friend bought her BluRay version at Wal Mart and the sound was perfect. This is the only movie in my substantial video library that has this issue. A last minute add.....the movie is over two hours long. I think another 30 minutes for plot building would have been helpful.I give the movie I saw in the theater 5-stars easy. I am only rating the digital download from Amazon 3-stars and I think I am being very generous. I was told the BluRay version is outstanding but won't rate it because I not seen it.

reviewText: Less a driving narrative than a series of set pieces, World War Z went through a gauntlet of writers and directors before it arrived on screens in 2013.  This fragmented production is evident onscreen, as our hero (Brad Pitt) ends up in one location after another for various reasons in order to find a solution to the sudden "zombie" outbreak that has spread worldwide in seemingly a few minutes.  I put "zombie" in quotes because the monsters in this film are not the walking dead in the traditional sense.  Instead they're virus carriers ala 28 Days Later who may not even be dead - just infected.  They also run really, really fast, which may or may not be your cup of tea.Max Brooks' novel, on which this film is very loosely based, was "An Oral History of the Zombie War", and every chapter was a different perspective from around the globe, describing the outbreak, spread, and results of the "plague" on the survivors, as all great zombie stories do.  In this film, other than Pitt himself, there is precious little time devoted to any other living characters.  If this were to actually happen, how would the populace react?  Do the dead and to each other?  Romero is the master of this genre because he understands that the zombies are not the villains - they are simply part of the environment that the characters must contend with.  The real villains are ourselves - our selfishness and our greed.Finally, for a zombie film there is no gore at all.  I mean none.  I guess this is how you produce a PG-13 zombie picture, but for a longtime fan of the genre, this was particularly lacking.
summary: The troubled production is evident onscreen.

No real characters that were interesting or memorable (who cared if any of them bit the farm).  A spotty plot that jerks around and doesn't really create any tension or excitement.  Inaccurate portrayal of the world of aviation, the military, and science (labs/infectious diseases) which makes the whole thing just painful to watch for anyone with even a casual familiarity of any of them.  Normally you could just sort of ignore it and enjoy your popcorn but they constantly held it up for close inspection letting you know exactly how little of a clue the director/producer had.All and all a rental and a big letdown considering how good the books was.

reviewText: Book readers worry when their favorites tomes are translated to the big screen. But WWZ fans should feel fairly good about this film adaptation. The film amps up the speed of the zombies, making them full throttle runners rather than shuffling deadheads, attacking normals like a lioness on a pokey gazelle. That makes them terrifying, as does their ability to scale obstacles by piling atop each other, antlike, until they reach their objective. The book's global reach, with reports coming in from various nations, is handled differently than the book, but manages to cover the US, the Koreas, Israel, India, Crete, Russia and Canada.Brad Pitt really steals the movie. He's a former UN investigator called in to deal with the madness. With his streaming long hair, he's a modern knight errant, living by his passion and wits, bravely going where no soldier or scientist dares. The film is non-stop action after about ten minutes of character development. There are crashes, explosions, screaming, terrified running and close escapes galore. The action drags a little in the last third (mostly due to a lack of zombies) when it swaps sheer terror for tension. Yet, this is still a smart action film, in which (thanks to Angelina, no doubt) the UN and the World Health Organization get major roles.Though rated PG13, WWZ might be a little rough on preteens. I know mine would have had nightmares.
summary: I was in The Big One, baby: WW Z

reviewText: I like zombie movies and was a little suspect that this would be a good movie but I like Brad Pitt so I gave it a shot.  The movie moves very quickly with a very fast character development on Brad and his family and moves right into high impact action sequences. After each action sequence is a little breather with some human interaction to further develop the human side of the characters. The action scenes are very well done. The film overall is well written, well directed and well acted.I liked ever part of this movie. I was surprised it was this good as I had relatively low expectations for it.It looks at the good and bad parts of humanity, through the randomness of mother nature's vengeance, you're taken on quite a ride where good people and bad people are harmed. It is sad and uplifting. It is exciting and suspenseful.Loved it.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Max Brooks' book "World War Z" worked as a book because like all good science fiction it showed a dystopian future to highlight the failings of the present:  Zombies became a threat because of the trappings and failings of globalization, modernity, and humanity.In the film adaptation, the ideas, themes, and motifs that made the book such an interesting read have been filtered out, and the residue is a competent if all-too-conventional thriller.  Gone are the hard truths and slow horrors of fighting a total war of extinction and entropy -- what's left is a slick video-game-friendly easy-to-shallow story of a man who solves the zombie puzzle in less than two hours.

reviewText: A great movie that has all the elements for a good scary ride and it is just that, a Good Scary Ride.It seems that most of these reviews are based on a television show I found boring and derivative; "Walking Dead".I'm guessing that fans of that show also think vampires are like the ones in that "Dawn" series.* Since I didn't read the book, I'm basing this review upon the movie itself. *Apparently the movie's biggest letdown, was that it used the book's title. Dollars, per usual, made that dumbnon-artistic decision. Personally I wish PR departments weren't so damned lazy that they just threw money at aproblem and then sit back comfortably, after having made their overpaid decisions. But, it did put a lot ofdisappointed butts into theatre seats AND made a lot of stockholders very happy.Plot holes: They ONLY needed one infected person. Wrong.Firstly, zombies have taken over. As in, zombies are everywhere. A semi-working lab wasn't found until near theend of the movie and it wasn't functioning very well. Should a cure have been discovered at a local Kinkos thathadn't been overrun by zombies or maybe in a WalMart pharmacy department?I've read about the physics of zombie stacking here and it's wrong. Was it shown correctly in the movie? No; thebottom tiers should have been crushed under the weight, BUT, that wouldn't stop a horde of mindless zombies, onfull blown adrenal rush, from scaling a wall without any regard for their own individual well being, let alone thewell being of another zombie. Of course this is all based upon my assuming, that they wouldn't even realize thattheir are any other entities, other than their own selfish, self-centered, selves.You know, 'zombies be spoiled'.Why? You may ask? Because (1 zombies are mindless entities that do not care about harming themselves; (2 Army antscan do it to bridge areas, to get to where they want to go; (3 Zombies do not have to move like Frankenstein'smonster; (4 if zombies that don't just plod along some road in America, or are moving seemingly too fast, thenmaybe you were actually scared. And, rather than admit this, you decided that the movie was all wrong; that BradPitt leads too privileged a life; that he's married to Angelina Jolie... et. al."What was that noise?"
summary: Great movie. I didn't read the book.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I'm a huge zombie fan and this movie just didn't measure up.  These zombies seemed completely uninterested in eating which is the very reasons zombie are scary and they were way too athletic.  I read the book and it is NOTHING like it.  It could have been soooooo much more if they slowed down the camera so we could actually see the action and they spent less time on relationships - more time on the crisis in each moment.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: My wife and I enjoyed this movie and we will watch it again. I thought that Brad Pitt did a good job in acting the role of an UN investigator. The action is nonstop and interesting. It is a different spin on the zombie movies as these devils are lightning fast and strong. The scenes in the movie can be graphic but it is a zombie movie and you knew that going in.I am reading the book and the DVD came so we went ahead and watched it. I was surprised at how different the book and film are but I enjoyed the film for what it was, an action movie based on a horror topic. There were some parts of the movie that were just stupid in how people behaved in a crisis but it is probably closer to real life behavior than we would like to admit. People will panic and act dumb!It is a good film but it certainly is not the most graphic or scary movie about zombies that I have seen. For me the film Night of the Living Dead was a shocker that I still remember to this day. I also think that the TV show Walking Dead is far more gory and graphic in the traditional sense of the zombie stories. For those reasons I rate this film as a 4 star entertainment value.
summary: A good story and a lot of action but it is a different sort of zombie story!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Brad Pitt is fine as a United Nations employee traveling across the world in a race against time to stop the Zombie pandemic that is toppling armies and governments, and threatening to destroy humanity. The film is definitely entertaining, although there are moments when it certainly drags a bit. It's a CGI extravaganza with no blood and very quick glimpses of the zombies as other reviewers also noted. I assume this was done to keep it's PG 13 rating and maybe keep the big budget for the CGI effects which is very overused IMHO. After a while, it gets a bit frustrating being a fan of the genre and I felt that 28 Days Later was much better. The silly premise of injecting oneself with a deadly disease in order to be "invisible" to the zombies was quite preposterous, but then again, it's Hollywood.Brad Pitt gave an interview where he said that "they pulled out all the stops" for this film and perhaps I had higher expectations based on his remarks.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I waited for the movie, and waited for the DVD release, and have watched it over and over.  As a Zombie Movie fan, it met my expectations, and the zombies were unbelievable.  Having been from Philadelphia myself, the opening scenes are supposed to be in Philly, but wound up using a city in Europe, made up like Philly, using Philly street signs, bus signs, etc,  and Race Street where the film takes off with the attack, kinda makes me think "gee what would I have done there on Race St, and where could I have run too"  ha-ha.  Seriously, great effects, makeup, and storyline.  Highly recommend, and now can't wait for the sequel now in filming.  Sit on the edge of your seat and enjoy!

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Intensity reigns supreme in this film, chronicling the rise of a Zombie apocalypse. Brad Pitt plays the protagonist, who spends the film trying to discover the source and solution to the massive problem of an exponentially increasing zombie population. Just when you think the problem might be solved, think again! Even though this film is a roller coaster of intensity, the ending is satisfying. I absolutely loved this movie. It gives the viewer a sense of hope in the midst of a terrifying situation. I highly recommend this movie, especially for people who are looking for a unique twist on zombie-themed entertainment. Full disclosure: I have not read the book, World War Z, so I do not know how well the book is adapted to film.
summary: A new take on the zombie trend

Title: World War Z

reviewText: ********SPOILERS****************SPOILERS********The movie tried to capitalize on the zombie-mania and appeal to two target audiences and ended up alienating both. That's not to say it's a bad movie, on it's own. In fact, it's very good. They probably made a mistake in buying the rights to world war Z and marketed it as such. It has absolutely nothing to do with the book and now it's highly unlikely that we'll ever see a true adaption of World War Z the book, which is an utterly fantastic read.That said, it's an excellent movie and stands on it's own. It probably needed to be rated R. It needed a bit more in terms of disturbing images. Not gore, as that gets redundant quickly, but it needed more to grab the audience and make them feel like you felt when you first watched 28 Days Later. It should have been given it's own name: The Zombie War. WW3. Z. So many names would have worked. That's practically all they took from Max Brook's book.***************Major Spoilers from the book --- Do NOT read if you ever intend to read the book**************Those of us who read the book will always think of what it could have been. Brad Pitt is a first rate actor and the cast was excellent. If it had been even a little faithful to the book it could have been incredible. Brad Pitt could have played the interviewer travelling in the new redefined world. We could have had flash backs and the most important stories could have been presented. It would have been fantastic on so many levels.Eventually, a movie will be made that is faithful to the book, just the way the LOTR was eventually made. It excluded some much loved and important chapters, but it was much longer.  The problem is it will probably take many, many years. Zombies will have to go out of vogue then come back in... we will be older and the world will have changed. Segments of technology and the intermingling of history in the book already seem dated. That will only increase as time passes.
summary: It's a great movie but nothing like the book.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Having just completed watching the anime High School of the Dead the day before seeing this, the comparisons were striking; I much preferred HOTD.  Yes, the production values and effects in WWZ are very impressive (loved the piled up ant-like scenes) but sadly I felt something missing.. probably the historical visceral, grisly, nature of R rated zombie apocalypse films.  This was a PG-13 fare and rarely lingered on the 'horror in the trenches', panning away before too much gore is shown.  Not to say it was 'bad' film, just didn't grip me like some of the prior entries to this genre.  Seemed too sanitized, laugh; one doesn't really grasp the gravity of the situation.  Quick take: Brad Pitt whisks his family away to safety while he endeavors to find the root cause of the current zombie apocalypse.  A good popcorn film/rental, but I wouldn't splurge to own it. 3.5/5 for effects.
summary: Great effects, but overall impact dulled by PG-13 constraints.

reviewText: The summer of 2013 has not been a good one for movies. Again and again I've been treated to mediocre blockbusters from the dreadful Iron Man 3, to the disappointing Star Trek: Into Darkness, and "meh" Man of Steel. When the best movie I've seen all summer was the underrated sci fi Tom Cruise movie, Oblivion (which wasn't all that great either) you know it's a bad summer for movies. Nothing even came close to wowing me.World War Z on the other hand delivered exactly what I've always wanted from a zombie movie. Typically there are two types of zombie films. There's the Romero formula where a handful of survivors barricade themselves in a bunker of some kind (be it a house, a mall, an underground facility, etc) and attempt to wait out the storm, or the 28 Day Later/The Walking Dead story set a month or so after the war is already lost as the hero's fight to survive in the post-apocalyptic world. People like to complain that zombie movies have been played out but if you really think about it when it comes to bigger budgeted zombie movies almost every single one has followed one of these two formulas. As much as I love zombie movies, I've ALWAYS wanted to see a big, epic, war of the zombies. That NEVER happens.  I cannot think of one example of a decently budgeted zombie movie where we get to see the infection spread in real time and the world's government's attempts to fight it.As a fellow fan of the books, both World War Z and the equally fun Zombie Survival Guide, I understand the skepticism of many fans towards this movie.  No, it's not a faithful adaption. Yes, the only similarities are the title, the character names, and a few situations.  I get it. We fans are the hardest people in the world to please, and there's nothing we like less than an unfaithful adaption of a book we love. If that's going to be your hang up, I understand, and this is not the movie for you. However, if you are willing to overlook this fact, and watch this as its own standalone movie, then what awaits you is easily the best movie of the summer and one of the best zombie movies of all time. Besides Romero's original trilogy, no other zombie film I've seen can touch World War Z. It is the most epic, most intense, most nerve racking and scariest zombie film I've ever seen, and I've seen them all. No, it's not nearly as smart as the original Dawn of the Dead or Day of the Dead, and isn't quite as scary as Night of the Living Dead, but the shear scope of this film overshadows, at times,  even Romero's best efforts. I was legitimately scared by this film. That hasn't happened since I saw Night of the Living Dead for the first time. Zombies DON'T scare me. They just don't. But World War Z managed to do just that.The movie waste no time putting us right in the middle of the action. Apart from the opening or the PS3 game The Last of Us I don't think I've ever been as impressed with an opening to a movie like this. Twenty minutes into it Philadelphia is a blasted ruin, New Jersey is in chaos, the President is dead, and the military forced to fight the plague from the safety of their Atlantic fleet. From there on we get to witness Brad Pitt as he zips around the world from Pennsylvania, to South Korea, to Israel in an attempt to find the origins, and hopefully a cure, for the plague. Everywhere he goes the pace of the film is kept fast, tense, and in your face. Sure its gets kind of predictable as time goes by; Pitt goes to location A, zombies attack, he escapes, goes to location B, zombies attack, he escapes, etc, etc, etc. This would have really been better as a miniseries as it feels sort of episodic in nature and tries to cram a lot of locations and scenarios into its two hour run time, but frankly I felt they did this really well. Though the locations may change the tone and pacing are very consistent for the first three fourths of the movie, and Pitt being the great actor he is holds the film together even as his adventure spans the globe. It never felt choppy or disjointed, or like this was supposed to be a much longer story that was crammed into one shorter film. It all flowed surprisingly well and the fast pace kept my attention better than any action blockbuster this year. The formula is broken at the end when the film changes from non-stop action to slow, scary, suspense, but again though, I thought they did this remarkably well.I want to also give major kudos to those who made the decision to make the zombies the way they are. Besides Return of the Living Dead, this film has the most unstoppable zombies of any zombie film ever. Sometimes a bite takes ten seconds to turn someone, sometimes it takes a day. This allows for the outbreak to be extremely fast as we see in the opening but also allows for infected individuals to go undetected for long periods of time, only to turn when inside a safe zone. This, combined with the fact that only head shots bring them down and that they are able to climb over walls like a swarm of ants (not to mention they have magical jumping skills) makes these easily the scariest zombies ever put to film. Let's face it, making zombies a realistic threat to humanities survival isn't easy, but this movie makes the scenario frighteningly real. The speed with which the infection spreads and the ferocity of the zombies themselves makes for some very intense sequences.As for negatives, this movie does push the boundary on what we as an audience can be expected to believe. I can accept that zombies are impervious to pain, don't ever get tired, can climb on top of each other, etc. What I don't buy is when they fall off a huge freaking wall and don't break every bone in their bodies. It also gets really ridiculous the things Brad Pitt survives. He survives more potently fatal situations then Superman, and comes away with barely a scratch.  It's a little silly that way, but what action movie isn't?So if you are a fan of zombie movies, or just want a really fun action adventure that will keep you on the edge of your seat for two hours, I can't recommend World War Z enough. If you've been dying to see an epic globe spanning zombie film like I have, there is no way you can miss this.
summary: In a summer of disappointment, World War Z delivers.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I'm normally not a fan of movies or shows about the Z-word, or even the whole concept. One of the only exceptions is "Shaun of the Dead," but of course that's more of a comedy than a hungry, hungry corpses movie. So, I was pleasantly surprised by "World War Z" because, while it has the walking dead in it, it's more of a straight action/suspense/thriller flick but still remains focused on the humans in the story and makes us care about them.Like "Shaun of the Dead," we are as in the dark as the main characters about what's going on at the beginning, so we are gradually immersed in this world with them. Even if we know the premise going in, the first part of the film (like "Shaun of the Dead") still manages to put us in the position of witnessing this catastrophe pretty much the way we would if it really happened. More importantly, it makes us really care about Brad Pitt's character and his family (both by blood and picked up along the way), so what happens matters.This is a lesson that all big-budget action films need to learn: give us specifically drawn characters, take the time to make us like them and care about them, then throw them out of the frying pan and we'll follow. Does "World War Z" move into conveniently bigger-than-life scenarios and escapes by our hero? Hell yeah. Do we just go with them by the time we get to them? Of course, because see above.The only complaint I have with the film is that it seems open-ended, but I know the reason for this. In adapting Max Brooks' novel, the filmmakers had to pick and choose and focus on one character, but I'm sure their original hopes were that other story-lines from the book could be made into subsequent films in the franchise. That still may happen. And if it does and those other films are like this one, then I will willingly go see the next installment in the theatre.PS: By the way, the film made me want to read the book, and that's also a rarity for me.
summary: Thrilling Action Pic Breathes New Life into a Dead Genre

Title: World War Z

reviewText: One of the many films I regret not having seen in the cinema last summer is World War Z, based on the popular novel by Max Brooks. We zombie parents love World War Z in its many forms and were excited about a movie version. Naturally, a movie must be very different from the book. The book is a series of interviews and stories collected while compiling a report for the United Nations. A narratively faithful version would have to be a TV miniseries, probably mimicking the Ken Burns documentary style. A two-hour movie could not cover all the different stories in the book but the movie gets the feel of it by spanning the globe in search of a way to fight the unrelenting waves of the undead."Waves" is a good term to use, because the zombies here for the most part are fast-moving swarms that overrun streets, walls, apartment buildings, etc. The visuals of zombies piling up in massive heaps to scale walls are amazing. There are very few close-ups of zombies till the end. They are not very gory even when attacking people. Almost all of the gore happens just off screen, making viewers squirm more than feel nauseated.The story follows Gerry Lane (Brad Pitt) a retired special agent for the UN who gets pulled back into service as the world begins to be overrun. He and his family flee their Philadelphia home and are picked up in Newark, New Jersey, by the UN forces after some harrowing encounters. They are taken to a air craft carrier that's become the UN headquarters. Lane is convinced to help the investigation into where the infection came from and he heads off to North Korea. Things don't go well there and he starts hopping from place to place to try and find a solution to the zombie problem.The movie is exciting enough in parts but is not quite convincing. I never believed Brad Pitt's character was in jeopardy, which is a bit of a problem. None of the other characters are around long enough or developed enough to be compelling. After his family makes it to the boat, any jeopardy they experience feels forced.Considering the great source material, the film borrows unnecessarily from other sources. For example, the last third looks like something from the Resident Evil game franchise (I haven't seen the movies yet but have played one or two of the games); there's a Hannibal Lecter-type character; the ultimate solution is cribbed from Species and is not very believable.On one hand, I wanted to like this movie a lot. On the other, I didn't really hate it. It's just another summer action movie that takes itself too seriously and (rather shamefully) begs to become a franchise at the end. I'm not interested in seeing a sequel.
summary: Typical summer action film; not typical World War Z goodness
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Uneven pacing and limited scope undermines what could have been the most epic zombie to date. Instead, we have Brad Pitt playing detective all over the globe, jumping from city to city in mere minutes. The action is good, but sporadic and sometimes laughably unrealistic. Like when Brad Pitt and his Israeli companion survive a plane crash so violent, not even intoxicated Denzel Washington himself could have landed it.
summary: Undermined by limited scope and uneven pacing

reviewText: I think the acting in this movie makes it the best zombie movie I've ever seen. Its just a great movie that is lots of fun and everyone should check it out.The converted 3D is about on par with the rest of converted 3D movies. It is never as great as a movie filmed in 3D, but it still added enough depth to make the experience more enjoyable.

reviewText: You know what? You take movies like Rise Of the Planet of the Apes, the 2011 adaptation of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo or even 21 Jump Street;(movies that on the surface look like failed attempts to be more than what they are), but once you watch them you feel like a total idiot because those movies are better than you would have even expected? World War Z IS one of those movies. And yes IT IS REALLY GOOD.World War Z stars Brad Pitt as Gerry and almost instantly we are introduced to he and his family; his wife Karin portrayed by Mireille Enos. The acting in this film was good; almost too good for a movie like this. The movie itself is nearly two hours but the pace of the film is fast. The story line carries the film to different parts of the world while it brings suspense, action, and obviously, a lot of zombies.I have seen many movies with good use CGI and bad use of CGI. In World War Z the CGI is not the best, but it is such a good movie that it is really nothing to complain about.I will say I like this movie a lot for what it is. It does not feel like a Michael Bay Transformers film that despite (great action sequences and visuals), has dumb cheesy moments or is a movie that is too long, and it definitely is not like any other recent movie with zombies, no World War Z is truly artful, and surprisingly intriguing. The action is great, the story is excellent, and great job from the multi-talented supporting cast. As suggested with the climatic sequence of the film, and the confirmation by the good people at Paramount Pictures, there will be a sequel (hopefully Sequels). I myself, along with many others I know in the world will be waiting and watching. World War Z gets4 Stars
summary: World War Z is a breath of fresh air for the Genre

reviewText: Note: May contain spoilers. Proceed with caution.Over the past couple of years the zombie apocalypse genre has really exploded in almost every form of media. While I'll admit that the genre never really resonated with me like it did with others, I still found myself drawn to World War Z. Not because it looked different from the other films, video games, and novels out there and not because I'm a huge fan of Brad Pitt. It just looked... more humane than everything else I've seen up to this point. However, when it was all said and done, I can't say I enjoyed it as much as I hoped.Based on the 2006 novel of the same name, World War Z follows former United Nations employee Gerry Lane (Pitt). After being attacked by a hoard of zombies while sitting in traffic with his wife and kids, Gerry and his family find themselves on the run until a helicopter comes to pick them up and bring them to a U.S. Navy vessel. After his friend Thierry (Fana Mokoena) explains the situation, Gerry is forced to travel half-way across the world in order to find a cure for the virus. If not, he and his family are kicked off the vessel and left to fend for themselves.One of World War Z's strongest attributes is its inherent ability to keep you on the edge of your seat, literally. I usually watch movies laying down, but within the first fifteen minutes I found myself propped up in a seated position and I didn't move for the remainder of the movie. From start to finish, World War Z is an intense experience unlike any other. Whether Gerry is on the run from a massive group of zombies or creeping quietly through a zombie-infested building, your heart is bound to be pumping out of your chest. What makes it even more exciting is the fact that there's very little down time so this intensity is almost non-stop.Also, the CGI for this film is breathtakingly beautiful. The animation for the zombies is flawless and, at times, pretty insane. When you see these large flocks of zombies sprinting around, toppling over each other, or piling to reach the top of a gigantic wall, it's almost surreal. While I don't agree with the media's decision to constantly make these creatures sprint at 20+ mph, I can appreciate the level of detail that went into making them come to life. There's no doubt in my mind that it took a lot of time and dedication to make them perfect and it shows in the end.Unfortunately, that's where most of my enjoyment stopped. I was pulled in because of these extreme situations, but the narrative surrounding these moments is nothing short of mediocre. I never felt attached to Gerry and I never cared about his well-being or that of his family. They were disposable bags of flesh in an unfortunate circumstance and I never felt like I ever gained an understanding of Gerry as a human being. The only character I truly held any attachment to was a young soldier by the name of Segen (Daniella Kertesz). She may have only had a few lines of dialogue, but she was the only one who actually felt like more than just a prop in the story.Another thing that genuinely bothered me was the lack of closure. The conclusion to the story is so open-ended that it left me begging the question, what was the point? We followed Gerry through attacks, chases, plane crashes, and the like, but for what? So he could find a "camouflage"? That's it? Really? It made the entire journey essentially meaningless. I understand that not every story needs a happy or perfect ending, but at least arrive at a point. There needs to be some meaning behind everything that happened. Otherwise it winds up just being wasted time.With that said, though, Brad Pitt worked really well with the material he was given. His performance wasn't jaw dropping and it's not going to go down as one of the best performances of his career, but he did well. He was able to bring some life to an otherwise two-dimensional character and I commend him for that. I also have to give Kertesz her recognition as well. As I said earlier, she doesn't have much dialogue, but it's her mannerisms that really stand out and show her ability as an actress. I can't comment too much on anyone else because a great majority of the acting came from Pitt. Everyone else just had a few minutes here and there.Finally, the score, composed Marco Beltrami was solid. Some of the compositions were a little too generic for my taste, but they worked well within the film itself. They were loud and robust when they needed to be, but also quiet and eerie in just the right places. Beltrami definitely had a good understanding of what needed to be present here and he delivered with the perfect score. While it may not be one of the most impressive I've heard this year, it fits for the source material.Overall Score: 6.75/10 - While I did find myself intrigued during certain areas of World War Z, I can't say that I was overly impressed with the end result. It aims to be a serious entry into a genre that usually fails to be anything more than bizarre, but in its efforts it lost any sort of life that could have made it a fantastic film. I would only recommend this to the hardcore zombie enthusiasts. If you're a casual like me then I would say skip it or give it a rental.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I admit, while watching I caught a few plot holes and general weirdness, but was generally entertained.While the credits were rolling, however, more and more things started to bother me.SPOILERS AHOY!The zombie piles - Physics? Anybody? No? OK, then.10 seconds to turn - OK, so by the time you actually chopped off Sagan's hand the infection should have already spread to her whole body. Gerry conveniently starts counting after he chops off her hands. Um, no, she was bitten more than 10 seconds ago already.Bites infect you, but zombie blood in your mouth does not?This man may be our last, best hope...so let's send him out into the apocalypse looking for clues with Gerry. With a loaded gun. That he doesn't know how to use. How could that go wrong?We lost cabin pressure, so surely the plane will now crash, because....PLOT DEVICE!Everyone thinks to use rolled up magazines and insulation, nobody has a leather jacket?Let's everyone fly around looking for clues, because radios suddenly stopped working. Even though sat phones still work. And certain radios, apparently.The live humans entering Jerusalem through wire cages do not entice the Zombie horde, but Jewish songs do.There isn't so much a plot as a spiderweb built around holes. Who wants to bet that the sequel is direct to video and stars neither Brad Pitt or Matthew Fox? (Who must be so pleased that most of his scenes were cut.)
summary: Entertaining, if you shut off your brain.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: One worthwhile sequence in the entire film, no matter which cut you see. That is the battle in Jerusalem. It is harrowing and meaningful, resonating much more effectively than any of the other sequences. The irony of that scene is well conceived and really makes one wonder why did they get only that part of the film so right, while the rest of the film is the same sequence over and over with a different setting. Don't waste your time. Zombies have always been boring even if they are fast moving and behave like flocks of birds like they do in this film. If you are new to this genre, simply go back and watch the 1968 version of The Night Of The living Dead and you will have seen the only zombie film worth watching.
summary: One sequence merits viewing. The rest of the film is a snooze-fest.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: World War Z is a movie about United Nations employee Gerry Lane (Pitt) who traverses the world in a race against time to stop the Zombie pandemic that is toppling armies and governments, and threatening to destroy humanity itself.I recently watched this in the theater and I enjoyed the movie, even though it had a major rewrite, 6 month delay and supposedly strayed from the book.  To me, this movie reminded me of a cross between Resident Evil and I Am Legend, incorporating elements of both.  I am not so familiar with the book that WWZ is based so I cannot judge how closely or how far it strays from the book but like most movies the moviemakers rarely stick closely to the original book it is based.After reading about the original filmed ending being based in Russia with a harsher and more bleak, I was curious if that ending would have worked better than the one on the big screen now.  Based on the description, I am not sure it would have been better but would have given some food for thought.WWZ differs from  Resident Evil's zombie kill them all style of storyline and a little less emotional storyline than I am Legend (I like I Am Legend a bit better).  I would say that it fits somewhere in between, which doesn't make it a bad thing as I liked the storyline even though it seemed the rewrite was set up strictly to create a sequel possibility if the movie did well, which looks like that will happen.Some people will not think this a good zombie movie due to the lack of zombie fighting going on but I thought the approach was good and entertaining, Instead the movie focuses on finding out what caused the zombie disease so a cure could be found.  I thought that idea brought something new in the zombie realm of movies.Even before I read about the rewrite, I did feel that some parts were cut and abrupt a little and could have been done a bit better.  I felt the movie was a bit disjointed as well at times and you can definitely tell that the movie is a product of multiple rewrites and 2 directors which hurts the film.I thought the lack of character development was also a weakness of the movie as there was little in that realm that kept me emotionally attached to the characters.  Something that I am Legend does much better.The Zombies themselves seemed realistic and scary and even up close such as the lab scene the makeup and acting of the zombies were well done.WWZ is not perfect but is definitely a good movie to watch that despite some flaws that I enjoyed watching.  It kept me entertained throughout even with its problems and although it strayed from the book, this movie is entertaining for what it is.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Not as good as the book but the movie is awesome!! Great story line and the zombies are pretty cool just like in "28 Days"
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I went to see it in theaters, I'm completely amazed by how great it is.I had to rent it to watch again, and to show my best friend when she came over.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Brad Pitt stars in this refreshingly simple action-thriller which features a sweetly simple story-line and avoids the over-done mellow-drama's that are currently flooding movie screens and DVD players across the nation.  This movie is packed with decent acting and wonderfully constructed action scenes and filmography that really captures the atmosphere of a world thrown into disarray by a deadly outbreak.The blood and gore in this movie is tactfully done and there is not a gag-factor in this film at all.  There is a realistic amount of graphic, without being over the top or overtly disgusting.  I would recommend the UN-Rated version to any who don't mind a little more graphic blood and gore, it has scenes that are a little longer and they are less choppy.  It all flows a little nicer in the UN-rated version.Overall, I was entertained by this film and thrilled to the very end.  It was refreshing to see a new take on the common Zombie theme in movies and TV and I enjoyed the film to the very last moment.
summary: World War Z: Refreshing action movie, no unneeded fluff

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I think this movie carried the weight of such expectation, because Brad Pitt wasstarring in it.  I think a lot of people were disappointed because...whatever.Because it wasn't like Romero films.  Because it wasn't like other Brad Pittfilms (since there weren't other zombie films in his repertoire).  Since it wasn'tlike...Outbreak or something.This generated a lot of jokes, my favorite being: "How many wars is that untilWorld War Z?  Because I can't do Roman numerals."Well, I particularly liked the opening sequence.  He appears to be just anaverage guy with an average family, driving in the Philadelphia area--then suddenly--something is wrong.  At first it's apparent there's beena traffic accident ahead, but you can't see why.  From there, it rapidlygoes downhill, and Pitt soon realizes--yeah---ZOMBIE APOCALYPSE!Gee fortunate for him I guess, he worked at...uh...Center for DiseaseControl or a UN version of it, so he's suddenly desperately neededotherwise he and his family would soon have been zombie meat likemost of the rest.  He and family are rescued and plunked down atsea (zombies don't do so well at swimming a hundred miles andclimbing up an aircraft carrier's side, it seems).  Just one LITTLE catch.He has to agree to join a team searching for the source of theoutbreak before working on a cure.From there, it's sorta--hey lets go here...OH NO, ZOMBIES...hey let'stry there--OH NO, ZOMBIES...maybe over there?  OH NO...you getthe idea.Interesting Big-Hollywood approach on how to do a serious (not asemi-comic like Zombieland) zombie film with a big-name cast.The results are mixed but if you watch it with lower expectations,you may find it a decent enough thriller.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: This was a good zombie war flick, rating at about 3 1/2 stars so I rounded to 4.  My 40-year old son and I both enjoyed it.  I am very pleased to say it was NOT blood, guts and dismembered body parts.  While you see zombies from the very beginning, you just see them bite and move on while the victim turns into one of the undead (in as fast as 7 seconds)!The story line is the zombie viral infection is all of a sudden upon us, spreading so fast and so hard while the government is trying to stop it.  Of course, Brad Pitt is brought in to try to help. There is some standard Hollywood BS, like the satellite phones would not have been able to get a signal in those circumstances, so smack the director for not catching that one.  All said, it was an enjoyable movie and also good in 3-D.  It also sets you up for a possible Part II.BTW - These zombies are attracted to NOISE, so whatever you do, BE QUIET in the theater or one might just jump off the screen and come after you  :(  s-h-h-h-h
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Former UN investigator Gerry Lane is with his family when the zombie wave hits New York City. It's fast, swift and terrifying. In lieu of protection for his family, Gerry agrees to find the source, Patient Zero, at the risk of his own life. What he learns has less to do with Patient Zero and Ground Zero, where it all began--how it all began and who knew what about the zombie infestation first.I have not read the book and not having read it, the whole backstory is MIA and a few of the 'clues' to explain how Gerry came up with the idea of a pseudo-cure is vague though handled better than I thought. This could have been a muddling, confusing and very sub-standard zombie-apoc movie but the handling of the script and editing helps to give a more cohesive movie based on a book rather than a frustrating interpretation of the original concept.In terms of originality, all the credit goes to Max Brooks, for giving us an a-typical hero and a typical story-line that felt fresh. His treatment of the cause as much as the pseudo-cure is clever and different. There is hardly any gore but lots of scare moments that made me jump. The zombies in this movie isn't that far off the George A Romero version but enough differences make it feel fresh. The performance of the film itself, its characters, is a white-wash. This is no character study but all action. It's good action and done pretty darn well. Brad Pitt rarely emotes, and the only real surge of any emoting is a young Israeli solder. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie, plan on reading the book and can't wait for the sequel.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: FIrst of all, this was a good book - written by Max Brooks of The Walking Dead, but because the show has been on for 3 or 4 seasons now, I think this movie would have done much better had it been released before TWD TV series. If you aren't a TWD watcher or just read Patient Zero by Max Brooks, you may like this movie. I liked the book, looked forward to the film but have had too much ZOMBIE SURViVAL by now.  I think Brad Pitt played his role good, as he always does though.  There are suspenseful moments and revelations - but all these would have much more impact had they not  been unveiled in TWD, making much of what would have made us say  "aHA", old news in this movie. It's too bad because I would have rather seen these all these theories and survival methods done the way Pitt came to his conclusions and tried out his theories, and came out victorious. The movie has a good ending that would have also had more of an impact had it been released before 4 seasons of TWD.  It's still a good movie, with good effects - I believe there is a disc included to see it in 3D but I don't own anything that allows me to see it this way.  If you've been following The Walking Dead you probably saw these types of effects already ... can't say one did any better than the other, although the TV series showed some things in a much more .."gory" way. Although I enjoyed it and watched it a few times today - you may find it predictable - I suppose this would depend on if you read Brooks' book which this is based on (Patient Zero) or if you're an avid fan of TWD. Brad Pitt needs to get a new PR agent or something because lately I've been expecting much more from his movies and his starring in it is the only redeeming factor - they previews have been misleading (Tree of Life, Killing Them Softly) - but I still enjoy them all - probably because I watch them so many times to catch all kinds of cool things you miss if you view these films just once.I PRE-ORDERED THIS FROM AMAZON - GUARANTEED THE LOWEST PRICE- TO BE SENT TO ME WHEN MOVIE WAS RELEASED ON DVD. Well I just received it.  The stores' racks are ghost town shelves with nothing but the "WWZ  Get it for only $14.99 NOW" signs dangling off shelf as if the store was looted.  ALL OVER TOWN FOR $14.99 and I am charged 24.00 + - AMAZON SAID I WOULD GET THE LOWEST PRICE POSSIBLE  IF I PRE-ORDERED THIS WHEN IT JUST CAME OUT AT THE THEATER, pay no more than 24.00 and get it lower if the price outside of Amazon was less.I will never PRE-ORDER another movie from Amazon, the promises are getting worse and worse... with EVERYTHING lately.  False photos, lies like" this lowest price", descriptions that are absolutely untrue.... AND THE WORST THING: AMAZON's CUSTOMER SERVIC time.  *** sorry, I know this last part has nothing to do with my review of the movie but I'm getting no where otherwise with the past 10 screw ups/lies and long, too long, holds for Customer Service who makes the call ten times longer than any other customer service.  FORTUNATELY WHILE TYPING THIS REVIEW, AMAZON COMPENSATED ME OVER THE PHONE - A mutual agreement with the least amount of trouble for us both, SO I DO NOT FEEL SO BAD; THIS Cust Rep took the initiative to THINK and we resolved this issue to my satisfaction, without my having to return my order- and it took a fair amount of time. PHEW!  Sorry about this last venting - it's a good movie that should have been released earlier, and as predictable as some of it is- I still enjoyed it. If you're unfamiliar with Brooks' Zombie Survival books and graphic novels, you willl probably like it. If you are not a TWD fan - you'll find this interesting. If you're a Pitt fan, his hair is LONG in this LOL :)
summary: Took too Long to be Released and Overshadowed by TWD

I love the books dearly but I don't mind that this is not the book, it never could be.Until HBO or someone goes full out for a miniseries with the kind of punch of casting, heart, devotion, and funding of GoT nothing will be.

reviewText: "World War Z" is excellent! This is how the story goes: On an ordinary day, Gerry Lane and his family find their quiet drive interrupted by urban gridlock. An ex-United Nations investigator, Lane senses that this is no ordinary traffic jam. As police helicopters buzz the sky and motorcycle cops careen wildly below, the city erupts into chaos. Something is causing hordes of people to viciously attack each other - a lethal virus that is spread through a single bite, turning healthy humans into something unrecognizable, unthinking and feral. Neighbor turns on neighbor; a helpful stranger suddenly becomes a dangerous enemy. The origins of the virus are unknown, and the number of infected grows exponentially larger each day, quickly becoming a global pandemic. As the infected overwhelm the world's armies and rapidly topple its governments, Lane is forced to return to his dangerous former life to insure the safety of his family, leading a desperate worldwide search for the source of the epidemic and a means to stop its relentless spread.The cast led by Brad Pitt (who also produced) (as Gerry Lane) is excellent. The directing by Marc Forster is excellent. The screen story (based on the novel by Max Brooks) by Matthew Michael Carnahan (also wrote the screenplay) & J. Michael Straczynski & the screenplay by Carnahan, Drew Goddard & Damon Lindelof is excellent.The music by Marco Beltrami is excellent. The cinematography by Ben Seresin is excellent. The film editing by Roger Barton & Matt Chesse is excellent. The casting by Kate Dowd is excellent. The production design by Nigel Phelps is excellent. The art direction by Jon Billington, Ben Collins, James Foster, Alan Gilmore & Matthew Gray is excellent. The set decoration by Jennifer Williams, set design by Claudio Campana, set dressings by Tammie Childress is excellent. The costume design by Mayes C. Rubeo is excellent. The make-up effects design by Mark Coulier & character design by John Rosengrant is excellent. The special effects supervised by Neil Corbould & Gabor Kiszelly, coordinated by Jalila Otky is excellent. The visual effects supervised by Matt Johnson, John Nelson, Simon Stanley-Clamp & Adam Valdez, coordinated by Nicole Duncan, Jane Ellis, Murray Gale, Jack George, Zafar Janjua, Ross Johnson, Abigail Mendoza, Simon Mills, Rebecca Scott & Mark Sum is excellent. The stunts coordinated by Simon Crane & Wade Eastwood is excellent.This is an excellent, entertaining, and fast-paced action-horror thriller that is interesting and intriguing. This is also a well-made and well-done movie, as well. This is one of the best movies in the zombie genre. Brad Pitt gives a solid performance as Gerry Lane. This is one of the best movies of the summer season.
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: What to say of WWZ- just sit back and enjoy the ride! WWZ is simply a lot of fun. The special effects are something we have never seen before. The pack behavior of these zombies was just real enough to captivate my interest. Watch a National Geographic show on army ants or schools of fish and you will see some real similarities. The highlight for me was the entire Jerusalem scene. The reasoning of the "tenth man" was fascinating, explaining why the nation of Israel was one of the few nations to be prepared (somewhat) for the apocalypse of the undead. It was here, in and around the "city of peace", that the "swarming" effects were at their best. The plane sequence was also very well shot- after the grenade, we get to see zombies sucked out into free falls, and the effects were superb. Brad Pitt is excellent. His character goes out in search of "patient zero", and a young epidemiologist instructs him that "nature is a proficient serial killer"; furthermore, she leaves bread crumbs- clues, as to why she is doing it. There is some truth in his claim that her most frightening manifestations also serve to hide her weak point- a "chink in the armor". In real life, the Ebola virus is an example of this. We fear it because it kills- viscously... quickly... totally, with few survivors; however, this is also it's greatest weakness. For a virus to spread, to become a true pandemic, it needs to be more subtle, with a longer incubation period, and a greater chance of host survival. Ebola is too vicious- and burns itself out before disseminated contagion can occur. It's most fearful characteristics are also it's weak point. So then- how does this all relate to the final epiphany arrived at by our hero?. In other words- what does Brad Pitt's "solution" have to do with the original "problem" described by the virologist?  I haven't a clue! But hey... that's OK- I  went to watch a massive zombie apocalypse, and boy did WWZ deliver!!
summary: Swarming Zombies make for great summer fun!

reviewText: I loved this movie. The film was intense. Once the action started, it never let up. Brad Pitt's Production Company had a bidding war with Leonardo De Caprio's Production Company over Max Brook's book "World War Z". Brad won and started trying to get it made as far back as 2005. Marc Forster wasn't their first choice as Director but he proves he can tighten the screws and never let up all the way through and the extra minutes that the unrated version adds just makes it more so. For those looking in this version for the original ending, it's not here. Word was the original 40 minute ending was re-filmed. I'm hoping in a few months, Paramount will say "Hey, if we release this DVD/BluRay again and add the original ending along with the theatrical ending, we'll make a fortune again.As the time of this review, the film cost about $190 million dollars to make and had made almost a billion dollars worldwide. Pitt has plans for two more sequels and I hope they are as good as this one as Brad Pitt as a retired UN Negotiator is blackmailed into traveling the globe to find where the virus started, so his family can stay safely aboard the Navy vessel they were rescued to. The action is believable and the gore is minimal. Although the film is rated PG-13, I would think twice about letting any child see this film. They may have nightmares for weeks. For that matter...so may you!

reviewText: I first saw this movie at the advance screening in Atlanta, Georgia (I wish I could insert my pictures of Brad Pitt!!) and went into the theater waiting to be disappointed.  I am one of those people who love the book, purchased the audiobooks (both the first abridged version and the one that was supposed to be unabridged but wasn't) and watches/reads all things zombie related.  I knew the movie was not going to follow the survivor stories outlined in the book and I was sure the movie was going to be the let down of my summer.Instead the movie was extremely intense, wonderfully paced, and contained a few little details from the book (not much but I wasn't expecting any similarities at all), and a very pleasant surprised.  I bought the unrated version as a birthday gift to myself and fell in love the movie all over again.This is a VERY solid zombie film that covers the degeneration of society as everyone scrambles to save themselves and shows governments making tough decisions in order to try and keep some type of hope alive.  Yes, Brad Pitt's character piecing together everything from a few casual observations did tempt me to roll my eyes a couple of times BUT it was still a great movie.I would have enjoyed a few more battles and more blood and guts (like the reported original ending would have included) but it was still a great movie and I hope there is a sequel.
summary: Awesome at the Screening and Wonderful Unrated

It was an intense and realistic ride and I'm glad we purchased it.

reviewText: I love zombie stuff and most of it is just for fun.  But this one tried a more serious tack.It was great to see society rapidly crumbling under the unstoppable onslaught, and giving the zombies speed and agility made them so much more challenging.The ending was pretty crummy as the movie degenerated into the typical jack-in-the-box type scares given in tight quarters.  And the premise that frenzied zombies would somehow detect a diseased human while running full-speed rabid through the streets was too much.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I felt as though this movie was very well done. The actors were very convincing in their roles and it was easy to get immersed in the plot line. You definitely need to pay attention to the movie throughout or else you'll miss important details.With that being said, there were some cons as well. The first being the soundtrack. I'm an artsy fartsy type, so I notice music during movies. The soundtrack for World War Z is insanely repetitive. As in you feel yourself becoming a zombie just by hearing the same song over and over.However, I digress. It was a breath of fresh air to FINALLY have something NOT incredibly gory. I'm not a person who watches The Walking Dead because all of the gore makes me feel nauseous. World War Z had hardly any gore which made it much easier to watch and easier to follow the plot. That's not to say that it won't scare you. It'll make you jump. Overall I loved the movie with my only qualm being the soundtrack. Well done!
summary: Great movie, not so great soundtrack....
Title: World War Z

reviewText: All through this movie I kept wanting to yell, "Slow down already!" Everything and everyone moved so fast it was hard to keep up with characters/dialogue/action.  Also, I just don't see Brad Pitt as portraying any kind of hero, and the actress who played his wife had very little to do except look distressed (apparently in the original version she had an affair while he was gone--they should have kept that in).I imagine the book on which this film is based is a lot better than this.  OK, the CGI's were good, but a movie can't make it on just that.  A world-wide epidemic that zombifies people is certainly a good premise for a zombie book, and you can read the book at your own pace instead of at breakneck speed, or having to constantly rewind to see what you missed.

reviewerName: Lorenzo M. in the Hollywood CA Area "Movie Wa...
reviewText: Paramount Pictures presents and Marc Forster (Quantum of Solace, Finding Neverland) directed "World War Z" with a lot of real compassion and interesting action that might make you jump once or twice. However, the story written from Max Brooks's novel and was developed into a screenplay by Mathew Michael Carnahan (Lions for Lambs, the Kingdom), Drew Goddard (Cabin In The Woods, Lost) and Damon Lindelof (Star Trek: Into Darkness, Prometheus) had very strong middle with interesting things being revealed slowly, but left too many questions as to what lead up to the this Zombie-making virus. Not to mention the end of the film which leaves you either to expect another sequel or you're asking yourself, "...exactly what the He%$ happened? That's it?"Now for the good stuff, Brad Pitt (Fight Club, Inglorious Bastards) is back and he does a fairly decent job playing a father who is only really passionate about his two kids and his wife played by Mereilla Enos (The Killing, Gangster Squad). They both are extremely believable in their somewhat heroic efforts to avoid Zombies, climb buildings and avoid the deadly bite of a new virus. And there way of communicating to each other throughout the movie is extremely poignant to the film.That's the other thing about the sci-fi element in this movie, there is no real explanation of what, where or how this virus develops and it's ultimately still kind of vague on what cure is or reason is for it existing even after the film is over. Also the onset of the virus only takes 10 seconds after you are bitten and then poof, you're a Zombie! Even the most viral viruses we know of on Earth can take as much as 12 to 24 hours to incubate. All that aside, the movie has some great dramatic moments of tension and some surprises that will literally make you jump once or twice right out of your seat. Nothing like a dead person jumping at you (in 3D if you see it that way) trying everything they can to take a bite out of you.The CG Zombies are pretty good and the amount of action from dead people making a "Zombie ladder" over a wall to an actual airplane crash (complete with an onboard Zombie attack) is all fairly well done. Coupled with an eerie and suspense building score of Marco Beltrami (Live Free and Die Hard, I, Robot), the movie was also slightly humorous.How you may ask? There is a really good scene where Brad has to deal with a Zombie and basically figure out how to get around him to get to a medicine cabinate. In that time the Zombies make this wonderful creepy yet strangely funny clicking noise with their jaws and teeth. It always seemed to get a laugh out of the audience - until they attack you and then bite of course.David Morse (The Green Mile, Contact) plays a creepy ex-CIA agent who basically gives Brad Pitt the reason and motivation of finding out what the source of these Zombies are and where the original virus may have originally come from.It does have quite the international cast like Ludi Boeken (Q, Deadlines) as an Israel official who decided to build a wall around Jerusalem just for this apocalyptic event. (How did he know?)  Daniella Kertesz (Loving Anna, Sceenz) plays an Israeli soldier who loses more than her pride when she is almost killed by the Zobies themselves. And even Fana Mokoena (Safe House, Hotel Rowanda) plays a US official and the only governing congress member on the off-shore government naval vessel who actually help Brad and his family, does a great job of suppressing his fears.Overall, minus some of the story holes and go-nowhere ending, it was an interesting film dealing with some action, suspense and creative make-up effects headed by make-up supervisor Karen Cohan (Captain America, Les Miserables). Although, not to gory, it's probably not for the really young or weak of heart and if you're a Zombie fan, you're gonna love it!
summary: "Teeth Chattering Zombie, They Had Some Charm In "World War Z""

reviewText: I'd ordered this movie based on a quick preview I'd seen on one of our other DVD movies.  It looked like it might be a decent action movie. This is the first Brad Pitt movie we've ever seen.  It's kind of like a toned down version of "I Am Legend" with Will Smith (which we like).  If you like "I Am Legend", you'll probably also like "World War Z".  I would recommend it.

reviewText: Let me make this as simple as the movie is:Pros:- Interesting twist on a zombie outbreak and cure- Good variety cast- Interesting conspiracy (that the government received notice of a “zombie” without informing the nation/ world)- Lots of action (if you don’t care how the action is delivered)Cons:- Another book ruined…- Odd CGI zombies ruined this movie for me- Unrealistic approach of zombies having super speed and turning into acrobats- Unrealistic that in a plane crash the main character and 2 others happen to be the only ones to survive…convenient- No true character development
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I saw it in the theater second day of it's release in 3D and -- being a Brad Pitt fan -- was absolutely horrified (and not in a good way) by this nonsense.And yet I can't help noticing a lot of 5 star reviews -- almost as if it's being seeded by the studio -- for a movie that has no characters, none of the traditional zombie violence (there's a lot of shrieking and running, but nothing remotely approaching "graphic", and not a single head-shot, which is how you kill zombies... isn't it?), and a story that is just silly.The camera does a lot of flash-panning and blurring, so it's almost impossible to tell what is happening -- which is probably for the best, because the director doesn't seem to have any interest in the story anyway.Every sequence in this film, from the very beginning where Pitt and family have breakfast, devolves into a tedious cliché.  The "acting" is pedestrian at best -- Pitt's two "cute" daughters are annoying enough that I actually found myself wishing they'd get eaten.  Every scene feels contrived and often like a cut-and-paste from another movie -- which I suspect most of them are.The zombies are those high-speed dudes from 28 Days Later (now THAT is a zombie movie), and they make a lot of noise and shriek -- but someone decided to trim (or not even shoot) any kind of carnage, so while there are some spectacular crowd scenes (you've seen most of them in the trailer BTW) there isn't any visceral threat, little tension, and no horror to speak of.The film makes the classic mistake that most Hollywood groupthink projects make: disrespecting the genre.  In "Night of the Living Dead" the dead rose and feasted on the living -- and no one wasted time trying to figure out why.  In "28 Days Later" a virus got loose, and the infected feasted on the flesh of the living -- and no one wondered why.  In Zac Snyder's silly remake of "Dawn of The Dead" one of the characters died, and then it was revealed that if you're not bitten you don't come back: so where did the first Zombie come from?  HINT: it didn't matter until the idiot screen-writer brought it up.WWZ has Brad Pitt on a quest for Patient Zero (a la "Contagion" -- a great apocalyptic movie BTW) so they can do what?  Find a cure?  You turn Zombie TEN SECONDS!  Find a vaccine?  They BITE you!  It's like creating a vaccine for shark-bite!By the time Pitt arrives at the final act you can anticipate the dialog word for word, and then it all turns into a Doom-like videogame.But wait, maybe I was just jaded, with ridiculous expectations?  I felt so bad about feeling bad about this movie that I rented "Mama" just to see if I was having a bad day: "Mama" scared the pants off me.WWZ?  Forget it!  This is the zombie movie you can take your parents to -- and then you can listen to them listen to them call you a wuss all the way home.
summary: Finally a horror movie you can take your parents to.

reviewText: I've been to every zombie movie ever made since I was 5 years old and loved them all.  I'm in my 50's and have never walked out of a movie in my life, but a little over an hour into this piece of crap, I couldn't take it anymore.  I left.  The movie was basically close-ups of Brad Pitt's face and scenes of running zombies.  That's all folks!  I don't even CARE how it ended, it was that bad.  I don't know what movie all those people who gave great reviews saw, but it doesn't seem to be the same one I saw.  What a huge waste of my hard-earned money.  I only go to the theater about 4 times per year because I live on a tight budget.  I sure wish I could get my money back on this one.  Monster's University would have been much more entertaining.  I'm going to read the book and forget I ever wasted my money on this garbage.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I usually don't like zombie flicks and don't really get the whole zombie obsession.  However, I have enjoyed many of the movies of Brad Pitt in the past which is why I bought this movie (and I could always give it away as a Christmas present if I didn't like it, which I did).As an action movie it is better than average.  Nothing spectacular, but still good stuff to keep you watching and on the edge-of-your-seat at times.  But what really makes an action film good or, better yet, great, is the stuff between the action with the story line and the character development.  This film delivers no interesting twists or developments with its characters.But what is worse is there is very little new stuff added to the "Zombie Universe" if you will.  We get the same-old-same-old zombie stuff: its a virus, it's fast moving (unbelievably fast moving, even for a horror/action zombie film) they eat brains, or people, or whatever, and their numbers are growing.  Also, there aren't any answers provided as to how the zombie apocalypse (or at least this apocalypse) started or any other relevant details.Nice action scenes, decent pacing, great cast, but... ultimately a very over hyped average zombie film that offers very little new or interesting ideas or things to the Zombie genre.Mark Cordia
Title: World War Z

reviewText: First off, if you've read the book and are looking for a replica, skip this movie.  The movie takes place at the beginning of the war, and as such, is not anywhere near the book in story or format.  That being said, if you approach it knowing that it is a new story and not expecting much relation to the book, you won't be disappointed.  It's a great movie with the right amount of balance between storyline, action & suspense.  If you don't gore, you won't be bothered by this movie.  Very light on the gore factor compared to most Zombie movies and without the horrible human nature element that discourages some from watching apocalypse movies.  I highly recommend this movie as a separate entity from the book.However, do not use this movie as a substitute for reading the book.  Since they are not the same thing in any way, you will really be missing out if you do.
summary: Great story that stands on its own, without the book
Title: World War Z

I thought he did a great job.Love getting the DVD and Blu-Ray together; Digital Copy may come in handy but don't really care about that now.Good price at Amazon; beat all other prices whether online or in-store.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: The entire movie is mostly Brad Pitt running around trying to find a solution to the Zombie virus outbreak. The problem is that it's not executed very well. Each person he meets babbles about something random and then goes on to tell him that "the princess is in another castle". So finally he sets out to the next location to find the origin of the virus so he can stop it. Along the way in his search he realizes something about the attacking zombie herds that leads him to have a stroke of genius that will help him find a way to save humanity.This movie is mostly CGI zombies and the other usual Hollywood special effects. I don't know what it was exactly about this movie but nothing worked for me. Brad Pitt isn't exactly someone I think off when I think Zombie, and to make matters worse he looks completely out of place here. His cookie cutter family doesn't match him, his pretty boy persona in a world gone to the dogs doesn't match him, and his serious/stale acting style just doesn't fit the movie. This guys delivery could never make me think he's in any danger. No matter what situation you get, you always end up with the poker face Brad Pitt. Is he happy? Is he Scared? Is he angry? I don't know he uses the same expression and delivery for all those emotions. It's not Brad Pitt's fault this movie doesn't fit him though, this film is pretty predictable and bland to begin with. Aside from seeing Zombies pile up to form ladders that's about all that's new. The theory of stopping the zombies has been done before in other horror movies. This is the first time I think I've seen it done with Zombies though.The thing that doesn't make this film work though is that aside from the cheesy CGI zombies (which are so unbelievably obvious I thought I this was a PS3 game), the movie lacks the Zombie feel to it. It just feels like your typical action movie. It's more Action/Science Fiction than it is Horror. This is adapted from a book that I haven't read so I'm not sure the direction these zombies are supposed to go in. With Zombies it can be anything. They used to be Supernatural and the dead coming back to life, then people started to try to make it believable and added in the toxic chemical theories and then the virus theories which takes it from being supernatural horror to science fiction. This is kind of like "I am Legend" with the scientific approach to understanding and solving the issue.For me the movie fell apart when Brad Pit meets a certain group of folks that are nestled away working on a solution. They are all so clean cut,mentally together, and nonchalant about what's going on that it only reminds you how poorly executed this movie is in trying to make you feel like the Zombie outbreak has ended the world as we know it.The bottom line is that this movie is just a way to kill time. I actually paused it to run errands for a few hours then came back to it. It was that engaging! I'm not surprised though I rarely find myself enjoying Brad Pit movies. It's not that I dislike him or his acting, the roles he takes are never in movies that interests me. This seemed more like a Tom Cruise role I could see him playing the lead and actually making it interesting even if the dialogue is bland.
summary: Not a good Zombie movie at all
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Within minutes of the opening scene... our 'expert' protagonist, with years of experience in NATO conflict zones, has escaped a crowded city in chaos...then takes his entire family into a store being looted by a mob...then allows them to split up? The movie hadn't even started and I had stopped believing in the characters and the drama that was being so poorly constructed...This film brings nothing new to the Zombie genre. Lazy cliches include - 'build tension in a scene with a car (RV) that won't start' and the good ol' 'we must be very quiet but I forgot to turn off the ringer on my mobile (satellite) phone' - so lazy, so uncreative...so many ways to do these things right...I'm embarrassed for the film makers...I hope the $ guys made them do it...If anyone made $ on this stinker, I hope they turn around and do some good projects with it... Brad... ;-)
summary: Sloppy is a good thing on a Zombie, bad on a plot or in storytelling
