reviewText: I enjoyed reading the book this is based on a while back and was excited to learn a movie was being made of it, unfortunately this isn't a good film of the book, but it is a decent zombie film. The story follows a familiar pattern for this type of film, there's an outbreak that spreads rapidly and humanity is turned into zombies.What this film does better than most is drive home the possible worldwide scenario for this story. It showcases some incredible set pieces on a large scale for a zombie outbreak. In fact this is the film's strongest point, some of those scenes are simply fantastic to watch.The pacing of the film is pretty good, it gets going quickly and keeps the pace up throughout, although there's a minor stutter near the end. The story might not be anything that hasn't been seen before, but the telling of it is slick.Brad Pitt does a good job as the lead, it's far from his greatest role but he works well as the focus of the film. The book is more a collection of tales from around the world telling the history of the outbreak, the film follows a similar globe trotting pattern, but in a more singular fashion, just following the single lead character.Overall this is a fun zombie film, it's sense of scale and high production values sets it up a strong member of a crowded genre, but is well worth a watch.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: A different take on Zombie infection - I liked the twist other zombie movies have not introduced. Original thought & great acting by Mr. Pitt.  Some great intense moments in film.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: **Some Spoilers at the end of my review, but not anything that will give away major parts of the movie, at least that's what I'm trying to do.Seriously, I have never watch zombie movie in my life. I really didn't know what this was all about, I saw it was a prime movie, so I decided to watch it.Surprisingly, I was hooked. Again, I can't stress how much I really think the only movies are dumb. Vampires, zombies, you name it, I'm not a big fan. This movie however, focused more on the people of the movie, surviving, and what you would do for your family, also focused on the "mission". In the big scheme of things, very little attention was paid to the zombies. Sure, there are scenes where you see the zombies "walking like zombies", but only so you'd obviously know what's going on, and understand what "your" dealing with.  There was not a ton of special-effects. Seems like a lot of movies lately, have focused on "look what I can do with CGI", but not this one.**this is where my "spoilers" begin, again, nothing to revealing.The only reason why I knocked off a star, is because one of the things the preview made the movie out to be Brad Pitt's character, saving his family, protecting his family, but that is not really what happens. The first 10-15 minutes, that is what happening, but they ended up putting his family off to the side, and focus mainly on him. Don't get  me wrong, it helped the movie along in some degree, but I feel like it lost some of the "personal touch" by doing that. On a different level, it was still about him saving, protecting his family, but, his family was nowhere to be seen.All in all, this is a really great movie. I would watch it again. And even if you are not a "zombie movie fan", this is a good one. The action is good, has a  good storyline, very nice Ending?. Lol.Good luck, hope you like it.
summary: I am not a fan of zombie movies, but this was a really good movie!

Title: World War Z

reviewText: that I've ever seen. They moved like a virus invading a human body, quickly over running everything in sight. And the movie moves at the same pace. It is a sprint from start to finish.The subplot is Gerry's relationship to his wife and 2 daughters and their personal struggle to come to grips with his return to service with the UN. Gerry is a sympathetic character pressed into a position that he doesn't want by the situation at hand. He rises to the occasion and confronts his fears, himself and zombies at every turn.The larger plot of the 'war" is explosive literally and figuratively; from the small scale individual battles with zombies to the larger scale decimation of cities. The move from actors as zombies to the mass of cg zombies was seamless. The feeling of panic was palpable and the thought of coming face to face with one of these zombies was terrifying.The lack of typical zombie gore was not missed in the edge of your seat action and terror of a zombie apocalypse.My inner geek longs for more exposition of the hows and whys of the plague; hopefully those will come in the sequel.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I normally would not deign to watch a zombie movie, but I forgot that that's what the "Z" stood for, and it was only a buck to rent, so I clicked pay without thinking about it. Amazingly, it's not a bad film, not bad at all. Casting Brad Pitt for the lead role is undoubtedly one reason the film works. The promo poster was what attracted me to it.  The older Brad has lost most of his "cuteness" appeal, but his expressive face and acting ability enable him to pull off a role that could have been very campy in the hands of a lesser star. (Tom Cruise probably could have made it work, but Pitt was the less obvious, and in my opinion, better choice.) I thought all of the characters were well-cast. No one looks like a fashion model. The acting  is very serious, there are no moments of comic relief, and the movie never descends into campiness, despite the ridiculous premise. The Zombies are decidedly silly, bug-eyed and snapping, but chilling nonetheless.  I was especially impressed by the zombie hordes, and there are plenty of zombie hordes. They have the horrific appeal of an ant swarm.I watched the slightly cut version available on Amazon, which is alledgedly a bit less bloody that the uncut film. That's fine with me; I have a low tolerance for pink jello, dripping wax, and fountains of  blood. In "World War Z" here is very little gore, but lots of action and suspense, and a great central character. If you can't resist the impulse to make a Zombie film, but want it to appeal to the largest audience, this is the way to do it. It wasn't perfect, but it was entertaining, and mild enough not to give the adult viewer a stomach ache and nightmares for the next month.  It's rated PG13, but I would have loved it at age 9 or 10.
summary: The tasteful way to make a zombie film...
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Adapting books into movies is the new fad in Hollywood. With zombie mania taking over just about all aspects of multi-media, it's been getting increasingly more difficult to find a zombie tale that stands out. World War Z, based off of the popular novel of the same name by Max Brooks, is the first zombie movie in quite a few years that tries to take itself seriously. And for this reason I was intrigued. Okay, and maybe because Brad Pitt was starring in it. Zombies and eye candy, right? But anytime I hear about a movie being delayed for reshoots, I get nervous. Originally, World War Z had a December 2012 release date but due to extensive reshoots, it was decided to move the film to summer 2013. Before the movie hit theaters, I had planned on reading the book version, but once I learned that the movie was heavily deviating from the novel, I decided not to read it so I could go into the film with an open mind. I'm relieved I went with my instincts, because my 3 star rating probably would have been lower.Here's the thing. I liked the story and the general direction WWZ was going in. Gerry (Brad Pitt), a man who once had a dangerous job as a United Nations employee, gave it all up for his family. The movie doesn't get into much detail here, but you get the sense that Gerry was tired of spending long periods of time away from his wife and daughters. It's also not stated what he currently does for a living but I sort of assumed he was a stay-at-home father and appeared quite happy at making his girls breakfast and packing their lunches. I like that Pitt's character doesn't fall into one of the many stereotypical male characters, ya know, the one where the husband/father gives up his dangerous career to make his family happy but secretly yearns to get back into the field and jumps at the opportunity when it comes knocking at his door. Nope, I never got that feeling from Gerry; he appears content and happy with his role as doting husband and father. However, this all changes when zombies enter the picture. In order to protect his family, he is forced to go back out in the field to help find the origins of this devastating pandemic. Yes, I mean literally forced. While his old UN ties help get his wife and daughters to safety, his old boss has his own agenda. If Gerry wants his family to remain on the ship with protection and 3 square meals a day, then he must go. If he refuses, him and his family will be dropped back off into the ravaged, zombie-invested city they barely escaped. I definitely felt bad for him because seriously, what kind of choice is that?Let's back up for a moment. Gerry's previous job makes the beginning of WWZ somewhat believable as he navigates his family through the city of mass hysteria as people start changing into zombies within seconds. Although you don't quite know exactly what his previous set of skills were, you can tell by his calm, take- charge demeanor that he's had some kind of training. I actually liked his wife. Again going back to stereotypical characters, it was so refreshing to see that this wasn't the case with her. Instead of the typical, hysterical females we are used to seeing, Gerry's wife did everything he said, remained calm, no bitching or crying-- basically she appeared to have complete trust and faith in her husband and his abilities to keep them safe. Gerry's daughters on the other hand...I'll get to that later. I also liked the female soldier he meets up with later in the film. She was pretty hardcore, although she annoyed me towards the end when she...yeah, I'll get to that in a bit as well.The zombies themselves were pretty interesting, even though you don't get a real up close and personal look at them until the end. They also deviate from some of the characteristics we are used to-- these zombies are super fast, not slow. Also, they are not drawn to people by scent. What gets these walking dead fired up is sound.They kind of walk around in a dormant like state until they hear something. Cool, right? Yeah, well, it could have been cool if it wasn't for...I'll get to that in a moment. I promise.The last thing I liked about WWZ is the shift in priority "the cure" takes. There are so many zombie movies and books out there that focuses on finding the cure. But what if you find something that can camouflage you from the dead? I reviewed a zombie book earlier in the week called FIEND by Peter Stenson that focused more on the discovery of what they needed to do in order to NOT turn into a zombie rather than actually finding a cure. In WWZ, a kind of camouflage presents itself first, which takes precedence. I'm trying to be as vague as possible, but I guess what my point is, I like the twist and it is more realistic. After all, not all cures can be found in a week or a month. It may even take years.If you are still with me so far, thank you for being patient. Because I am sure at this point you are wondering what possibly could be so bad after talking so highly about the movie. Here is where it all went wrong.  Remember how I said World War Z is the first zombie movie in awhile that tries to take itself seriously? Well, one thing I CAN'T STAND is a movie that tries to take itself serious yet is filled with cliche after cliche. Like I said above, the movie starts off solid. Gerry and his family are stuck in city traffic when zombies start to make their debut. They steal an RV which is smart since it's (a) big enough to push other unmoving cars out of the way and (b) can possibly serve as a temporary home instead of being cramped in a car. I was slightly annoyed with Gerry's daughters; I guess since his wife didn't fit the typical stereotype, they figured to make his kids do all the whining and not listening. But whatever, small price to pay if the rest of the movie goes smoothly, right? Just when I am thinking this, one of his daughter's has an asthma attack. And it JUST so happens they forgot the inhaler at home. Why I didn't see it coming when they had talked about packing the inhaler before they left the house, is beyond me. But it should have been my first warning that more cliches were coming. The asthma attack forces them to stop at a grocery store that has a pharmacy inside. Okay, cool, they can grab the meds and some supplies. Once they go inside, it is complete chaos. People, including police officers, are running up and down the isles, ransacking the place. So what does Gerry and his wife decide to do? Yup, you guessed it. They SPLIT UP. WTF! Isn't like Survival 101, NEVER SPLIT UP??? Because you know what happens when they split up. Gerry's wife gets accosted, one of his daughters is screaming her head off. Oh, and let's not forget the RV is gone when they finally get back outside. Yup, cliche after cliche......And the cliches continue. Once they learn that sound is what attracts the zombies, you can guess what the rest of the movie is filled with. Yup, people making noises over and over and over again. Here are a just a few examples:1) Riding rusty, SQUEAKY bicycles in the RAIN in hopes to get to the plane faster. Really??? They were better off walking quietly and letting the hard rain cover their footsteps!2) The epic scene in the trailer where the zombies scale the walls in hordes. The only thing that saved that scene was how awesome it looked. But you know what caused it? A whole CITY of people singing and if I remember correctly, the sound was even louder because the singing was being projected through speakers.3) Towards the end, Gerry and a couple of others need to get into a certain part of a lab that is overrun by zombies. Gerry says no guns since it will attract sound. Do they listen? Nope. Soldier chick not only takes a gun with her, but uses it. You're smart enough to imagine the consequences of that.4) Gerry appears to forget his own advice to stay quiet as possible as he and his little group: (a) walk on broken glass, (b) "accidentally" kick something across the floor, (c) push a creaky door inch by inch instead of just opening it quickly.World War Z had a lot of potential. The focus of the story was engaging, the non-stereotypical characters were refreshing, and the zombies were interesting. But why ruin a perfectly good movie with cliche after cliche? I'm not stupid. I get movies like this need to build suspense and I can handle a scene here and there. But when characters keep making the same mistakes over and over again, I can't help but get annoyed and extremely frustrated. Oh, and I forgot to mention the 3D. Or should I say, what 3D? I am not a huge 3D fan like some people, but after being blown away at seeing Man of Steel in that format, I figured what the hell. I now wish I hadn't because I can't remember one scene that was shot in 3D. A definite waste of a few extra dollars. A sequel to World War Z is apparently already in the works and I'm not quite sure how I feel about it. On the one hand, I can see the potential because of the way WWZ ends. But I cringe at the thought of sitting through another 2 hours of cliches.Mia @themusescircle.blogspot.com
summary: A Zombie Movie That Had Potential, But Riddled With Cliche After Cliche

reviewText: Definitely not the BEST zombie picture ever made and doesn't come close to something like the TV Show "Walking Dead", but I was surprised at how much I enjoyed it.  The action was fast moving from the very start and the special effects were really well done.I am an avid zombie movie fan so it is easier for me to tell you it is something worth watching, I would say RENT it now, since the price is not for purchasing at $14.99, which is NOT worth it, but it is worth RENTING, for $4.95 to check it out for the fun of it.Brad Pitt does what Brad Pitt does best, plays the "hero of the hour" kinda guy and helps put the world on a potential good track again, but they did leave it open for a possible sequel and the overall problem was not really solved to destroy the zombies. At any rate, worth watching and NOT a time waster, but definitely not a Blue Ray DVD Uncut super set edition, $29.00+ with trailers and such, definitely a waste of money there.I think what lacked the most was I found myself not caring at all that much about the main characters of the movie. Nothing is spent on creating these characters and fleshing them out, so to speak. If they had spent more time on that, and perhaps made it a bit less predictable in the storyline (I never read the book), perhaps it may have been much, much better.Thanks again for reading my review, happy zombie hunting!Mike

reviewText: this film is a decent enough film.  It's not as good as the comic book it came from. But it is a fast moving zombie movie , featuring running zombies.  Brad pitt is good in this one and he carries the film pretty much. It did good enough for a sequel to come out. The 3d version is the best one of course. And even if 3d just adds depth it makes watching a movie more fun for sure.  The blu ray has a 2d extended version as well.  This looks great on blu ray and that's  a good thing.  This is really a expensive b movie , like 'pacific rim' if you take it on that level then you will enjoy it.  Zombies overrun everything. That's the plotline. Will they find a way to stop them?  .  It has lots of cgi effects , often those don't look as real as standard makeup. The thing prequel suffered from that as well. But this is worth watching for pure popcorn value.  The new doctor who lead actor has a small role in this one as well. Peter capaldi. So that adds to it as well.

reviewText: nicely done mix of "28 Days Later" (in which the Zombies are FAST! rather than slow and stumbling) and "Contagion" in which the thrills and drama center around the race to find a cure.  it's not Brad Pitt's fault that he's tabloid magazine movie star fodder - he delivers another credible performance in this one, and the rest of the cast is up to the challenge.  a few slightly silly moments (you really didn't think to turn off your cell phone?) but overall a worthwhile couple of hours of excitement.

reviewText: Brad Pitt is surprisingly warm and tough in this chaotic and frantic vision of our world amid a full-blown zombie apocalypse. reviewText: This movie is a great standalone zombie apocalypse movie, carrying over a few themes from the book.  I would say this movie is "inspired" by the book rather than "based" on it.Still, this movie has its merits.  Decent acting, amazing visuals, fairly coherent story.  There are a few 'why would he/she/they do that?' moments, but they don't detract from the fun.Though this unrated version has more blood and guts than the theatrical release, it still doesn't come close to other movies or zombie fare (I think it has less gore than a movie like 'Dredd' or the series "The Walking Dead").Notable differences: more graphic zombie headshots, a more intense (i.e. bloody) version of the hand removal scene in Israel, and a few more zombie body obliteration sequences.This version did not contain the original ending everybody is hoping to eventually see.
summary: Unrated version is bloodier, still not as good as the book

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Heresy - I know. This movie has been touted as one of the best of the year by some. I get it, there is almost nonstop action and tension.... Maybe that's why it missed for me. And maybe that's why I find "The Walking Dead" so much better.You're thrown into a whirlwind with almost no character development at all. From there, I guess they are hoping you won't mind! As I age I find myself enjoying movies more if they have more character than action. Don't misunderstand my view - I still love a good action film, but I guess finding ones that have that right mix of character and story get harder and harder to find. As goofy as it may sound - I enjoyed Pacific Rim more!

Title: World War Z

reviewText: But this one is still a good film, however the video game "The Last of Us" which is basicly the same story is better defined & the characters are fleshed out & defined much better, that is what is missing here, although Brad Pitt's character is defined as a loving husband & father, the other characters are just there, I admit that the action is good & the film waste no time getting to the point, & it is fast paced no doubt, which is good for those with short attention spans, but when comparing this to the game "The Last of Us" I have to wonder why this one didn't follow a similar path, I realize zombies have become the new boogie men, but let's be clear as to what may have caused such an outbreak, Will Smith's "I am Legend" did this so well, & the "Last of Us" hints at the cause, this film gives no clear explanation as to what may be the cause, there is a bit of voice over by Pitt at the end that tries to clarify it, but I feel the filmakers may be holding out to do a sequel, which would make sense I guess, as a stand alone film, it doesn't work, but if you put it with "The Last of Us" game & "I am Legend", then yes it does make sense, I will say that the airplane sequence is by far the best part.

Some parts of the book were boring as !#!@# but there was one retelling of the zombie apocalypse that reminded me about The Hunger games and surviving in the wild.  That part of the book was worth suffering through the rest...oh but the Movie..yeah...watch it.

reviewText: To be fair, I only made it through about 20 minutes. There did not seem to be a story beyond how many ways can this family be traumatized. If you like action only and nothing else, it might be OK.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: If the only reason you are planning on seeing this movie is to see the book onscreen then don't bother.  The two have little in common beyond the title. However if you want to see a good zombie flick that is well written and acted then see this movie.  This film does an excellent job of showing the true scope of the devastation worldwide without being overly gory which is quite a feat as most directors use the excuse of 'I'm making a zombie movie' to up the blood and violence and ignore the plot.  After all, it's just a zombie movie.  Now I don't mind gore and violence but found, to my surprise, I didn't miss it here. There are a lot of genuine suspenseful and terrifying moments. Terrifying because they felt real.I recommend this movie to anyone who likes zombies and likes suspenseful movies. Popcorn movies don't have to be brainless.
summary: not the book but still pretty good

reviewText: World War Z is a big budget horror film that imagines a theoretical zombie apocalypse as an extinction event on par with an asteroid impact (Armageddon) or climate change (Day After Tomorrow) or a geological catastrophe (The Core). By combining two genres the film makers made a movie that succeeded as both a horror film and a disaster film.Brad Pitt plays Garry Lane, a former top secret United Nations investigators who spent years working in many of the world's most dangerous hot spots. Exactly what Gary did for the UN isn't completely explained, but suffice it to say that it involved lots of danger and time away from his family. When the movie begins, he's retired from his dangerous life and enjoying the role of stay-at-home dad. He's on a family trip when zombies begin running amuck. Stranded in a strange city, with zombies biting and turning everyone they see, he must lead his family to safety.Help comes in the form of a UN helicopter that takes Gary and his family to a U.S. Navy ship. But sanctuary comes with a price. Non essential personnel cannot stay on the ship. So to keep his family safe he agrees to lead a mission to determine the source of the zombie virus outbreak. That mission takes him first to Korea, then to Israel (where Israeli Defense Forces are protecting Arab refugees from the zombie swarm), to France...all in search of clues to the outbreak's origin.I've never been a big Brad Pitt fan, but he did a great job playing the quick thinking UN investigator. He also had well written script to work with.A Note for the zombie cinema fans out there. The zombies in World War Z are the fast moving 28 Days Later zombies, not the slow shuffling Walking Dead zombies. Since WWZ was written as much as a disaster film than as a horror film, the writers and director attempt to scientifically flush out the idea of a zombie outbreak, and do a pretty good job of it. I'm glad I saw this movie and recommend it to my friends.
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I'm not gonna lie - I read the book first. I loved the book and I was THRILLED at the idea that they were going to make a movie. I didn't know how they'd do it but I was so excited that they were trying.Unfortunately after hearing that it bared very little resemblance to the book, I held off seeing it until this weekend.  I went into it knowing not to expect the book but hoping for a new, interesting, exciting experience, anyway. I didn't find it.Not only is this the most generic and bland zombie movies ever, Brad Pitt gives such a bland, blank performance as the main character, I actually zoned out during most of it and had to watch it again!The zombies are badly CGI'd, from far. Up close, they're cheesy (Teeth clacking? Come on) and unconvincing.The amount of times I said, "Are you serious?" became too many to count - between the awful wife (ill-timed call), the contrivances(mob rapists within hours of the zombie siege), the suspension of this movie's own rules, there were very few bright spots to cling to.The most visually striking image was on the poster, in the trailers and previews - the (fast) zombies climbing the wall into Jerusalem.... and that was about it. The PG-13 rating ensured everything was vague and off-screen or shadowed.My opinion is that if you're in the mood for, "Brad Pitt saves the world", by all means, get this movie.  If you'd rather have a thoughtful, suspenseful, SCARY fast zombie movie, get 28 Days Later.  If you'd like to see a real zombie apocalypse, read the amazing book.

reviewText: Brad Pitt's acting is excellent in this film.  What makes it tedious to watch is the fact that the audience is expected to accept the premise of a zombie apocalypse as real and possible.  if you know anything about viruses, science, or reality, be prepared with phrases like, "Oh, come ON!", "You've got to be kidding," and "Pigs will fly first."  The whole movie just seemed like a ridiculous charade to me.  I gave it 2 stars for the good acting, at least on Pitt's part.  The rest of it is just a total crock.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: MINIREVIEW: a taut, well plotted zombie apocalypse as it first strikes humanity that doesn't hold any punches in showing society unravel. The "cure" is a series of clue trails as things get bleaker and bleaker for humanity. Unlike other zombie tales they're harder to kill and they come en masse having the ability as shown in the trailers to build a "zombie pyramid" to get over towering walls. No places is truly safe. They don't let up on the overall grimness which I appreciated. OVERALL GRADE: B plus.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Heavily promoted movie and was looking forward to watching it...until some of the negative reviews. So instead of watching it in the theater I watched it at home with lesser expectations.Pleasantly surprised that the film did a nice job of combining action with the zombie horror element. The pace of the film was good with a minimum of "talking heads" to slow it down. The downside is that there was little character development and a great actress like Mireille Enos (who I loved in The Killing) was almost invisible in her role. Obviously this was a Brad Pitt movie and that is not bad even if his character was underdeveloped too.I am a huge Walking Dead fan and it was interesting to see how the 'rules' were similar or different than the film version of zombies. The WW Z zombies were lightning fast unlike the Walking Dead version. Otherwise most of the 'rules' were similar.The biggest difference between The Walking Dead and WW Z was character development. Loads in The Walking Dead and almost none in WW Z. BUT this is an action movie, not a season long TV series, so it works just fine.Definitely recommend if you want a good action movie and don't mind a little gore.
summary: Not The Walking Dead but that is alright
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: World War Z, I thought, was a nice new approach to the zombie apocalypse.  I will say that this is now my third favorite zombie movie (first two being Zombieland and Scooby Doo on Zombie Island).  World War Z has a much different feel to it than most zombie films, at least ones that I have seen.Brad Pitt does a good job in this movie.  I think this is his best performance in a while.  I like his character, Gerry Lane, because you can easily sympathize with him, and he is proactive.  I like how Gerry has a military background which plays a big role in the story.  The other characters are not really worth mentioning.  Gerry's family is not given anything to do after they escape the city in the beginning of the movie.  They just sit around on a ship for most of the film and occasionally give Gerry a call to remind us that they are still in the film.  The majority of the other characters are introduced and then killed off just as quickly.  The other "supposedly" major characters do not appear until the third act, and we do not know anything about them.There are a lot of things that make World War Z relatively new and refreshing compared to previous zombie flicks.  First is that rather than starting the movie off in the midst of the zombie outbreak (which most zombie films do) this movie shows us the beginning of the zombie apocalypse and all the chaos that ensues from it.  Also, most zombie films take place in relatively remote locations and revolve around a small group of civilians trying to deal with the new reality.  The movie starts out like that, but once they escape New York the movie shifts gears.  Rather than just showing the effects of the zombie apocalypse in one area this movie takes place over several locations and how the people in each location are dealing with the outbreak.We also get a lot of scenes involving the military and how they are dealing with the situation, which we rarely see in other incarnations.  There are also many action scenes with the military vs. zombies which are the best scenes in the movie.  The film is titled World War Z, so I expected lots of action, and I got that.  I also like how the main character is trying to find a cure throughout the movie.  Usually in zombie movies it is just people in the midst of the zombie outbreak and them dealing with it.  By the end he more or less does find a solution.  I like that it was not all in vain.  This is one of the few zombie movies to end on a somewhat triumphant note.The effects are alright.  There are many instances of obvious CGI with the zombies.  However there are also scenes that use practical effects which I am thankful for.  The score was okay, but nothing great.People have said that the 3D is not that good.  However I did not see the film in 3D, so I cannot comment on that.  I also have not read the source material, so I cannot compare them.  However, I have heard that the film greatly deviates from the book.  Fans of the book might not like this movie.Overall, I think World War Z is pretty good zombie film.  It is definitely one of my favorites of the genre.  Fans of the book should use caution when viewing this, because it is not really like the book.  However, I do recommend this to all who are fans of zombie movies.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Zombies or their equivalent appear to be the monsters of choice these days.  They've even populated comedies.  And now one of filmdom's biggest stars, Brad Pitt, joins the battle.  He plays Gerry Lane, a former United Nations agent known for getting in and out of hot spots.  He's not a para-military type.  Quite the contrary.  Now retired and spending "quality" time with his wife Karin (Mireille Enos from TV's "The Killing") and their two daughters (Sterling Jerins and Abigail Hargrove), he runs into trouble just after the opening credits.Director Marc Forster wastes no time getting into the action as the Lanes are caught in a traffic jam in downtown Philadelphia.  This early onslaught of zombies never lets up which is one of the great things about this movie.  These zoms run with the speed of Usain Bolt and have no problem hurling themselves at people, windows, vehicles or diving off buildings.  Once a victim is killed he or she will convert in about 10 seconds.Gerry manages to scramble out of harm's way temporarily and manages to get to a tall building where his former UN boss has him picked up.  I don't want to short change this section of the film.  The escape is harrowing and tension filled.  Gerry agrees to work again for the UN in return for relative safety for his family on a Navy ship well off the eastern coast.  His job is to find the source/patient zero and figure out a cure.  This takes him to Korea, then to Israel and finally to Wales.  Along the way he picks up clues that may lead to a possible immunization.Having seen scores of "R" rated zombie movies not to mention the carnage on TV's "The Walking Dead" I was curious how this film would fare with a PG-13 rating.  So here's the scoop.  We don't see any gore or blood splatters.  Yes, we get some close up zombie makeup and it's very well done.  In the final act, some zombie scientists in the Wales W.H.O. lab are really first rate, especially the one that has Gerry trapped inside a glass storage room.  "WWZ" has a fine cast and a memorable score to go with some top notch action sequences.
summary: 4 1/2 stars for a tension filled, high action zombie flick
Title: World War Z

reviewText: My sons are 9 and 10. There is not a lot of bad language or overly bloody scenes in this movie. There is one scene in which the mother is attacked by two men in a grocery store. We enjoy watching it as a family and discussing survival scenarios as well as how certain scenes in the movie were shot or how plausible certain scenes are.

reviewText: This film is about the zombie outbreak. Title: World War Z

reviewText: Much has been said about world war z. This highly anticipated film was to be adapted from max brook's cult following novel. After a bidding war with leonardo dicaprio, brad pitt managed to secure the rights with his production agency. Apparently brad then endured a year of stress to make this film happen. Reports included reshooting, delays, re-writing and an overblown budget. Ironically the critics began to appear from the woodworks, one by one to naw at the prospects of brad's brainy demise. And i have to admit it did not look promising when he was quoted as saying that he chose this role to do something his kids would enjoy. Why would his kids enjoy a horrific world war calamity??The problem for brad pitt, maybe unknowingly, was that the passionately loved book would be incredibly difficult if not impossible to translate into a 2 hour feature movie.  It really deserves a mini-series format.I am not much of book reader, but i was harassed long enough by my house mate such that one night i finally opened the pages. I couldnt put it down thereafter.When i heard they were making this film i wondered how brad would be able to bring together a book which was essentially a series of short stories,  that encompass different characters, places and times to create a world war narrative on a massive global scale. Each chapter has a different protagonist and a different perspective, that gives an insight into the world of a zombie apocalypse. From intimate tales of survival to social commentary to geo-political consequences. The book was intelligent, gripping, and always took itself very seriously.And serious is how most fans of the novel are towards this piece of fiction. Brad pitt had alot to deliver and its not completely unfair for fans to expect a certain level of respect that goes hand in hand with a planned adaptation.Without exaggeration, this film bares almost zero relation to the book. The movie from start to finish never even happened in the textbook. The only premise it took from the original source was the notion that a zombie outbreak occurs on a world wide scale. But why did he purchase the rights to deliver this premise?For those who havent read the book, it obviously appears irrelevant, but for many people like myself it means that a true cinematic adaptation of max brooks novel is no longer possible. That chance has been needlessly wasted here. This movie could have been called 'zombie apocalypse' and someone else could have produced 'world war z'. And that would have been fine,  and i might have even conceded it was a pretty entertaining movie in its own right.This movie fails for this reason. I understand many liked it, but unfortunately they dont realise just how small a glimpse they were offered, and how amazing it should have been.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: A movie that had the potential to be good, but was screwed up by morons.As with many bad films, there are usually a few really stupid things that happen that ruin the movie.  World War Z is one of these films.After Gerry gets his family to the naval group, he is told by the commanding officer that he must lead a team into Zombie infested South Korea or they will kick his family off of the boat.  The purpose of the mission is to provide assistance and protection to a doctor  who is investigating the virus and looking for a cure.  Gerry is basically forced to agree, but the commander reassures him by telling Gerry that he will have the protection of a team of Navy Seals.Given that the zombie apocalypse is going on, I'd assume that a "team" of Navy Seals would be a large number.  Uhhhh... no.  It turns out to be like two guys.  Seriously, it is like two guys... maybe three at the most.  The world rests on this doctor finding a cure and the best they can do is send a couple dudes with machine guns for protection.  Uhhhhh... anyone else find this stupid.  Wouldn't you send an entire platoon, squad, or whatever?Also, why do they travel to South Korea in a giant cargo plane.  Why?  The cargo consists of the doctor, Gerry, and 2 or 3 Navy Seals.  What the heck do they need a giant cargo plane for?  And did that plane take off from the aircraft carrier?  Do aircraft carriers carry planes that size?  Wouldn't it have been faster to take some jets and refuel them in route?  I don't know, maybe I'm crazy.  Watch the movie and explain to me why the big cargo plane was necessary.So anyway, they land in South Korea with their awesome force of like 4-5 guys and quickly find themselves attacked by zombies.  Lucky for them a garrison is at the base.  Unlucky for them, the doctor trips and falls on the platform exiting the plane and shoots himself dead.  Boom!  Dead.  Uhhhh... why?  The plot of the movie sets up this doctor as the savior only to have him kill himself before he gets off the plane?  If they were going to kill off the doctor, why not have him killed by a zombie?  Wouldn't that have that been more entertaining or more interesting?  Was having him shoot himself after tripping really the best way to do it?  Doesn't this whole thing seem incredibly stupid?  Why set up the "doctor" character only to kill him shortly thereafter is a very lame and unexciting way?  Am I the only man on earth wondering this?Well, Korea turns out to be pretty lame, so they decide that they better get to Israel because the Israeli's apparently were the first ones to close off their country to keep the zombies out.  Uhhh... except when Gerry arrives he discovers that they really haven't closed off the country.  They are still letting people in.  That doesn't make sense, but whatever.  And where did the giant wall come from?  When did Israel built the walls of Troy around the country?  Or at least around a city?The walls just don't cut it though and the zombies get in, make a mess, etc.  In the middle of the battle, Gerry saves an Israeli soldier (who has been bitten) by chopping her arm off above the bite.  That's cool and everything, but then why does he decide to take her with him?  Sure, the city if being overrun by zombies, but wasn't is a bit odd that Gerry suddenly decides to save a one-armed Israeli soldier?  Uhhhh...But hold on holmes!  I haven't gotten to the two dumbest things yet!  Amazing, I know.Jumping forward in time (after Gerry and the soldier both survive a plane crash which just happens to be walking distance from their WHO destination), Gerry makes his way to some sort of World Health Organization lab.  He needs to get to the viruses in storage, but they must fight through some zombies to get to the vault.  Who goes on this hunt?  Gerry, one dude from the lab, and the one-armed Israeli.  What?  Would you go zombie hunting with a one-armed person?  Heck no.  And what is the number one priority? Stay quiet.  Make no noise.  Ok, so guess what the one-armed Israeli does when she sees a zombie.  Bam!  She shoots him with her pistol.  They took an ax, a bat, and a crowbar in order to be quiet and the first thing she does is pull out the pistol... which the other zombies hear of course.  Shockingly stupid.But to take the cake, it turns out that the way to hide from the zombies is to inject yourself with a lethal pathogen.  The zombies won't attack you if you are already infected with some other nasty virus.  Uhh... Why?  Has anyone been watching the zombies in this movie? Did you see how fast they are?  How they jump people?  How they smash their faces through windows to get at people?  Does it look to you like any of them have time to stop and take a wiff before biting someone?  And why would this zombie virus give a damn?  So what if someone is infected with something else?  Guess what, now you can be infected with a zombie virus too!  Double the pleasure, double the fun.  What - did the zombie virus come up with a way to detect other viruses and then make judgments about how lethal they were?  Chicken Pox no but Measles yes?  Common cold no but Bird Flu yes?  What the heck?Oh - almost forgot!  Earlier in the movie Gerry and his family are joined by a little hispanic kid when they escape Jersey in a helicopter.  How did that kid make it to the roof?  Huh?  The last we saw of him before that was inside his apartment with zombies knocking at the door.  Also, we know that the staircase up to the roof is full of zombies.  So how does that kid get around all of the zombies to make it up there?  Regardless, why does it even matter?  The kid plays no part in the plot whatsoever, so why not just have the zombies eat him?Very poorly done.
summary: Apparently one-armed Israeli soldiers are idiots
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Walking Dead (which is excellent by the way) sparked this whole Zombie come back.  Zombies were never my favorite.  They are gross and generally decaying.  Replace Brad Pitt with another actor and I think this movie would have been a complete dump. Okay I like Brad.  There were parts of the movie that were okay, but in general long, drawn out and boring. Mireille Enos from (The Killing) is an excellent actor, but in this roll she was written in as this kinda mousy wife that pretty much just waits for Brad to come back to her and the kids in one piece.  Her holding the phone were some excellent scenes (being sarcastic).  She is capable of so much more, but just played a third or fourth or whatever rate actor to Brad.  It was his show and the zombies.  The computer generated kind.  There were just so darned many they could only have done it this way.  Okay.  Basically the story line was good, but it just took way to long to get there.  And then the likely hood of how to defeat them had to do with an enormous (let's say impossible) amount of luck.  Even for a movie the ending was just too much a hit and miss.  I don't want to ruin it, but if the odds in Vegas were that good, everyone would be a winner!
summary: Zombies. Are they getting worn out?

reviewText: World War Z is a great zombie movie. I read the book before watching Brad Pitt's big screen version and although it wasn't the 3-hour epic I was hoping for, Plan B has left plenty of room for a franchise. I hope they have set dates to begin production on part 2 and I also hope they do not let this summers string of flops deter them from moving forward. This was a crazy summer for Hollywood across the board. Zombies continue to be hot and an early 2015 sequel would be nice, a Halloween 2014 release would be even better. I'm sure Brad Pitt knows that "The Battle for Yonkers" must be included in the next version, as well as the wealthy "Mansion" scenes. Including the downed pilot would also be a huge addition. I think they did a great job with the first one and hope they take it even further for part 2 with a 3-hour epic!

reviewText: The unrated (as opposed to the theatrical) cut is only eight minutes longer,but they are mostly very short bits elaborating on the zombie attacks. So theunrated version makes the violence much more vivid. The cuts were probablymade to spare the gentler souls among us, but if you're into zombie apocalypseyou may want the critical-mass view of things. In particular, the big Philadelphiasequence at the beginning is notably more intense. On the other hand, if you'rewatching the theatrical release, you won't be missing plot points or anythinglike that.Of the film itself, it definitely doesn't screen like something that was rumoredto be weak before its release, as this was. In fact, it is both innovative in thisgenre and very exciting. Its only weakness in my view is a lack of interestingcharacters. Comparing it with The Walking Dead, there's no one like Rick, Michonne,the Governor, and so on. On the other hand, this is a much more lavish productionthan The Walking Dead. I'll say this--fans of the zombie apocalypse genre shouldn'tmiss either title.

reviewText: The best Zombie movie yet. It kept me on the edge of my seat all through the show. I just wish it was a bit longer and showed him introducing poor one armed Sagen to his family. She too was terrific in her roll. reviewText: After reading the book, I was pretty stoked to find out about a film adaptation being made, I was really excited for it, but then I saw the trailer. My initial reaction to the trailer was, oh god they ruined it, this is gonna be nothing like the bestseller, but you know, you really can't judge a film just by its trailer.So I went out to see it at a local AMC theater. I sat through the whole thing and, I was very disappointed.My main issue with the film was how it ended. *SPOILER ALERT* Brad Pitt luckily picks the right unmarked vile that contains the cure to the disease, and if he was to make the wrong choice, all of humanity would pretty much be lost. Wow, what a lucky dude.I hate it how they end a film like that! Also,I guarantee that you will not relate to or like any of the characters in this film.The effects are decent though, not too bad but, eh.I give this film a 2/5  Just read the book, it's ALOT better, trust me.
summary: Waste of Time, decent effects though

reviewText: As a big Sci-Fi fan, I always look for "coming attractions"........Max Brooks book  covers the before during and after, while the movie skims over and concentrates on the Pitt maneuver. Good action, a story line that may leave some scratching, and fast zombies!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Brad Pitt spends a lot of time running down streets, sneaking around in the dark, walking through crowded corridors with other survivors, and as an exciting denouement, racing up and down almost identical laboratory corridors.  It's the end of the world, Living Dead style. There are some scary moments. And they are very good, which makes you see exactly how dismal the rest of the film is.  I was moderately entertained until the laboratory sequence, when I realized that being bitten by a ghoul was a picnic in the country compared to watching more of Pitt tiptoeing past zombies in labcoats, pushing security button door openers and piling gurneys against swinging doors. We have all seen the other movies, they all did the same thing.  "28 Days" and its sequel were better and they weren't wonderful.  The book the film is 'based' on, which was written by Max Brooks, son of comic genius Mel, is an oral history of our planet's encouters with zombies and very well done.  Too bad they just used the title.If you want to see a really chilling zombie film, something original but that sticks to our essential Romero Rules, you have to keep waiting. And if anyone knows of a film that lives up to the standard set by Romero's original "Night of the Living Dead," please let me know.  I don't think I've seen it.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Watched it twice.  Would watch again and again.  Loved looking at Brad Pitt in the family way as a husband and father.  Everything was great about this movie.

reviewText: The action was great but not enough killing groups of zombies. I would have liked to see a bunch killed with Vulcan Mini-Guns, Strykers with 105 cannons and grenade launchers, tanks, napalm, and more with  flame throwers.  Also it only showed zombies biting people not eating them. Maybe the sequel will be better.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Very rightly, other folks have advised that WWZ is NOT a straight adaptation of Max Brooks' entertaining 'hisorty' of the zombie war. I prefer to describe the film as "inspired by the book of the same name." We are dropped into the home life of Brad Pitt & Merielle Enos adn their two young daughters with no explanation or context. Just what we can pick up from the TV and radio chatter heard in the background. Very, very quickly, everything goes--as a friend from the UK likes to say--pear-shaped. Again, without warning or explanation. This is the film's chief virtue. For as long as possible, director Marc Forster keeps his audience off-balance...and frightened. This are not the zombies of George Romero or Robert Kirkman. This is a worldwide pandemic that is moving far too fast. As Pitt's character, Gerry Lane, takes his worldwide investigation (as a UN consultant) to Israel, the story starts to falter. An attack is instigated for the seemingly sole reason of getting Gerry OUT of Israel and into an airplane and onto his final stop. This attack is completely aviodable. By this point in the film, what attracts the infected to the healthy (loud noise and activity) is well-known. Yet, a celebration (amplified with HUGE speakers!!) is allowed to occur NEAR the giant wall built to keep the undead out. GUESS what happens?!? Once on the plane, we are treated to one more thrilling fright before arriving in Wales for this film's resolution. It is well-known that the ending was reshot and delayed release of the film. It is the weakest section of the picture. Pitt's voice-over narration as the film concludes leaves the door open for a sequel. As WWZ turned out to be a financial success, the sequel is possible. I can't see it being more than a 'bug hunt' (sorry, Pvt. Hudson). Certainly a different kind of action film. I watched WWZ alone and then again with my wife and a third time with a friend. It was fun to watch the shock of others and I wasn't bored. The holes become obvious, though. The BD looked and sounded great on my 57" DLP screen and 7.2 surround system. I'm happy with the purchase.
summary: Mostly holds up under multiple viewings
Title: World War Z

reviewText: No matter what anyone says about the action, cinematography, special effects, or anything else, there's a huge problem with this movie: There's absolutely no reason to find the source of the "zombie" virus. All you need is one infected person and you have everything you need to do the science required to develop a vaccine. In other words, having Brad Pitt running all over the world chasing down the source of the virus is pointless, which makes the entire movie pointless.If you can suspend disbelief sufficiently to ignore the pointlessness of the whole thing, you might enjoy the action which is well-done and exciting. If that's all you expect from a movie, you'll love World War Z.P. S. Why is it that it's always the mediocre films that are so full of themselves they sacrifice the ending to create the opportunity for a sequel?
summary: Don't you hate gigantic holes in a film's premise?
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This brief review is more than knowing I'd have a story and performance bar set from 3 years of watching The Walking Dead.Its more than that.The story is contrived around a UN operative(Pitt), of whose former role at that organization, is never clear. However: helicopters, airplanes and human life are at Pitt's disposal as he hunches his way around a dissolving human race. Everybody likes him, no one questions him... must be like being married to AngelinaWhile the movie begins in The City of Brotherly Love, Phillie... then surprisingly moves-on to Newark, New Jersey; of all places.... (not the first city i would chose to traverse as the dead start walking and biting... where are these characters from? Not Pennsylvania.. They must be following a gps and not good sense.... might as well just get a room in downtown Camden.) but no association with any US forces occur. Instead in this P.C. tale; we are to believe that the 'UN fleet' safe off New York is running the show amid the chaos. The New World Order steps up to bat against the Zombie Apocalypse and comes off as contrived and undefined as the Socialism that supports it. It's like counting on the French and their leadership; only 'times 2'...Pitt rises above all the sacrificial death and destruction that is put-out in support of his inane quest. Again... it all just seems like a day in the life of a spoiled brat(brad), getting his own zombie movie.I truly hoped this would not  happen, I so wanted a cool zombie movie... So will you....Cheers and good-luck mate!

reviewText: Well, as far as I am concerned this movie is worse than one star.  Ok, I will blame myself for not reading up on this stupid movie before I rented it because I absolutely hate zombie movies of any kind!  But..I didn't anticipate the two main actors involved lowering themselves to a zombie movie either.  Let me say this, I rented the 128 minute version.  It took me 3 days to get thru 46 minutes of the 128 minutes!!  I just kept saying, "OMG! This is so horrible!", and then turned it off!  Even the parts I forced myself to watch had such poor lighting that it seems like they filmed this in the dark our something.  Maybe they couldn't afford lights, I don't know.  But Brad Pitts last name has taken on a new meaning now.  It falls under movie ratings now..."The Pitts". I'm not a big Brad Pitt fan anyway but give me a break!  Even if I were I would hate this movie.  Like I said I didn't watch it all the way thru because it was literally that bad. I just want to pretend that the main characters were devoured by the zombies and therefore, I will live happily ever after!!!  Please don't tell me otherwise.  It's my fantasy.  Don't bother renting this unless you are a die hard zombie fan because that is all this is about.  I have to stop typing now.  I'm having WWZ flashbacks.

reviewText: Let me state upfront that I did not read the book, so I cannot make any comparison between the book and the movie. But I did see the first trailer for this many months ago (it's from the very beginning of the movie, where Brad Pitt and his movie family is stuck in the car in Phillie), and I was genuinely excited and very much looking forward to seeing this. Then all of the negativity started seeping from seemingly everywhere (multiple scene reshoots! budget overruns! nonsensical plot!). I mean, the movie critic at the Financial Times, whom I happen to respect quite a bit, rated this movie zero stars, ZERO! My son and I finally saw the movie this weekend in the theatre."World War Z" (2013 release; 116 min.) starts off with Gerry Lane (played by Brad Pitt) and his family (wife and 2 young daughters) having breakfast while keeping an eye on the TV, broadcasting disturbing news about rabies-reminding symptoms breaking out everywhere. Next thing we know, the Lane family is stuck in a traffic jam in downtown Phillie, and all mayhem breaks loose. Those 10-15 min. in downtown Phillie are some of the most intense minutes I can recall seeing in a movie in a long, long time, and after that we are off to the races. To tell you more of the plot would surely ruin your viewing experience and hence pointless.Several comments: the initial 80 min. of the movie (ending with the crash in Wales) are nothing short of flawless, indeed the most thrilling and intense movie viewing that I have experienced in a long time. The uncertainty, anxiety and utter chaos all feel very real. Forget that this is a "zombie" movie, as it is more about a movie where the human race is fighting for its very survival. The last 40 min. are not quite as stellar (and hence I can't rate this movie 5 stars), where the producers seemingly were struggling in how to bring it all home and wrap it up in a sensible and believable manner. At that, they succeed, but the visuals simply cannot compete with those of earlier action scenes in the movie. All that aside, I would strongly urge you to forget about all of the negative stuff you've been hearing or reading about this movie, as "World War Z" is shockingly good and makes for a very intense movie experience. Both my son and I simply loved it. We saw the movie in 3D and I didn't think it added much to the experience, so save those extra $3 or 4 bucks and see it in 2D. Meanwhile, "World War Z" is HIGHLY, HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
summary: 4.5 stars... Shockingly good and intense movie experience

reviewText: I really enjoyed this movie relating to zombies from a almost believable standpoint. Unlike the fairly cheesy ones that were made in the 80s and 90s with just bad horror makeup and terrible plots. And a few that were just too graphic with poor acting. This one rocks with a good plot and is always on the move. I did not get bored.The movie begins right off with chaos and gets progressively worse as Brad Pitt leaves with his family on a normal day. Since its a virus that changes these people into the zombies, the objective begins where they must locate the source. And in the meantime you're wondering who or when the next person will change into a zombie as the story unfolds.

reviewText: The label on the box's  picture on Amazon seems toindicate that you get an unrated version and a theatrical version on both the DVD and Blu-Ray discs.  Amazon's details on the product indicates that you only get an unrated version and only states the unrated run time of the movie; which is wrong by the way, it should be 122 minutes.  The reality of the situation is you only get the unrated version on Blu-Ray and the theatrical version on DVD.  Somewhat disapointing since at some locations I do not have a Blu-ray player.  The theatrical version only is on the digital version with english track only.  Would be good if Amazon has a picture of both sides of the box so one could obtain it for itself before buying.The movie is interesting, a little different from other zombie movies I've seen.  These zombies  are harder to kill.  In the past you shoot them, they are down, but in this movie they get up again and keep on coming.  One would think that when you blow them up the little pieces would still be coming or reassemble.  Maybe in the sequel.  Anyway, my favorite part is when they are in Israel quite an impresive scene.

reviewText: In the natural order of things no one would argue that zombies are at the bottom of the food chain. Unless of course, they are the zombies of World War Z. Never have dead people run so fast, gathered so close without biting one another, or chased anyone so diligently. Brad Pitt is great, his character is not superhuman, nor endowed with any super power other than his own abiding faith in himself, his love for his family, and his weapons that do not take him all the way to the end of the war. No, this hero uses whatever is at hand, a gun when available, an iron pipe if not, or his own hands if it comes down to it. And it does. He is great - BUT - (wait for it...), the zombies are fantastic! Never has a movie depicted the dead literally flowing across the screen, over fifty foot high walls with or without machine gun wielding living bodies on top. They swarm across rooftops, oblivious to the fact the roof ends with a sixty story drop to the street. They race down hallways unconcerned for their safety or well-being, and even attack when there is no hope of victory...proving they are zombies after-all. Suspense is limited however by the same factors and this nearly cost it a star - but not quite. I've come to expect the dead to generate less suspense or awe-inspiring fear than say a power-hungry Emperor with a space armada at his disposal and a henchman who breathes through a mask and talks really deeply! But the dead CAN and DO generate a visceral fear that I cannot explain, am at a complete loss to fathom and yet find myself at the edge of my seat with my hair standing on end, (even in my nose! which takes a bit really!). A must see flick for the morbidly obsessed zombie fan, or anyone who can devour a bucket of popcorn, large box of SnoCaps, and gallon of Coca-Cola in under three hours. Yep, been there-done that, and am willing to do it again, even if it's to World War Z (1), for lack of a 2!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: As a fan of The Walking Dead, I had to give this movie a shot. The way people were "zombified" had a different spin, which was pretty interesting, and I also thought the pace of the movie was good. There isn't a lot of lag time in getting right into the meat of the story, and I appreciated that. It was worth the rental, and I would watch it again.

reviewText: This is a hard review to write. Why would Brad Pitt do this movie? I am a HUGE Brad Pitt fan. I have to wonder why he chose to be in this production.The script is one predictive scene after another. I just wanted to Zombies to ‘do away’ with the annoying daughters of his character. There is NO chemistry with the on-scene wife! Really now! Brad had more chemistry with Tom Cruise in ‘Interview With The Vampire!’ The only Tom Cruise movie I have been able to sit through, BTW.I am very glad I did not waste my money on this at a theater. reviewText: DVD arrived in perfect condition and before the predicted delivery date.Oh God, another ZOMBIE movie!  Look what the "Night of the Living Dead" has grown into. There are a lot of zombie themed films and books and stuff about. So, why watch one more? This one is from a main line studio with A list stars and a moving plot. A fast moving plot...that follows how a plague could travel the planet in days accurately. Only this plague is a virus that causes zombies. Brad Pitt stars as a retired United Nations "troubleshooter" for the Secretary General who gets unwillingly recalled to the job by the emergency of the wildfire infection racing around the world. We go from Philadelphia to a US Navy task force evacuation fleet off the coast of New Jersey, to South Korea, Israel, and finally a World Health Organization research facility in Cardiff Wales. All in about thirty hours time. The pace of the film is frenetic  due to the rapid spread of an unknown virus. And I mean rapid...from bite by an infected zombie to a full blown dead and biting zombie in TWELVE SECONDS. Can Gerry (Brad Pitt) find the source of the plague and a means to an antidote or vaccination? Watch it and find out...and do not expect all happy stuff as thermopile concludes.I liked this film. I enjoy the growing zombie rage in entertainment. Hey, when I was a teen, one of my favorite singing groups WAS " The Zombies"("She's Not There")!  I never miss the best series on TV, "THE WALKING DEAD" , so of course I had to get this one. I enjoy all the different " takes" on zombies by different writers, directors, creators, make-up artists, etc. But these World War Z zombies are not your everyday "Walkers" stumbling by eating people. These zombies are FAST! They run, they climb stuff well and quickly, they break glass easily, and they aren't biting you to feed..they bite to spread the virus...that seems their only drive once infected. WOW.  Seeing a major city overrun in minutes is chilling to watch...and to me, the best and most jarring scene is the virus being spread on an airliner in flight..with our hero on the plane with an idea for antidote about to be infected...a hand grenade can sure be useful!!Watch this one to see what I'm talking about. Highly recommended!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I don't understand what the critics want from a movie. This was very entertaining - granted it wasn't a grand drama, but it was fun and enjoyable.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This tale serves up a few interesting twists, and some pretty cool special effects, but as zombie films go, it's not all that memorable. One thing that was missing, which is in a way good, but also in a way- not so good, is that there literally isn't much  blood and gore or maybe even none at all. I suppose people expect some blood and gore when it comes to zombie movies, and that is usually a major factor that hardcore zombie fans expect, but it's nice that the film manages to be pretty slick and entertaining without much of it. The special effects are really rather great at times, especially how the zombies are presented as being extremely vicious and rabid.They climb upon one another by the hundreds trying to scale the tall walls of fortified cities. At a distance they look like armies of ants piled one upon another. This is the niftiest thing about this movie. These zombies are very fast and very determined. It's also pretty refreshing that when they "turn" they don't really look all evil and rotted out like they do in some zombie movies, they just look like regular people who appear slightly less alive. Over time they begin to morph into something more sinister looking. The sounds they make with their vocal chords are pretty creepy, and they did manage to put a frieght into me. They are rather scary, though not all that unique from zombies of the past.If it had not been for the suprb AMC zombie epic "The Walking Dead" with it's extreme gore and powerful story telling being still very much on the minds of many zombie fans, this one might have seemed a little more endearing to some people. But as it seems to be suggested by the many less than  impressed reviews, zombie fans have the AMC series and much better movies to reference on their minds, such as Night of the livind Dead, Both Dawn Of The Dead and it's remake, 28 Days Later, and numerous other zombie movies.In my opinion Brad Pitt seems a bit miscast for this kind of role. It really is a rather obvious departure from most of the roles he's chosen. Then again I'm trying to imagine who could have been cast in this and would have fit the role better. Liam Neeson? Keifer Sutherland? Maybe Cruise or Hanks? Na, don't think so. Pitt moves along with this role perfectly fine, but he just seems not only a bit out of his normal territory, but it's also hard to imagine him with the sort of job title that get's him elected to take on the task of helping end the pandemic in the first place.Over all the story is interesting, and the action is often very good, but the movie just seems to be lacking a great deal that would make it memorable. Most of the characters in the movie and the actors that play them seem rather cookie cutter and the performances and characters are not particularly great. This film has more visual appeal that it does a great plot, story and character development. And much of the script is fairly bland. This is certainly entertaining, but as zombie movies go there's not a great deal to chew on here.
summary: Creative with a certain sense of style, otherwise average zombie flick
Title: World War Z

reviewText: The movie starts as any other. But if you pay attention to things around you and keep moving, you might make it. Title: World War Z

reviewText: As a big zombie fan, if we watch World War Z, knowing it's intended to be a PG-13 movie, we'll know right away this isn't going to feature the blood and guts like any R or unrated zombie movie you've seen. Would it have been more drastic and horrifying with gore? Probably, but what is not seen and imagined can also be effective (see the original Texas Chainsaw Massacre).Keeping that in mind, WWZ delivers on its intentions. Put yourself in the shoes of the lead character, and you're cast into a hellish world where a sudden outbreak of "rabies" as they first called it, spreads like wildfire in the cities, causing havoc all around. In a desperate effort to escape the horror, Pitt's character's goal is to get his family to safety, and in doing so, is obligated to find the origin of the disease that has taken over the entire world.WWZ is tension filled most of the way, and fills the screen with overwhelming amounts of zombies in some very unique and original ways not often seen in a zombie movie. These zombies are dormant shamblers when not stimulated by movers. But sound instigates them, and they sprint to "life", attempting to bite anyone who can serve as a host (which brings up a major plot point by the way). The ending sequence closes the film brilliantly, requiring some clever tactics along with agility and speed, as the zombies tend to amplify their ability to run and leap, oftentimes, jumping off rooftops, smashing to the ground, getting up and continuing the chase.Zombies Locations: Major City, Israel desert city, airplane, night time airport, day time airport, apartment building, Research Facility with white painted walls (which would have been perfect for some blood if this was R).3D: The 3D in WWZ looks very dimensional, with visible pieces that bring depth at a higher level you'd expect a 3D film to render it. A success in 3D, which also increases the dread of each horror scene. In addition to the powered 3D dimension, there are many instances where objects pop out of the screen, worthy of a good flinch back.Movie: 4.8/53D: 4/5
summary: WWZ 3D Review: Cool Zombie movie and 3D
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This movie is a must own. Very cool and I highly recommend it to any action or zombie movie fan!

reviewText: If there's going to be a zombie apocalypse, this is surely what it will be like. The story was a little uneven and a bit too contrived in places, but the cinematography and special effects were fantastic, so overall it was a good couple of hours spent. Pitt did a great job with the script, as did the supporting cast.One of the things I didn't like was that, no matter what country Pitt ended up in, or what kind of foreign national he was dealing with, the other person could always speak English, or there was someone there who could interpret into English. How often does that happen in the real world, much less in a world overrun with zombies, and chaos everywhere? I have a hard enough time calling customer service at (any major retailer) and getting someone who can even speak pidgin English. But, things are different in Hollywood.....Also, Pitt's weapon for a good part of the movie is a rifle -- which is better than nothing, but if you're going to be dealing with zombies, a shotgun would be the better choice. Not only from a practical standpoint, but also from a movie standpoint: zombies just splatter better with a shotgun.

reviewText: Overall, the movie is a lot better than I expected, despite some weak areas in the story (which is why it's not a 4). I was impressed.The movie follows a young family, as a zombie breakout occurs and they struggle to make it out of the city alive. Then cue the extra layer in the story where the Dad (Brad Pitt) has some ties into some higher ups because of "other" work he's that wasn't at a desk.I was impressed with the action scenes and the edge of your intensity of this story.  It had some weak areas in the story though, some things that could have been stronger (the family relationships namely), better character development, and some areas of the zombie stuff seemed a little lacking for me.  But it was good acting (I question some of the casting though), great VFX and fantastic action scenes with a story that totally pulled me into and had me glued to the TV.I'd watch this movie again, and would buy it.

Just sit back and enjoy the movie.  The FX are really good and some of the unspoken of plot elements (the nuclear explosion) are quite good. reviewText: It's kind of a fun what-if type movie but really just doesn't bring anything to the table.  The number one killer of this movie is the same as practically any kind of horror movie (though this is more action than horror)-predictability.  Brad Pitt does a good job in the lead role, but it's the stereotype of an action hero who can fight anyone and eventually uncovers a solution no one else can.  Watching it you know the end will be Brad Pitt figuring out a puzzle the world's top experts can't.  And that's exactly what happens.  A guy who's basically a glorified cop figures out a medical problem the world's top doctors can't?  There's also a lot of unfilled holes in the plot.  How did Brad Pitt know the people the zombies were ignoring were infected with terminal illnesses.  Why did the zombie in the plane stow away and wait?  Max Brooks himself says a zombie has no mind, it simply acts to spread the virus, and virtually every zombie in the movie acts like that.  Why was one intelligent enough to wait for the right moment?  There's more but I won't submit them all.I'm not saying it's a bad movie, I did enjoy watching it.  But I am saying it's just another superhero action guy main character saves everything, nothing more.  So watch it, enjoy it.  Just don't expect any plot twist you haven't seen a thousand times already.  You WILL know everything that happens before it actually does.One final note, I expected Max Brooks to at least make a cameo.  Let down there.  Would have been cool to see him in the movie based on his book (which I admit I haven't read and other reviews don't seem favorable to the comparison).
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Pretty much after all the hype and watching the movie all you can say about it is "meh". While like with most zombie movies you know there really isn't going to be a real great deal of thought on the plot or characters and for the most part that's what happens in this movie. It feels like a mixture of 28 Days/Weeks later,I Am Legend and Dawn Of The Dead mixed into a blender and renamed World War Z.  The effects are good but in some cases seem overused and over the top some other times, the characters again aren't bad but their stories have been played over so many times that you can pretty much read what they're going to do before the actor/actress says their lines.If you have time to kill and don't mind going to see a zombie movie this is a alright choice but keep any expectations of any real original characters,story or plot out of your mind.

reviewText: ...so, we should agree that Zombies (not the 70's musical group) are all the rage.  The CG effects are awesome, never swa so many human bodies, blown up, shot, twitching and twerking, yeah...twerKing, (I think).  Amazing flights of human athleticism, done by the 'un-dead'... great camera and special effects work, over loud and boring music score. lousy script (yes, you can guess what the character is going to say)  Pretty much a sophomoric attempt at a disaster movie, using a lot of production money, and a big star... I suspect he was paid very well... the visuals are great, the rest of it, well, not so much... unless of course you are really into ZOMBIES... and I am not done with it yet, after 2 nights of viewing, I still have the last 30 minutes to view, maybe... and this movie was HUGE... oh boy, I am really out of the cultural loop...

I have to, no choice, rental was not an option some have to,get my money's worth from this one. Lol. It was good though. You should be adequately entertained if you like zombie movies and are in the market for one you've never seen before,
Title: World War Z

reviewText: ehh... Well it's a ok zombie movie if you like wham bang action scenes.  Not that inventive.  It feels fairly generic and is full of typical hollywood action sequences.The way the movie is structured does not flow well.  It feels like it's built around 3-4 key action set pieces that are patched together loosely.  I could probably draw a 5 frame storyboard that depicts the entire movie.I am reading the book now and it's barely related.  I am not faulting the movie for that, I am just warning people I guess.  The materieal would have been hard to adapt correctly no matter what.If you like action instead of tension in your zombie movie this may be your thing.  Brad pitt is alright too so i guess if you need to complete your brad pitt bluray collection pick it up.
summary: world war z the movie is a movie with zombies and actions
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Found myself figgity and looking over my shoulder for a few days after watching this.  Not normally my type of movie, but I did like it.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: It was - surprisingly - very enjoyable.  I actually put my phone down to watch without distraction!  It is a zombie movie, like many zombie movies, so you have to love this type of movie.  BUT - there is a stronger focus on the story rather than on the gore and walking dead aspect, so my husband was willing to watch and enjoyed the movie without rolling his eyes. There is also something elaborate about the world travel and world reaction to an epidemic virus.
summary: On the edge of your seat
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This was a masterful movie. The acting was amazing. Shot for shot it was artistic and stylistic. The drama and action will have you on the edge of your seat for almost the entire movie. My only real beef is, for a zombie movie, they sure don't seem to have that much to do with zombies. Sure there are hordes in the streets in the beginning. Hordes in Jerusalem, a small handful in the WHO building, but they don't seem to have much actual focus on them. This is purely my opinion. I personally would have liked to see more direct zombie action, especially in the set up. I thought the WHO action was perfect. I just think with such amazing...everything else...5-10 more minutes of zombie carnage...VISIBLE zombie carnage...not horde trampling zombie carnage, could have really added the last little "horror" aspect that I personally felt was missing. Again, I think the movie was phenominal, this is just a zombie horror movie fans opinion on what I think could have made it just a little bit better. Still if you are looking for a little less gory, more...tame...pg-13 horror film, this is an absolute must. You can not miss with this movie!
summary: I want to give it 4.5 stars, but they don't let you
