Title: World War Z

reviewText: World War Z(released June/13)stars,among others,Brad Pitt,Mireille Enos,James Badge Dale and Matthew Fox.This is a film that seemed to have alot of potential, but it was saddled with a been-there,done-that script and a star who virtually snoozes his way through everything.Pitt has no more charisma or the feeling of a leading man than any of his costars do.He is totally vanilla.The story introduces us to Pitt,his wife and two children.They are stuck in traffic in Philadelphia,when their vehicle mirror gets ripped off.As he steps out to investigate an explosion in the distant goes off.Then a traffic cop on a bike comes by telling Pitt to get in his car.Just then a garbage truck runs the cop over.Pitt follows the truck and is eventually fleeing towards Newark,away from.....? There Pitt contacts the Secretary of the U.N.who will send a helicopter to rescue him and his family.The family is eventually spirited away to a ship off the New York coast.It seems Pitt was a former forces member who the Navy wants to redeploy to help them with this sudden outbreak of a deadly virus on the human population.Pitt takes a team to Korea,with a virologist in tow.The virologist is killed and there is no credible lead there as to the nature of the viral outbreak anyway.What is left of the group flies next to Jerusalem.The city is under siege and has erected a wall to keep the zombies out.They got tipped off by some intelligence just before the outbreak.While there Pitt witnesses a Muslim group,brought into the city,celebrate over loudspeakers.The loud noise attracts the zombies outside the wall who try enmass to enter.(the scene in the trailers showing this human wave trying to climb over each other up a wall,is that moment).The zombies enter the city and it is a mad dash to leave by plane.Pitt and an Israeli soldier make it onto an airliner.The airliner flies them to Wales and to a World Health Organization outpost.During the flight a zombie has got aboard somehow and it has infected just about the entire plane.It crash lands in the Wales countryside.Pitt and the soldier make it to the WHO compound.The compound itself is under siege by some of its own former staff.The ones left figure out that the zombies don't touch those that are lame or sick.Pitt manages to make it to a section of the labs that has some pathogens stored there.Pitt injects himself with some and he is able to walk right by them untouched.This leads to a viral serum being developed which gives the armed forces a big advantage in containing the threat and Pitt is reunited with his family in Nova Scotia.Not only is Pitt so utterly vanilla in this picture,the film has quite amateurish S/FX.Any scene,such as the zombies climbing over each other to scale tall walls,like the Jerusalem scene,are terribly fake looking.On top of this,the film just cannot strike a moment where it can generate any level of excitement or tension for any length of time.Technically speaking the film is in its w/s a/r of 1:85:1.There are no specials.All in all this movie is the Pitts,and that's where alot of the blame lies for its feel.He holds any modicum of emotion in check and thus exudes no enthusiasm from the viewers perspective.The film itself has a second rate script(seen it all before)and it fails in its own job to create any excitement.Go watch any Resident Evil film and get some proper zombie kicks,not this RE wanna be.Zzzzzzz.2 1/2-3 stars.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I was pleasantly surprised by this movie. It is an intense action romp and I highly recommend it for all fans of the Zombie genre.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This movie is nothing like the book. You may enjoy it if you haven't read the book yet. With that said, the zombies are the result of a viral infection- just like in '28 Days Later'. IMO, this is a weak effigy of that movie, at best.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I was very much looking forward to seeing this film, but ultimately found it to be a somewhat average and mildly entertaining work.  There was nothing particularly special about it.  And, unfortunately, all the better scenes are in the two-minute trailer, so there's nothing really surprising about it.  The storyline dealt more with investigating the medical/biological source of the "zombie" affliction than the zombies themselves.  The zombies, in fact, felt like a plot device to drive the investigative angle of the story - nothing more.  For that reason, I found the film a bit disappointing and would not be interested in seeing it again.  I'm not even sure that I would be all that excited about a sequel, which is 100 per cent certainty.  Overall, I'd call this a tepid entertainment.  You won't want your money back, but you may wonder if it was well spent.
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I found myself entertained by World War Z, even if it had nothing to do with the book by Max Brooks (which I thoroughly enjoyed).  At the same time I found myself comparing it heavily to "28 Days Later", which it mirrors quite a bit (fast zombies, rapid onset of infection, rapid breakdown of society).  In fact with the last acts of the movie set in Cardiff, Wales, the comparison got even stronger.Make no mistake, this is first and foremost an action flick; there's no deep thinking involved, no "oh wow!" moments, nothing deep.  It starts up quickly and ends quickly and in between is a thrill ride and nothing more.  In short, an entertaining two hours.
summary: An entertaining action flick, if nothing like the book.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: 5 STARS! World War Z is so good. I've watched it three times. You know the premise probably. The world is over. The dead walk the earth, but in this case they run super fast and infect you. Most zombie movies are about survival and sadly most of the cast don't make it. You endure a whole lot of body munching, screaming, and gore. In World War Z, you move past that because there is no survival for anyone if they don't figure out how to neutralize the zombie infestation. So it's a mystery wrapped in an apocalyptic thriller. If you've always wanted to watch a zombie flick but were scared of entrails all over the place, this is the movie for you. Plus Brad Pitt is so very awesome in it. He rocks, and tries to save the world. I love him.
summary: Not your typical zombie horror, think zombie mystery
Title: World War Z

reviewText: An extremely impressive entry in the zombie genre and for me easily the best such since 1977's Dawn of the Dead. WWZ may break one of the supposed rules of the genre in its almost complete absence of gore but Brad Pitt's film more than compensates with an efficiently plotted linear storyline that remarkably shows no obvious signs of its troubled production, a spectacular sense of scale, a satisfactory balance between action and emotion rare in summer blockbusters and an often intense breakneck pace.There's a lot that I liked about WWZ, from the way the film utilizes its fast moving zombies as a symbol of the often frightening speed and density of everyday life, to supporting characters who are introduced only to be killed off without any of the bombast you'd have had to endure had the movie been directed by a Zack Snyder or Michael Bay. The emotional heart of the story - UN hotshot Gerry Lane's (Brad Pitt) relationship with his wife and kids - feels refreshingly damped down rather than overblown, believable without being schmaltzy. Rich and famous he may be but there's an interesting grounded quality to Pitt. Casting him as an Everyman sort of character doesn't seem like the kind of stretch it would if you had the likes of DiCaprio or Tom Cruise starring.The story is a ground-breaking amalgamation of zombie horror and one of those plague stories in which the hero is charged with finding a cure. The plot, which sends Gerry from Philly to South Korea, to Israel and then Wales in pursuit of the infection's source, never feels like it's just marking time.  Each location holds a clue and by the time Gerry figures out the ingenious solution en route to the film's climax the story tops even that by forcing our hero to make a virtual life or death decision. The payoff includes what might be the most well earned and enjoyable onscreen drink since Ice Cold In Alex.The action sequences are sensational with the (rightly) much talked about Israeli siege a standout. The chaos which leads to a hectic chase through narrow streets covered by a wire fence over which swarm countless zombies leads to an even more claustrophobic showdown inside a jumbo jet. The film is genuinely unnerving, often tense - especially the final third - and sometimes jump out of your seat scary. All without any bad language or explicit gore. There's a lesson there.Littered with unexpected touches - the viewer's shock at a would be suicide jump by a certain character who fears he's been infected and can't bear to see his family in danger, a female Israeli IDF soldier who becomes an unexpected ally of Gerry's and who isn't saddled with a lame romantic sub-plot between her and the star, a nuclear blast viewed from the cockpit of a plane in which no words, no explanation are offered and don't need to be (at this point in the movie it truly looks like game over for mankind) and perhaps best of all a last act that eschews the empty spectacle of so many summer blockbusters and goes instead for a tense, low-key and genuinely intimate climax that I'm happy to acknowledge had me on the edge of my seat.But perhaps best of all is the film's underlying message, epitomized by an Israeli who tells Pitt's character that 'For every life we save, it's one less enemy we have to fight.' This is a movie about the end of the world that unlike so many other zombie films shows people refusing to retreat into small survivalist groups but instead doing their best to save as many lives as they can. It does not surprise me in the least that World War Z has defied months of hostile online sniping to become a big box office hit and I'm very happy it has. Highly recommended.

reviewText: If I had fully realized when I turned this clunker on that it was a zombie movie I would have found something else. As a fantasy movie with big star names and a lot of very glitzie computer generated aspects, scenes and features, I suppose this isn't terrible. The dialog is reasonable, but most of the characters with speaking parts of some sort don't really show the kind of stress that the tale of zombie hordes should have evoked.  This is an excellent movie of its genre, suitable for eight or nine year-olds who like scary movies, or perhaps those adults who suffer from severe intellectual and emotional development issues who believe that this sort of fantasy-garbage could actually take place. After thinking about it for a while, I have decided the only really good thing about this movie was that Brad Pitt probably got paid more than union scale.
summary: A Zombie Movie?  Really?  I must have been asleep at the switch.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Based on the book by Max Brooks, “World War Z” is a gripping, adrenaline-pumping thriller about a worldwide zombie apocalypse (a phrase that is fast becoming one of the most overused in modern pop culture).Brad Pitt plays a retired UN employee, now stay-at-home dad, who barely makes it out of Philadelphia alive with his wife (“The Killing’s Mireille Enos in a largely insignificant role) and two little daughters as the zombie attacks spring up seemingly out of nowhere.  Because of his previous experience maneuvering through arduous situations, he is sent out into the world to find answers as to how the plague may have started and to discover what possible remedies there might be to keep the human race from literally devouring itself into nonexistence.These are not the shambling, foot-dragging zombies of the Romero films or TV’s “The Walking Dead.” They’re not only fleet of foot but are able to scale seemingly impenetrable walls by piling one on top of the other like a cheerleader pyramid on steroids (in their speed, they actually have more in common with the creatures in the “24 Days Later” series). This may make them a lot harder to outrun, but it robs them of some of the creepiness we normally associate with the zombie figure.Because the movie is done on a global rather than intimate scale, it lacks the haunting, soul-searing dread and emotional desolation of a work like “The Walking Dead.” In contrast, “Z” feels more like a grand action movie but, even as such, it hits all the right notes. Thanks to Brooks’ beat-the-clock scenario (adapted herein by Matthew Michael Carnahan, Drew Goddard and Damon Lindelof) and Marc Foster’s full-throttle direction, the audience rarely gets the chance to relax the muscles, as we hurtle right along with Pitt from one close-call encounter with a baffling, seemingly intractable enemy to the next.Not all that memorable really, but entertaining while it’s going on.

reviewText: I loved the fact that this movie, which came under intense scrutiny during its arduous production phase, emerged as a great popcorn summer horror movie.  By focusing on the humans in the story, and creating a few incredibly effective set pieces (the apartment building; the plane; the medical center), World War Z may not be the book, but it's a very fun, very scary movie that grabs hold from its first horrifying moments. Brad Pitt plays the everyman lead with expressive appeal, and the narrative, while sometimes ridiculous, never fails to provide some surprise that adds to the tension and thrills as it moves swiftly to a predictable conclusion.  Bravo!

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Mildly entertaining in an exaggerated, beyond credible way.  A zombie infestation drops upon the world like an unexpected thunderstorm. Brad Pitt stows his family aboard an aircraft carrier and flies off, first to South Korea, then Israel, then after a plane crash somewhere else. Details are unimportant. Brad figures it out and, due to his prowess and the script, saves the world. A touching family reunion follows. It's like eating junk food, momentarily satisfying then you wish you hadn't.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: In the spirit of most zombie movies, there's a pandemic that is spreading through human bites breaking skin. While the premise is believable, the pace of the action and the fact that the zombies aren't shuffling slow but incredibly fast means the movie just flies by going from action sequence to action sequence. Brad Pitt's character is left without having a lot of his background filled in - we are told that he's essentially a "special forces" type who is brought back into service to escort a virologist to the suspected outbreak source to find Patient Zero - but a shocker of a development leaves him alone to do the investigation himself, flying from military hotspot to hotspot to gather the info. At some point, they abandon the search for Patient Zero in an effort to just find some answer for how to contain the spread of the disease - a very current proposed solution (which was a nice twist) provides a very good sequence of scenes that make the entire movie totally worthwhile - but the ending is one of those which sets up a potential series of movies to continue the storyline further (I don't know if what is left of the story is worthy of continuation, but that's another topic for discussion...). Fun movie, really enjoyed it as a light evening's entertainment.
summary: breathtaking visuals - the story is fine as well
Title: World War Z

reviewText: While I love a good action sci-fi thriller, I set aside the sage advice of my former AP U.S. History student, Matthew Normand, who in response to my criticisms of "Avatar," said, "Colonel, park your brain at the door of the theater and just enjoy the movie."  Forgive me Matt, but I cannot help myself.World War Z (WWZ) would have been much enjoyable for me if Brad Pitt had paid a bit more attention to detail on various aspects of the story.  While I embrace the concept of zombies, the rapid contamination in a matter of seconds from zombie to human was unrealistic.  Given that rapid rate of infection, how did it spread from India to Korea without sending up red flags all over the world?  For that matter, how did it spread across oceans to the U.S.?  What did the zombies eat?  It appeared that their only motivation was to infect others.WWZ should have used some other organization than the United Nations.  The UN has no robust standing military command structure or forces.  A much better and more plausible scenario would have been using NATO instead of the UN, replacing the UN deputy secretary general with the U.S. vice-president, and casting Brad Pitt as a former member of Seal Team Six.While I respect the Mossad, I question how they were able to take unbelievably rapid action in response to a radio intercept of an Indian general reporting fighting the "undead."  The Israelis ability to construct a wall around Jerusalem before the onset of the zombies strains credulity.  What would have been the reaction of the rest of the world?  I also found it unfathomable that the Israeli Defense Force (IDF) would not have complete and solid surveillance on all parts of the wall to prevent surprise attacks like the one that scaled the wall.  Although I know from my 30 years in the Army and three trips to Israel that female IDF soldiers are tough, I find it hard to accept that Segen did not go into complete shock following the traumatic amputation of her bitten-hand by Brad Pitt to avoid the spread of the contamination into the rest of her body.  Then, only four days later, she was able to conduct strenuous tactical operations in the W.H.O. facility in Wales.  HOOAH!!!How they got to that facility is also troubling.  Civilian air travel would have been shut down long ago, and I doubt that the wall around Jerusalem would have included the airport.  Surely, WWZ could have used some other aircraft than a commercial one from Belarus Airlines.  No explanation was given as to how the zombie that suddenly appeared in-flight managed to stowaway on the aircraft.  Kudos to Brad Pitt's quick action in using one of Segen's hand grenades to blow a hole in the side of the plane that sucked out the now infected zombies.  Amazingly, in the resultant crash (conveniently within walking distance of the W.H.O. facility) those two were the only survivors except for one zombie still strapped in her seat, but she does not count.  Brad Pitt is certainly one lucky puppy in that he, with virtually no formal medical training, was able to select and inject himself with the pathogen that would make him undesirable and thus virtually invisible to the zombies.The rant is almost over.  WWZ had no closure at the end other than Brad Pitt muttering some philosophical balderdash or platitudes (take your pick) about how although offensive action is now possible against the zombies it not the end, "not even close."  Please spare us from a sequel.Despite my pointing all of the above to her, my highly intelligent 15-year old granddaughter wants to see the movie again.  Although I love her, I will pass on accompanying her for an encore viewing.
summary: Special Effects Do Not Overcome Flawed Story
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Fun, fun fun with zombies. Brad Pitt was perfect for this role, I heard there were massive rewrites, in this case they worked. It had a grea spin on the zombie mythos (working together to achieve goals, watch the storming of the city walls in Israel), grim faced military, sadness, and a nice twist with those the horde thought was dead. There is so much zombie literature and film available, including some surprisingly good stuff (I read/watch this to entertain, not tax the brain, Clive Cussler performs the same role). "Juan of the Dead" (Mexico) and "Rec 3" (Spain) are recent discoveries with nice details and surprises. But I digress, I liked this so much I rented it twice. Don't tell my wife.......

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Never read the book first off, so no comparison. The movie is one action packed scene after another. These are not The Walking Dead zombies, these things haul - I like that. Pitt is superman in the movie, no regular human. Got an airplane stuck in your gut, give me three days and I will save the world. It's a movie, enough said.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: We don't watch zombie genre movies, such is our predilections. However, this movie skirts the edges of the issue and serves up tense multi-national action that has some albeit spurious logic and is ultimately entertaining.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I wanted to see this in 3D in the theater, but didn't get the chance. Actually happy I didn't pay all that money and ended up renting it on Amazon. I don't think this movie would have stood as good a chance if it wasn't for the name of Brad Pitt. He's such a good actor, but the story line felt very scattered. As soon as a character is introduced, they're offed. It felt like lots of pieces of other movies (the specialist looking for a cure, was dead before I knew it; the military guys at a zombie hot spot, and just not enough screen time to be of any signification, I already don't remember most of their dialogue for their 5 minutes on screen; then there is the specialists where Brad comes across a solution, not for the Zombies, but what people can do in order to fight these hysterical, rabies like zombies who run, leap, and hurl themselves, and go from human to zombie in under 12 seconds.  I know this was a movie with different time constraints, but it did make me appreciate the Walking Dead's story telling. If you are more of an action than story telling person, this movie "runs" with very little sit down time.
summary: Fast Paced, Good Effects, Thin Plot Line
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This review is for the unrated version.  This was a surprisingly good movie!  Once you realize that the zombie pandemic is a metaphor for anything that can take over humankind very quickly (disease, politics, religion, etc) it become very intriguing.  Edge of your seat action throughout with fantastic effects and some very good acting.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I loved this movie, good story and great action, plus there's Brad Pitt so I mean.... No difficulties in purchase or download, so I do recommend amazon movies.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This is one of those movies that you must want to have fun with, it's not a movie to provoke thought. It's ridiculous, yet intense, much like a nightmare. I watched and thought, man this would be awful even though it's impossible. That's the whole point, but the good news is that it's entertaining. You worry about the characters, you don't want them to get infected. You're rooting for them to survive. It's exactly what I would want from a zombie movie, sadly it's PG-13 so it's limited on what it can show. That's good and bad, most zombie movies over do it with gore which I hate. I liked the subtle violence. It's a lot of exploding and running, impossible getaways, and silly plot. That's what you watch a zombie movie for, if you went to a zombie movie expecting some psychological thriller, then you need to be slapped awake. This is for fun, not for thought! Intense headshot action! Enjoy it for what it was meant to do.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: First two acts are a hyperkinetic rampage, the infamous -remade- third act slowed down the pace but is quite a good nexus to a future second movie... in my opinion the original third act (freaking big battles on moscow and an epic fighting entrance to reach the hero's family) could have made this movie one of the greatest movies of the decade.The unrated bluray add more graphic violence (out of screen on theatrical release), no big changes but adds to the movie a better fit into the zombie gender. Recommended to any movie fan but not for hardcore zombie fans.
summary: Not so new twist on zombies + overall ok plot + action packed = WWZ

reviewText: I like Sci Fi but not necessarily zombie movies.  I mean basically if you've seen one zombie you've seen them all. Zombies haven't changed much since I was a kid.  However, I really liked this movie. It made some scientific sense.  Brad Pitt does a great job (nothing new there) his wife in the film annoys me but then when people are stupid in movies it's because it's in the script.  I'd definitely recommend this particularly to Sci fi fans even if they are not zombie movie fans.
summary: Pretty good for a zombie movie
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I gave this movie 2 stars because I didn't like it. My review will hopefully help you decide if might/might not want to see this movie, it is not about fairness, it is my opinion but perhaps helpful.Fundamentally the movie could not make up its mind between gross horror flick and science fiction apocalypse of the future. Had it been one or the other then I might have liked but it didn't and I didn't like it. The movie is well done though and great special effects and decent acting but complete lack of plausibility. That is the problem, totally implausible that a virus turns humans into zombies. There has never been recorded a case of a person becoming a zombie so that is where I fault this movie. Had the victims become insane or homicidal or aggressive then the movie might have been a little more realistic. Or had it been a real horror zombie movie then that would have been ok. But it tries to make zombies a real threat to our future, ludicrous to say the least. The other problem is that our hero survives impossible situations time and time again and then saves the world. To me this movie tried to portray this viral outbreak as realistic yet goes way overboard when getting our hero through situations that are simply impossible to survive. I won't give away any parts of the movie but the last time he survives another impossible situation it was ridiculous. The other problem I have is our hero's look, long scraggly hair, beard and overall does not look like the character being portrayed.However, if you are a Brad Pitt fan then you will probably like this movie. If you believe in apocalyptic movies then you might like this movie. If you can ignore plausibility then you might like this movie.But if you want a good horror movie then probably not going to like this one. If you want a realistic future apocalypse movie, then probably not going to like this one.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Brad Pitt. Umpteen million extreme close ups still did not make up for this 'disaster' movie.  You can't even suspend the belief you tried to suspend at the beginning.  Almost fell asleep before the end but I wanted to see that pileup of 'Zekes' and how that happened.  It wasn't horrible, just slow to develope into a coherent plot.  The plot was very, very hard to swallow.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This movie is incredibly intense! If you're looking for a normal "zombie" movie, this isn't it. It has zombies and can be quite creepy in places, but it's more intense than anything else. I had to own this one b/c it's so good. Brad Pitt's acting is incredible, and the movie was absolutely wonderful. I enjoyed it very much!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: World War Z stars Brad Pitt and is (loosely) based on the book of the same name by Max Brooks. Pitt plays a former United Nations investigator who hunts down a solution to the sudden zombie plague wreaking havoc across the world.The first thirty minutes of the film had me on the edge of my seat, cringing and wondering how the rating was only PG-13 instead of R. It's very intense with heart-pounding suspense and chase scenes. Though, unlike other zombie movies, the focus isn't gore. Which is good as these zombies are FAST. And they can turn others within seconds of biting.I had few expectations going in, other than knowing it was nothing like the book. So I was pleasantly surprised with the solid characters and story. The acting is outstanding. They did a good job making us care about the characters while so much is going on. World War Z is a global apocalypse meets zombie thriller.WORLD WAR Z Blu-ray/DVD Combo Pack Includes:Blu-ray:* Feature film in high definition (Unrated version)* Origins--The filmmakers discuss collaborating with renowned actor/producer Brad Pitt to create a Zombie film the likes of which have never been seen.* Looking to Science--Explore the scientific realities of Zombie behavior in nature and learn more about Zombies in literature and film.* WWZ: Production- Outbreak--Go on set with Brad Pitt and director Marc Forster for a behind-the-scenes look at the film's breathtaking first attack in Philadelphia.- The Journey Begins--Delve deeper into Gerry's fight for survival during the dramatic escape in South Korea.- Behind The Wall--Explore the epic scene in Jerusalem and discover the incredible logistics of creating the elaborate stunts and crowd sequences.- Camouflage--Experience the final confrontation between Gerry and the Zombies and discover the phenomenal scope of the film's production.DVD:*  Feature film in standard definition (Theatrical version)- Review previously posted at SciFiChick.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Not terribly exciting or particularly good.  I heard the book was good but this was not a great movie.  Glad I only spent a couple dollars on the rental.  It was ok, nothing was terrible, just a bit bland and boring.

reviewText: This movie IS NOT THE BOOK, (very, very good read it), but don't let that deter you from enjoying it.  The zombies move too fast, the infection is too "instant."  But  this film is way excellent in its own right.  Everyone in it is wonderful.  Brad Pitt is beyond awesome!  This is an  A List film based on a C list version of an A list book.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Just straight up fun to watch.  A bit of a different twist on the Zombie movie.  Don't come into this expecting the meaning of life.  This is a Zombie movie.  Just entertainment.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This one left me kind of bored. Which is a terrible thing to say about a big budget zombie apocalypse movie. Something of this scale and subject matter should leave you amazed or disgusted or terrified or all of the above, but all World War Z does is turn the zombie apocalypse into a 'meh' procedural. There are some cool scenes, but they all culminate toward a small dull finale. I've read they underwent massive reshoots, due to problems with the ending, and I think the ending they went with does work in a narrative sense, but honestly I wouldn't have minded a stupid ending if it was epic in scale. Example: "Umm...Zombies don't like the color blue", then show a massive zombie battle. That way you could leave the theater saying, "That was dumb, but did you see that crazy zombie battle at the end!" That is a much better senario, than what we're left with, which is just 'meh'.
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Me and my wife were impressed with this thriller that was not gory. Much like the style of the old Alfred Hitchcock movies.His belief that the audience can imagine much worse then what can ever be shown on screen is true in my opinion.Ironically at one point where it could've been very gory, it was actually funny because he was trying to get the crowbar out of the zombies's skull offscreen.We waited a long time to find the theatrical version on Blu-ray.This movie does a great job of showing how people, cities, and different nations would react to a serious global pandemic.We have read the book and it is superior, but the movie did a good job of catching the feel and did credit to the book.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I hate to say anything bad about a Brad Pitt movie, so I won't. This a a stand alone movie that has NOTHING to do with the MOST EXCELLENT book. I guess they didn't care much about the reaction of the fans of Max's book. The book was a very well documented telling of the takeover of a virus/epidemic from several viewpoints. This had none of the humanity of what the reality of the book was trying to convey, given the fictional nature of it. This movie is all action. That's it. It IS an edge of your set popcorn movie. The "wrap up" is a clever plot twist. But if you're looking for even a loose adaptation of the book...be aware, the only thing the two projects have in common is title.
summary: This has nothing to do with the excellent book of the same name.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Since the appearance of The Walking Dead zombies have been a hot topic. I think it is pretty clear that this film uses that situation to its advantage, but the similarities end there. World War Z brings to the table a few things I really enjoyed. First, these are not your typical zombies, none of that slow relentless walking, here we get zombies that are fast and agile, with relentless being the characteristic that makes the former really scary attributes. I also liked the suspense injected in the plot in terms of what is causing the zombie outbreak and how to battle it. But most of all, the cinematography is truly visually stunning. It is extremely hard to describe with words the enormity of this production, you will have to watch it to understand.The story is entertaining enough and Brad Pitt does a very good job in his role as a UN investigator that had retired but is forced to jump back into the fray to get protection for his family. There are many situations in which you will find yourself on the edge of you seat since you know a zombie will jump out soon. There are several gruesome scenes, but it being a zombie movie I assume you could have guessed that.I won't say this is my favorite movie ever, but I do think it has some qualities that make it worth watching. It is certainly different than anything else out there. If you are not too squeamish, I think you should give it a try.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: The Unrated Cut runs about 7 minutes longer than the Theatrical Cut, and primarily contains additional action shots (nothing major).  Director Marc Forster has said that the Theatrical Cut IS the Director's Cut, which also unfortunately means that we will not be seeing any footage from the discarded Battle of Moscow (except for a few quick scenes in the closing montage) and the Matthew Fox subplot.The UNRATED Cut is the one to get!  It contains slightly more gore (but not gratuitously so) than the Theatrical Cut, and the action scenes are more fluid and less choppy.I've listed the primary differences between the Unrated Cut and the Theatrical Cut below.  Note, SPOILERS follow below, so read at your own risk.1) When zombies are shot/stabbed/curb stomped/etc.., they spew CG black blood.  When people are bitten, there's more CG red blood.2) During the opening scene in Philadelphia, there are more scenes of pandemonium and zombies getting shot and/or biting humans.  The segment with the red T-shirted male ("Here comes the Number 12 Train...") being bitten and transformed into a zeke is longer and more violent.3) At the NJ Mart, when Gerry is looking for albuterol for his daughter, the camera pans down to show a dead body lying in a pool of blood, suggesting that the pharmacy employee shot him.4) The chase scene from the alleyway to the apartment is longer and more harrowing.  Gerry headshots a zombie and shoots a few others, also crushing a security guard zombie with a filing cabinet.  In the theatrical cut, this zombie chase scene is instead used during the Lanes' early morning escape to the apartment's rooftop.5) The escape scene to the apartment rooftop is now longer and more violent.  Gerry bayonets, shoots, or rifle butts many more zombies.  In a surprising twist, Tomas saves Gerry from a zeke, rather than Gerry himself shooting the zeke in the theatrical cut.  Matthew Fox's parajumper character also shoots a few more zombies and there's more zombie blood when they're shot.6) When Dr. Fassbach trips and accidentally shoots himself in the head, the wound is more graphic.  Chunks of his back skull are blown into the air and gore covers the exit ramp of the C-130.  Although this description sounds graphic, the camera cuts away quickly so that only brief glimpses of gore are seen by the audience.7) David Morse's character graphically pulls out his last remaining tooth in the Unrated Cut.  This is not shown in the Theatrical Cut.8) The Battle for Jerusalem has additional action shots.  It's now a thrilling and intense sequence in the Unrated Cut!  More IDF soldiers shooting zekes, more zekes biting people, grenades blowing up zekes, etc..9) When Gerry cuts off Segen's hand in the Unrated Cut, we see the bloody stump as well as geysers of CG blood.  This is definitely graphic and not for the faint of heart.10) The zombie attack on Belarus Airways is now more intense with passengers getting bitten left and right.  There is more CG blood too, but nothing too explicit since most of the shots are very quick.11) Gerry takes down a few zekes in the WHO facility more graphically.  He clotheslines one zeke with a crowbar and stomps on the face of another.  More CG black blood.Prior to watching World War Z, I had mixed feelings about the movie based on the trailers I had seen.  Fast zombies?  Blasphemy.I ended up enjoying the movie, even with Damon Lindelof's rewritten third act.  The ending on a quiet, but hopeful note was a better conclusion than the rumored Battle of Moscow.  The idea of using a temporary, but curable disease as camouflage was a unique plot point.  Can't wait for the sequel, even if it has very little to do with Max Brooks' original books.
summary: DIFFERENCES BETWEEN THE UNRATED CUT AND THE THEATRICAL CUT
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I anticiapted this movie for a few months assuming with Brad Pit as the leading man it would be a decent show, especially since its a Zombie flick.. *********MILD SPOILERS******** This movie starts quick and is fairly smart, It breaks from the normal mold of zombie flicks, and thats a nice change.. Brad pit is smart and measured in most everything he does, its clear he's a thinker just as soon as this show gets going it gets into a fairly smooth progression, I liked that. If your looking for a gore fest look elsewhere as this movie spends more time on suspence and story telling and alot less time on Zombies and gore. The story brought me in, hooked me, took me for a pleasnt mystery suspence ride.. and then towards the end it fizzles..  I get what scenes in the movie are suppose to be the climactic ending but i feel like they are a letdown. The ending in general was a letdown. Mind you im not saying it was a bad movie and if we could do halves i would have rated it at 3.5 However we can,t and i dont feel this movie deserves a 4 star rating.  The previews are deceptive and thats onother one of my gripes..This movie felt a lot like "ARGO" only a zombie flick..  it was never very exciting,however it wasnt boring.. i think it did ok up till the last 15 minutes then it just fizzled..
summary: This is a very tame zombie flick..
Title: World War Z

reviewText: The movie was definitely entertaining, but it required a lot of suspension of disbelief, even aside from the zombies.  Several problems:1) You CANNOT fly unrefueled in a  C-130 from off of the East Coast to Korea.  Even if you did, the flight would be VERY long.2) Why would Israel be so wise as to build a wall, but then be so stupid as to not have people watching from the top of it so they could mow down or burn the zombies trying to climb it?  Why wouldn't they have noticed the affect of sound and told people to be quiet?  What are the odds that this noise and zombie attack just HAPPEN to happen while he's visiting?3) It's seems highly problematic that a dead body could turn to a zombie in seconds and also that he would appear "sick" enough to avoid zombie interest just minutes after injecting a virus.
summary: Pretty entertaining, but requires a strong suspension of disbelief.

reviewText: Do you like the fast zombies of28 Days Later/Dawn of the Deador the traditional slow zombies ofNight Of The Living Dead/The Walking Dead? I'll take my zombies however they're given to me. But if you're particular about your zombies and you like them traditionally "undead" versus the rage-disease pandemic style zombies, then you might have a bone to pick with World War Z. I've seen some passionate zombie fans scream bloody murder if you even call a rage-diseased person a zombie. "Zombies are only people that have died and come back to life," the naysayers will tell you. WWZ takes care of the issue by knocking down a human for about 12 seconds before coming back as a zombie without ever really explaining whether or not the person actually "died" before coming back as a fast-rage-undead-zombie. Hence undead and rage fans should equally enjoy WWZ.......Until mid-way through the movie. The first half of the move is very well done actually. The zombies are some of the most terrifying that I've ever seen. Brad Pitt is a former United Nations investigator. When the world is suddenly turned upside-down by a rapidly spreading zombie infection, Pitt is reluctantly recommissioned and travels the world trying to find the source to potentially find "a cure." The initial outbreak scenes are awesome. Pitt plus family's escape from a city gone mad is wild. And Pitt traveling from country to country to find the source is vicious-zombie-filled and thoroughly entertaining. Then comes "the crash."I'm not a big fan of spoilers, so I'll just use the aforementioned "crash" reference to indicate the point in the movie where a jump the shark moment occurs taking the movie from believably great to unbelievably gimme-a-break territory. Once the movie jumped the shark it became not only silly at times but also predictable.So all in all the movie is half great, half not so great resulting in a 3-star flick. Worth checking out, but check your brain at about the 75 minute mark.
summary: Crashes to the Ground Half Way Through

reviewText: Fast action, reasonably good acting, clear storyline and logical conclusion of the dramatic sequences. All in all better than many of the "Genre's" typical fare IMHO! Brad Pitt has come into his own, and needs no help from Giggly females in barely concealing attire to keep our interest nailed to the screen, with action flowing. Brad's Co-star was not known to us, but she and the wonderful children actors/actresses did superb jobs as credibly "scarred s***-less" almost victims in at least a dozen breathtaking moments as the Movie's initial plot unfolded in the first ten minutes, among Philly PA's always scarey "street scenes". Worth an hour or so on the edge of a seat in our home theatre, streamed or otherwise  brought to your screen!
summary: Brad Pit blazes though Philly PA's always Scarey Streets! Hang onto your Seats, look carefully for Z's seated next to you!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I know that movies rarely resemble the book -- but this movies should not have even been named World War Z.  There was absolutely NO build, no beginning, no end --- just one big, flat middle!
summary: Very Disappointing -- especially after reading the book
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I am not a fan of zombie movies as we are being drowned in them right now but this movie surprised me.  It was more a study of the characters than just the mindless zombies.  Also the speed of the zombies was a nice twist.  I still am not a great zombie fan but did enjoy watching this film.
summary: Better than most but I am not a zombie fan
Title: World War Z

reviewText: There are a few thrilling sequences, especially near the beginning as all holy heck breaks loose in Philadelphia (the city of brotherly love? Not anymore, heehee!). As a red-blooded femme I don't have complaints regarding the presence of Mr. Brad Pitt in the leading role - so handsome! But his spouse, played by a very excellent actress named Mireille Enos, is short-changed with a role that begins as important and slowly dries up. A metaphor for the female life cycle? Perhaps. I know they included a femme soldier who is brave (up to a point), but even she seems to vanish following a hairy episode aboard a jetliner. I enjoyed her performance too!When they say this is a "popcorn movie," boy do they ever mean it.
summary: I'm wondering why no strong femmes are featured
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I liked this very much being a war nut. The action was good and the story plausible with the one exception that burnt to ashes the Zombies could come back to life. It seemed showing them to use flame-throwers way down the line too a mistake.
summary: For once Hollywood nearly got it right
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I liked World War Z a lot more than most zombie movies (and I love anything zombie); this movie keeps moving forward with a plot, opposed to other zombie movies which have a bunch of characters just trying to survive and doing a poor job of it.  If you've read the book it definetly isn't like the book.  The book followed a bunch of different characters as the coped/survived the zombie apocalypse, while the movie is more about the beginning to the apocalypse... but still very good in my opinion!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: After seeing the trailer for this movie, I could hardly wait to get it!!  Well, the wait is over and boy was I completely and totally disappointed in this 2 hour trip to no where.  If you want to see a bunch of running zombies getting shot in the head over and over and over again, from all angles, then this is the movie for you.  But if you like movies with suspense and a script that makes sense and characters you can get to know and, oh I don't know, maybe substance and entertainment, then this is one of those movies you can just pass up and forget about.  First thing I did after I finished watching this was to give the DVD away to someone I know who collects movies for the sake of collecting.  I didn't even want this one taking up room on my shelf.  Too bad, because it looks so darn good in the trailer.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: the story line is average, the cgi is kinda cool and is what makes you finish the show.  but the zombines moving at light speed? kinda loses any sense of reality when they run faster than cars.  once "infected" with whatever it is, they become almost magical in physical abilities?  the CGI kept me watching at the show until the end
Title: World War Z

reviewText: pretty standard zombie film with speedy zombies instead of the slow movers. pace was decent, probably the strongest element of the film. acting decent (Brad Pitt is a star for a reason) and everybody did a good job acting-wise as far as I was concerned. two story weaknesses for me were having the Israeli soldier very physically active post-amputation, that was highly unbelievable (this is a zombie film, but still), and also the antidote wasn't believable, but, overall, didn't suck. I turned it off after the amputee was physically able to get Brad Pitt's character to their destination post plane crash, but I was able to return to the story to see the last act.  It could've been worse...

reviewText: It was a good movie in my opinion. I would recommend this movie. Makes you think that something like this could really happen.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: All my many reviews focus solely upon the actual quality of the film from Standard Def DVD quality to the higher standard set for Blu Ray. Summaries of the plot and opinions of the story line and acting can be found in the majority of the other reviews so I do not want to be redundant.  In this case, I did not see World War Z in the theaters nor did I have the Standard Def version prior to buying this film on Blu Ray so the review is just about the quality of the video and audio on BR.Keep in mind, however, that the quality of what you see and hear is also dependent upon the quality of the TV monitor you are watching on as well as the home theater set up you are using. The monitor I use is a fairly new Panasonic ZT 65" plasma and the amps, speakers, cables, BluRay player and Surround Processor I use are hi end esoteric gear to provide me with a more realistic and objective perspective.VIDEO....The video quality of this film varies.  All of the film is beautifully presented with deep blacks and excellent contrast.  At no point did I see any artifacting, dropouts or haloing from the many CGI effects. I also saw no banding in the many sky shots which is where banding can often be seen.  Color grading was fairly natural with excellent skin tones and slightly saturated colors.  The color grading did vary from cool for the night shots to an overly warm grading during the scenes in Israel.  For many films shot in the mid East, the editors produce an overly golden color correction.  Not sure why this is as that is not the what you actually see when in the mid East. Maybe they think that the desert is always of a golden color.  The mass rush of CGI zombies goes so quickly in its many scenes of this type that the zombies themselves are often a blur of movement rather than a detailed depiction of each zombie running by.  This blur obviously causes a loss of detail.  Details for the real actors and actresses however are sharp and defined even in the shadow areas.  The average Mbps rate appeared to be in the mid 30's and, overall, the quality of the extended version on Blu Ray was really very good.AUDIO...I love that there is a 7.1 lossless DTS HD MA audio mix which the film defaults to. If your system is still a 5.1 system, not to fret, the additional 6th and 7th channels will be muxed to feed into your 4th and 5th rear channels without any issues.  The lossless audio codec provides clear and transparent dialogue and the audio levels are set so that foley fx does not step on the dialogue.  Once you set your volume control you will not need to go back to it to readjust for roller coasting audio.  I did watch this film on a 7.1 system and there is excellent use of all channels for panning between the left and right and front and back audio stages.  The 6th and 7th channels are not given specific foley sounds to reproduce but add a more expansive and immersive theater experience creating a wide field of ambient sound.  Discreet directionality between the channels is more often than not used for larger audio occurrences rather than a cup falling to the floor on the right stage.  In other words, not too much small foley fx but more for larger crowd and helicopter type foleys.  There are a couple of scenes that produce some of the deepest bottom end for your LFE channel that I have ever heard and your sub will get plenty to do throughout the film.  5 stars for the audioEXTRAS....The one clearly negative thing about this Blu Ray is that there are 3 previews of other films. You are paying for their advertising which takes up room on the Blu Ray calling for even more video compression in order to fit it all in. Who wants to pay for an advertisement ? Not me, I'd rather have an improved video transfer with less compression.Other than that, this Blu Ray has plenty of excellent extras.  Often I find the 'Making of ' documentaries to be rather boring but this multi part documentary on the writing of the script, the creation of the CGI work, Stunts and more was really very interesting and included brief and on going narratives with the writers, actors and producers.  Also included is a small section on the scientific basis for zombism and it symbolism in the real world.  There is no on going commentary while the film is playing.The Digital copy offers 2 choices between downloading to iTunes which I am doing as I am writing this and Ultra Violet which I have never liked.  First I went to the UV address and entered my code, email address and password..all properly...UV said my email address was not valid, weird since that is the only one I ever had.  Just don't care for UV.  I had no problems at all putting in my Digital copy of the film and redeeming it on iTunes.I do hope that this review, which focused solely upon the quality of the actual transfer to Blu Ray has been of some help to you in deciding your purchase. All of my reviews are of this nature and I hope they can be of HELP to you as well.Thanks for reading.
summary: World War Z on Blu Ray +DVD+Digital Copy
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This is the first zombie movie I can remember seeing.  I highly enjoyed it.  Great picture and sound on the blu-ray disc.  Im glad they did an unrated cut.  Would still like to see the Battle of Moscow at some point, perhaps in a sequel.

reviewText: i saw the trailer for this a few months back and was totally excited about it. i finished the book a few days ago and was even more excited about the film adaptation. i saw the movie in the theater yesterday and...wow. what a let down. almost entirely different than the book and not in any semblance of a good way. there were so many scenes and details in the book that would have made for incredible big screen excitement, something this film completely lacked. bummer.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: In my opinion these were the most realistic zombies I have ever seen. Because physically and psychologically that part of our brain that makes us have fear or personal safety was gone in these specimens. They would slam into each other in doorways and corners to get to their victims. They would climb over each other and jump off roofs, even through windows to get their targets, Truly real life Undead Killing Machines. I loved the movie and have always loved alot of Brad Pitt's stuff from Interview with a Vampire, Ocean's Eleven and SEVEN as well as others. I like the wife because she was scared but she wasn't a screaming basket case and the female Israeli Soldier that traveled with him. I definitely would tell anyone to watch this movie and I myself will probably watch it again.
summary: Best Zombie Movie in Along Time

Title: World War Z

reviewText: If you like zombies and epidemics, you will probably like World War Z. That's about the gist of it.It actually feels like it was created by kids. It has lots of imagination, but little reality. You're really going to have to have the ability to suspend reality to get into this. But, if you like zombies and epidemic movies, you're halfway there, right? I prefer sci fi or paranormal type movies because they are way scarier because they COULD be true. There is no way that anyone would ever believe that this could happen the way it played on screen, so it wasn't the least bit scary.The acting was okay. Nothing to complain or write home about. The scenes were okay. The zombies looked like dumb zombies. All in all, it was on the dull side of alright. It wasn't horrible, but i wouldn't see it again.

reviewText: I am not into the whole zombie craze whatsoever but my eyes were glued to the screen (when I wasn't hiding behind my hands in sheer fright). I found the reinvention of the genre to be refreshing - zombies moving superfast and infecting people within seconds. This movie moves thrillingly fast - no time for your heartbeat to calm down. Most of the movie had me on the edge of my seat but in particular the sequences in the apartment building, the Korean landing and takeoff, and the lab had me jumping around in anxiety. The Jerusalem sequence was also visually stunning. This movie is up there with Shaun of the Dead & Zombieland in terms of unforgettable.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: First of all this film has nothing in common with the book by the same name other than the name of the protagonist and the zombies.  Note the book is called World War Z not Brad Pitt's Zombie movie.  It really is Brad Pitt's Zombie movie and unless they actually complete a sequel and have at least one scene from the book they should just abandon the whole World War Z premise altogether.  Having said all that I loved this movie.  I saw the rated cut version in the theatre and enjoyed it as well as it was completely new material bearing absolutely no relationship to the book I had just read.  Now it's been months since I've seen that theatrical release but if my memory is correct, and it probably isn't, I don't recall the final few minutes being in the original.  Those minutes showing the battle in Moscow.  Those who read the book know what I mean.  And that was a nod to the book and a promise to create a sequel which may, if it's a trilogy, make what they did in this novel perfectly appropriate in its vision.  I love me some zombies and this franchise is a totally different take on the genre.  The rule of thumb in the genre is that humans lose.  They spend the movie trying to survive only to find out survival is impossible.  In World War Z the message is the opposite.  We are nearly defeated but like in Independence Day we ultimately survive.  How this franchise gets us there will ultimately determine whether it's World War Z or Brad Pitt's Zombie Trilogy.Now that we went there, for fans of the genre, wasn't it just a bit of stolen thunder that the director chose Philadelphia as the place from which the story begins (sorry directors, I95 has never been that empty of traffic) considering Justin Cronin's "Passage" Trilogy is slated for filming and one of the best, most important, scenes in the Passage is the outbreak in Philly.  At least the director of WWZ didn't use 30th Street, that would have been too cheesie.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Another Zombie movie. 50 years of zombie movies. Kinda hard to have a very high expectation of a new zombie movie. Surprisingly, it delivers on the suspense and there are some limited good special effects. Every thing else is just kinda the same stuff. For whatever reason, it reminded me way too much of I Am Legend and Outbreak. Admittedly, I am not a zombie movie buff, but this movie begs me to ask a question: I know we are to suspend disbelief when watching movies, but it bugs me that the characters here point out that the zombies are dead bodies, not living tissue, so they can't be infected with another bacteria or virus, but no one ever asks how such a dead body is able to move and run way faster, and longer than a live body and how they can defy gravity and physics and every other law that live bodies adher too. Blah
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Brad's not on a role with his script-picking these days.  Killing Them Softly had some good moments, but was basically gibberish.  Now the zombies take over in World War Z and with little explanation, Brad is the only one who knows the special formula for saving the human world.  The great '50s sci-fi movie War of the Worlds was more interesting and credible than war of the Zs.  This is just a stupid movie and I'm really sick of the zombie thing.  Rent if you must see, but don't spend $$ to own this thing.  You'll never want to see it twice.

reviewText: I really liked the movie.....great premise, acting, special effects, plot, etc.....but was distracted throughout by Brad Pitt's slovenly appearance and matted, filthy hair. I can understand looking like a homeless derelict when you're portraying one, but when you're supposed to be a happily married, dignified former UN investigator with two sweet, young daughters, for God's sake, take a bath and clean up your act!SPOILER ALERT: I honestly think Brad could have walked safely among the zombies without the vaccine. Let's face it, if zombies discriminate between victims who are healthy or ill, they are definitely going to avoid one who looks (and probably smells) like he's been dead (and buried) for several days.Again, this was a great movie that provided all sorts of thrills and chills, but it was burdened by the revolting appearance of the 'star'. This became an issue in "Legends of the Fall", when Brad Pitt's disgusting lack of hygiene was publicly condemned by his cast mates. I guess some actors carry enough weight that they can simply show up and behave any way they want in a movie, like Marlon Brando in "Missouri Breaks", but when their appearance and behavior begin to seriously detract from the overall performance, it's time to wake up and smell something other than greasy, filthy hair......like roses, maybe.Let the flaming begin.
summary: Good Movie, but the Scariest Part was Brad's Filthy, Matted Hair.........
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Acting 5/10special effects 6/10Plot 5/10Overall entertainment 4/103D 2/10Yes, it is another zombie/apocalyptic movie. Although the zombies are presented in a different way (smarter or with stronger survival instincts), it is not enough to make this movie stick-out from the rest of the zombie movies/TV shows already in the market. The 3D is completely unnecessary and overused.The plot has some minor twists but basically is another story where the survivors try to escape the zombies and find a cure. And of course there is the "revelation" that the only way to kill the zombies is by shooting in their heads. Yes, it is full of cliches.
Title: World War Z

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: The world ignores the signs of global disaster and the next thing you know there is a world wide zombie (closer to rabies) pandemic. The incubation period is 12 seconds, yet somehow the infection was able to be transmitted by airplane to the entire world. I am still scratching my head on that one.Brad Pitt,who is now a family man, must save the world to save his family. There is some background noise that would indicate the zombie outbreak might be caused by how man destroys the environment and ignores the signs (global warming, wink, wink, nudge, nudge.) The world is thrust into anarchy, while the military exists.Brad must look for the original virus somewhere in the world to find a cure. We discover N.Korea is unaffected because they pulled everyone's teeth. Israel is unaffected because they have a great wall around their country, but apparently cold isolated places like Greenland are infected. The only reason I point out these inconsistencies is because the film writers went to great length to make the film realistic. Oh yes, if you have a lot of people on a ship, they share beds and sleep in shifts.I enjoyed the film more as a pandemic film than a foot dragging, flesh eating, living dead, rotting zombie film, because that is what it was. I would say if you don't like Brad Pitt, don't see this film. There is very little screen time that doesn't show his face. Should make for a good video game and a decent sequel.Parental Guide: No f-bombs, sex, or nudity.
summary: MOTHER NATURE IS A SERIAL KILLER

reviewText: World War Z must have one of the shortest first acts in film history. The first act, usually the first half hour is generally where the conflict is introduced. This film opens with Gerry Lee, Brad Pitt, a former UN investigator having breakfast with his family. Five minutes later, BAM, zombies. No time is wasted getting straight to the conflict. Begin second act.The story is not complicated: zombies take over the world and Brad Pitt is obliged to save the day. The assault of zombie movies over the past few years has been such an onslaught that by default the genre itself now gives me an automatic feeling of “I don’t care.” World War Z is very much another zombie film, but a damn exciting one. Even the script’s description for becoming a zombie, turning Zeke, is subtlety refreshing.“It’s not what you say but how you say it.” With cinematic excellence, Director Marc Forster breaths new live into this tired cliché. It’s all in the delivery, and WWZ definitely delivers.As Gerry Lee (Pitt) travels the world trying to solve the mystery behind the infection causing people to turn “Zeke,” the scenes that unfold during his expedition are so exciting that story arc is incidental in comparison. A memorable scene is when a military commander becomes infected. He’s got about ten seconds: “I’m a goddamn Zeke…I got this one boys.” Then, he puts a bullet in this own head.The exotic set designs of the adventurous locales are the highlights of the film. First an adrenaline pumped escape from an infested Philadelphian housing project, then to a US navy ship at sea, then over to a US military base in Korea where a massive fire fight breaks out. Next Lee arrives in Israel where the citizens have protected themselves against the Zekes in a totally ingenious, but vulnerable walled up construction. The set design here is just incredible and when the situation goes awry, and things start blowing up, the visual effects are some of the best around, bar none.Errata: Brad Pitt picks up an Israel solider sidekick along the way. They are both the sole survivors of a horrific plane crash. How convenient.In 28 Days Later a single drop of infected blood causes a subject to turn into a zombie. In WWZ Brad Pitt gets Zeke blood in his mouth and doesn’t turn. This fact is acknowledged early in the film so we know this fact for the remainder of it. There doesn’t seem to be a single, recognized method of contracting zombieism.Interestingly there is a real drug called Tetrodoxin that is supposedly the closest thing to an actual zombie-causing agent in existence.Get more at getthebonesaw.blogspot.com
summary: Great, Fresh take on a tired Genre
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I knew when Brad Pitt bought the rights to the book he would ruin it. World War Z is a bloodless, mindless, not remotely scary bore.Without getting into spoilers there are moments that should be scary or suspenseful, but are actually very very funny.Marc Foster should never have been allowed to direct a movie after Quantum of Snoring, and Pitt is as wooden as ever.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Possibly one of the most hyped zombie films since the 1968 "Night of the Living Dead" is "28 Days Later" and having seen both of those iconic movies along with countless others I can confidently say that "World War Z" easily outranks `em as far as pure entertainment and not to mention it's truly epic.Hey, before ya press the "No" button under "was this review helpful?" listen to my case.What WWZ has:  Brad Pitt (this is coming from a non-fan btw) who is not only ridiculously handsome as always but a good enough actor to make us believe he's a post-apocalyptic special envoy for the U.N. and a pretty tough survivor type to boot.  Action... and I'm not talking about stupid, Hollywood over-the-top fluff but riveting events which we can get caught up in without eclipsing the underlying story or defying credibility (not too much anyway).  Zombies par excellence! This is how the undead should look and I'm totally ok with them occasionally moving at leopard speed or building zombie pyramids cuz it all fits in with them no longer being human.  And finally, a great script aided by a filming style which enhances the overall level of dramatic intensity and allows the viewer to take this story seriously.When I think of all the cheesy and terrible zombie films made over the last 30 years and yet try to view WWZ as its own production rather than through the lens of past genre benchmarks then I must give it a 5 star for the reasons I've already mentioned as well as originality.  :o)

reviewText: Zombies are overrunning the film industry, because it's easy to drool and stagger and there's no need to motivate the characters. First, there's an infection. Then, zombies spring forth drooling. After that, everyone runs and fights, and kills and dies, and the only thing let is to see which characters survive, if you even care by that point.Because it is a Brad Pitt movie, the production values are good and the acting isn't awful. But the plot isn't any better than the original NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD. The one difference between this and every other zombie flick is how computer-generated effects turn a few zombies into hundreds and thousands, with lots of screen shots from afar showing infected throngs of humanity overtaking the world like ants, climbing on top of each other to scale walls and buildings. Even Brad Pitt fans will get nothing out of this.Just buy an ant farm, instead. It will be more entertaining and you will get something for your money.
summary: HOW MANY ZOMBIES DOES IT TAKE TO MAKE BRAD PITT DO A ZOMBIE MOVIE?

Title: World War Z

reviewText: **spoilers**First, this film bears absolutely no resemblance to the book of the same name. The only thing they have in common is the existence of zombies, the title, and the worldwide scale. This film could only be remotely like the book if it were told in a documentary style with interviews of the various people. This film is basically Brad Pitt (Gerry) goes around the world kicking zombie butt and looking for a cure for the zombie plague. In order to review it more objectively, I am going to pretend the movie isn't called World War Z and put aside all my expectations and hopes based on that title.World War Z is an interesting film that brings up concepts I haven't seen before in zombie films. There aren't many that focus on what the government does during such a situation. Gerry used to work for the UN and he is basically told to help them find a cure or his family can't stay in the safe housing anymore. He flies all over the world chasing the origin of the disease and narrowly escaping death at each locale. The suspense is well done and builds in the right places. My favorite scenes were the zombies in the airplane and the claustrophobic journey through the WHO lab. The zombies are frightening and super fast. The solution at the end is temporary, but effective. Gerry notices certain people just don't exist to the zombies. He theorizes that those people survived a deadly disease and thus are an nonviable host for the zombie virus. This is proven true when he injects himself with a random disease in order to go bypass the zombies and return to his team with the diseases to test the theory. The film ends with a vaccine being made of a lethal pathogen to render the general public invisible to zombies. It isn't perfect and it isn't the end, but it's a good place to start. I like that all the ends aren't tied up with a nice bow. The theory makes sense and isn't something I've seen before.The film has a lot of flaws. I've ranted about it before, but I really don't like fast zombies. It doesn't make biological sense for their muscles and tendons to be magically invincible and able to take the stress over long periods of time. World War Z takes it a step further and makes them swarm in an insectile way using bad, cartoony CGI. It just looked horrible and made me roll my eyes. The film is PG-13, so although there are numerous zombie attacks, there is very little blood and gore. I'm not just being a gorehound here. It's a realistic part of being in a zombie apocalypse: people are torn apart and eaten everywhere. I felt like I was watching a watered down or censored zombie film. The zombie virus takes hold quite fast. There really isn't enough time for a person to board a plane and go somewhere else to spread that the disease. It just doesn't work in the scope of the narrative. The characters were less than compelling. Gerry only agrees to help save humanity because his incredibly generic family is threatened. I'm not sure if he thought that through, but his family is included in all of humanity. The situation with his family also makes the film just like every other disaster movie ever. It was frustrating in a lot of ways. It just goes to show that being the most expensive zombie film ever made does not make automatically it a good film.Overall, the film was ok: nothing spectacular and definitely does not live up to the hype. The novel is clearly superior on all possible levels. I would watch the sequel to see where it goes next, but I don't anticipate greatness.
summary: Ok film if you forget the amazing book it was based on
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: The ultimate success of this genre depends on the viewers "willing suspension of disbelief."  Very hard to do when:1. Zombies take over the world at light speed.  The entire city of NY NY falls in about a half hour, yet Brad Pitt and his family manage to escape.2. A former "UN Envoy" (Brad Pitt) is portrayed as a James Bond like character that the US military, the Israeli government, and the CIA come to for answers.  Not the UN from real life.3. Israel is able to keep the zombies out by building a 40ft-plus ft high wall around their entire country.  Then the zombies climb up on each other to form a human mountain of undead flesh and scale the wall.4. Pitt's wife call him on an iridium phone while he is in South Korea investigating the source of the zombie outbreak, and while he is surrounded by zombies just waiting to take him down. The call is so he can say goodnight to his kids. Pitt narrowly escapes, several of his comrades are bitten and become zombies all thanks to his wife's naivety...  and Pitt doesn't even bother to tell his wife not to call him again, while he is involved in operations.I could go on and on. If you want pulp action and are a fan of zombie movies then by all means watch this.  Don't expect to laugh, cry, or feel like you are there, however.As someone who both loves action sci-fi, but also realizes a well done movie may be done by artistically representing something like an old man fishing from a boat and nothing more (as in Hemmingway's "Old Man and the Sea), I have to say this movie is not well done on either end of the spectrum.  I stopped watching it after 45 minutes--something I only do about once every 5 years or so.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: When the first World War Z book was published it took young readers by storm and climbed to the top of the New York Times Best Sellers list. It was destine to become a movie, especially now, with the popularity of zombies, but ultimately, the highly anticipated film fails to deliver anything different. U.N. Employee, Gerry Lane (Brad Pitt), is out with his family when a recently discovered virus hits the United States and all hell breaks loose. The first 45 minutes of this film were literally like the pilot of The Walking Dead. No one knows what's going on, people are panicking, it was all very predictable. The film does go into a different direction after that, but how many different ways of doing a zombie film are there? Lane starts traveling the world seeking a cure for the disease, while at the same time trying to avoid being attacked. The unfortunate fact is that no matter how good the acting or the writing, there is very little you can actually do with a zombie film. The zombies and the circumstances behind the outbreak are always a little different, but ultimately it becomes about survival or the race to find a cure. Brad Pitt is terrific, and as I have been saying for year, it doesn't matter how good looking the guy is, he belongs in action films! This is the genre where he excels and even though World War Z was painfully predictable, Pitt makes it worth watching. He is the focus of the story and it takes a lot of quick thinking and tremendous stunts to keep him alive. For me that was the best part of the film. There was a lot of hype behind World War Z and it was a very intense film, but like I said, there is very little you can do with an end of the world/zombie film that hasn't been done over and over again. While some what entertaining, World War Z is ultimately just another copy cat.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Granted there are some holes in the plot of this movie big enough to drive a truck load of Zombies through, but all in all its really a cut above your average Zombie apocalypse film. A few notable variations...(Possibly a spoiler alert or two here...)The movie doesn't rely on trying to out-gross other zombie films. (At least in the rated version) No graphic depictions of brains being splattered, etc. Instead it relies on the story to carry it through.The climax isn't a final, bloody battle to the death (Or undeath as the case may be). Instead we get a somewhat quiet and very tense final reel.The characters are all three dimensional. No one screaming "You go out there if you want to but we're staying right here!!" No one going all Mad Max on anyone.Instead of focusing on just surviving, a lot of the plot involves an effort to understand what's happening in a scientific way and come up with a medical solution to the crisis. Its sort of Contagion with zombies.Add in strong performances and you get an eminently watchable addition to the zombie oeuvre. (Mirielle Enos is money in the bank no matter the roll. If I needed an actress who could convey sympathy and intellegence with one look my first three choices would be Mirielle Enos, Mirielle Enos, and Mirielle Enos)
