reviewText: "If you can fight, fight. Be prepared for anything. Our war has just begun." Gerry (Pitt) and his family start the day like every other day. They wake up, eat breakfast then head off to school and work. That's where the day begins to take a strange turn. When explosions happen and people start running no one is sure what is happening. After given safety Gerry is told he must go and find a way to stop what is fast becoming something that could end the world. I have never really been a fan of zombie movies. I really liked Shaun Of The Dead, but I'm not sure if that counts. I have to say that while the movie was a tad slow in a few parts this is a very good, exciting and fun movie to watch. The one complaint with this movie that I have is that it got a little repetitive, but that didn't really hurt the movie too much and the movie was exciting enough to keep you watching and tense almost the whole time. If you are a fan of zombie movies you will really enjoy this. If you aren't give this a try, I did and I enjoyed it. Overall, one of the best serious zombie movies I have seen. I give it a B+.
summary: One of the best serious zombie movies I have seen. Exciting, tense and fun to watch. I recommend this. I say B+.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I saw this film opening weekend and I left the theatre thinking "WOW!". And while normally that would mean awesome it this time meant they screwed up some things. Now before I begin reviewing the film I must state and caution readers I HAVE NOT read the book nor will I (not into novels). Having said that I do love zombies and I do enjoy some of Pitt's vehicles this being one. Now the first thing I find very annoying is the rating. Yes it had around a $200M budget but to me that is not to say it wouldn't have done well at the box office had it been rated R. When a zombie bites someone blood SHOULD be shown and when you see a reanimated corpse running well it should be a bit more scary. The thrills that led this film should have been replaced with suspense. Pitt did an alright job but for a guy who pretty much got this project off the ground well I would have thought his performance would have been more emotional now this isn't to say he was by any means bad but he was a bit disappointing for me. As for the overall tone of the film it was mixed as I previously noted thrills should have been suspense and there should have been some gore (by no means am I saying it should have been an NC-17 movie) and a lot more scares.Now you know where I stand I would like to point out that I am still excited to see this film by seeing the Unrated version in hopes that some of the things that disappointed me will be fixed and I can bump up the rating of this movie at least a half star. In closing if you ONLY want a shoot em', thrill ride zombie flick with pretty good storytelling this film is for you. However if you love Zombies and want a true adaptation (again I haven't read the book but many have expressed that it isn't loyal to the novel) that is gory and scary well this probably isn't for you....yet! There is still hope as I have mentioned...with an unrated cut we hardcore zombie fans might be able to say this is fun and scary not just fun. Until then I will just watch Dawn Of The Dead. Though I hope to add this to my collection very soon. Lastly it is also worth noting this film made some profit (500M+ Worldwide at the box office) so with a sequel or sequels we could very well get a better zombie flick out of Pitt and crew.
summary: Had potential and perhaps still does with the unrated version!

Title: World War Z

reviewText: What would it be like if a major Hollywood studio makes a big-budget zombie movie with an A-list star? The answer is "World War Z" starring Brad Pitt as a former UN investigator trying to find a way to save his family and the world, too. This is a zombie movie without gore and flesh-eating. You may call it the world's least gory zombie movie, or the most family-friendly zombie picture.I haven't read the original book by Max Brooks, but I imagine the source material is pretty different from what I saw on screen. The film is filled with choppily edited action set-pieces involving cars, helicopters and an airplane, that are decent but not special. Anyone who has seen "Quantum of Solace" knows that Marc Forster, who did a great job in "Finding Neverland," is not the right choice for directing action scenes.Anyway, it is obvious that Forster attempts to turn the familiar zombie movie conventions into something different with social and political commentaries (the high walls in Israel in the mid-section action sequence is a good example). Unfortunately, his attempts to address deeper issues are at best feeble, easily overshadowed by CGI-enhanced action scenes that are fun to watch, but ultimately forgettable.And action scenes. Swarms of zombies running wild in the streets or climbing up the wall are at first impressive, but then become a bit dull. Some scenes are physically too incredible, even by the standards of mindless entertainment, undermining whatever serious subtexts (if any) you may read in the apocalyptic tale.In short, "World War Z" is a new spin on a zombie genre - a summer blockbuster zombie movie, which means, ironically, a zombie movie that doesn't bite. This is an enjoyable ride, to be sure, but you may also feel there's something missing in it.
summary: WWZ: Hollywood's Big-Budget, Family-Friendly Zombie Movie (No Gore Included)
Title: World War Z

reviewText: the movie promises to be very good in terms of fast paced action epic drama.  It has a bit of that but the movie needs to end within a given timeline.  the sequence following the initial city-wide outbreak tends to be confined to help solving situation of one individual & its family. Unfortunately this narrow down aspect of the film seems a bit of a rush (looking for an ending) that ;IMO, takes away the explosive climax that one would like to see from any large-screen hit considering the good effect caused by Z -related action drama seen from the likes of the very good "Walking Dead"

reviewText: I didn't feel like this was a good showing for Brad Pitt.  Absolutely loved him in Inglorious Bastards, as well as the supporting actors, so that gives you an idea how my tastes run.  This felt phoned in.  Absolutely no chemistry between Pitt and the actress that plays his wfe to the extent that at least once I wondered why he even cared what happened to her.  Also, I found it a little unbelievable that Pitt's character was the only one in the entire world that could do anything to solve the zombie issue.  The special effects of the zombies were good for the most part.  The speed of a person becoming a zombie was a bit ridiculous, bite to zombie in 10 seconds? At that rate, unless you were on a deserted island, the entire world would be doomed in about a week or so.  Couldn't help compare it to I am Legend (Will Smith) which, IMO, is a much better movie.
summary: So much hype about this movie I guess I expected more from it.

reviewText: My wife and I saw the movie this afternoon and were both impressed. The casting and acting were solid. Pitt did a great job in the lead role as Jerry. The girl who played the Isralie soldier was also very good. Zombies, well played and frightful. Story line developed nicely. Special effects 5 stars. I just wish they had answered a couple of simple and fairly basic questions in the process. First, what is the Zombies motivation to attack and bite humans? It isn't hunger since they don't eat anyone. It doesn't seem to be general anger and rage as other than biteing, they are essentially non destructive to other animals or the physical world around them. Big question: Why do they bite everyone? What is their motivation? As they are mindless - it isn't to keep propogating the infection (they aren't thinking that deeply). I wish that question had been answered. Question 2, as they are dead, why don't they decompose? I'll admit I'm not a Zombie geek, but it would seem normal that their bodies would decompose as they are dead and other bodily functions have ceased. For these and a couple of other unanswered questions, I have to take one star off and give it four instead of five.
summary: Very Good Movie - Needing Just A Bit Of Clarification
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I really hate fast Zombies. This was a great movie based in part on the really great book by Max Brooks (who knew he was such an expert). The actor was first rate and the actors were top notch. Even my kids loved this movie, but they don't like fast zombies either.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This is a well acted, well done movie which switched from place to place too quickly. We didn't get a chance to know the various characters well enough before they were either dead/and or we moved on.SpoilersWhat makes this movie exceptional is the humanity and sensitivity brought to it by the performance of Brad Pitt. I enjoyed watching the family scenes, the love between parents and children was palpable, but I would have preferred they take more time. Whatever happens is more effective when the pacing is slower and more thoughtful.Either make this into a longer movie or decide not to hit so many spots and go through so many characters, bang bang bang.Each of the places visited could have made a movie in itself. Why cram in so much????? Because we the public now have the attention span of three year olds from 20 years ago? Because, thanks to TV, computers etc., I imagine that even 3 year old's today cannot sit still as long as they used to.Sometime try watching and episode of Bonanza, or the Twighlight Zone. What's the big rush?Of course, like everyone else, I get impatient when things go too slowly. I love Rectify, but hate how SLOWLY it moves. I have to wonder what all this fast fast fast imput to our sense does to our brains-and to humanities brains long term. Will we have to be constantly hooked up to some stimulous in order to just get through the day???....wait! That has already happened!Anyway, good movie.
summary: Good movie but covered too much too fast
Title: World War Z

reviewText: It would seem like a "chase" movie to a harsh critic, but I think it was well done. For me, this movie didn't give you any baggage. Didn't waste too heavy on time getting to know you dialogue blah blah...just quick and too the point....like any other day of a typical family, then moving into the shock and horror of the surprise of something knocking you out of a typical usual day. Then it lets you watch a more down to earth version of reactions of government and internal disaster planning from someone who would be on the inside of things. I thought the first time I watched it that I finished sort of unfed at the end of the movie....but then the next day I wanted to watch it again and didn't feel bored or unexcited during action scenes. If I had to criticize one thing it would be at the end when Brad Pitt has to get a vaccine...a little boring and predictable. Still this is probably my favorite movie for 2013 for entertainment....but for some reason movies are getting crappier....including this one.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This is not just another zombie apocalypse movie. This one actually has a story with characters that you will care about and feel for, as Brad tries to protect his family and others from the hordes of zombies that are springing up everywhere.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: I never read the novel, World War Z, by Max Brooks.  Brad Pitt, however, must be a zombie fan because he bought the movie rights in 2007, which was way before The Walking Dead appeared on AMC television.  It took Pitt five years to make the film at a cost of $190 million dollars.  The movie has internationally grossed over $540 million.  It broke even.  It didn’t make a profit.  A film supposedly has to make three times its cost to break even, which is divided amongst the studios, the distributors and the theater chains.Now, because I was unable to see the Blu-Ray edition, which was the extended version of the film with a lot of behind-the-scenes stuff on it, I had to settle for the theatrical version on a regular DVD.  Surprisingly, considering all the negative reviews, I actually found the movie to be understandable and very entertaining.  In fact, I was glued to the television set for the entire length of the film.  For me, Brad Pitt is now the king of zombie movies.The film pretty much starts right into the action with Pitt (an ex-United Nations investigator) and his family getting caught in a traffic jam in the city of Philadelphia.  The zombie epidemic has already spread from Europe to the United States with blinding-like speed (in fact it only takes twelve seconds for a dead person to change into a killing zombie).  Brad’s character, Gerry Lane, calls his friend at the United Nations so he and his family can be air-lifted out of the city.  This does happen, but only after being chased by a horde of zombies to a roof top in downtown Philly.  The catch, however, is that If Brad wants his family to be protected, he has to do what the military tells him, which is to fly into Russia and try to find a cure for the decease.  This is the rest of the movie.  Pitt flies to Soviet Union and then to Israel and then to an outpost where the most infamous deceases known to mankind are studied.Is a cure eventually found for the humans still alive?  You have to see the movie, but a sequel is already in the works.Let me tell you that these zombies aren’t slow walkers.  These handsome fellows can move fast and they take no prisoners.  The special effects of the movie are awesome in my opinion as thousands of zombies pile on top of each other to climb over the wall surrounding Jerusalem.  Remember, zombies can’t be killed, unless you shoot them in the head.I certainly enjoyed the pacing of the movie.  It didn’t really give you time to think, but I liked what Brad Pitt’s character was able to discover and the shootouts with the zombies.  A female Israeli commando is bitten in the arm, and Brad cuts the arm off without any hesitation, leaving her alive, but with a stub.  Fortunately, this woman is one tough cookie and can shoot with accurately with just one arm.Being a big fan of the early George Romero zombie movies and The Walking Dead television series, I found myself impressed with this film and Brad Pitt’s acting.  The whole movie more or less is on his shoulders, and he carries the weight without any problems, displaying his ultimate skills as a truly excellent actor.  He makes this movie happen, and you believe in him and his love for his family.  Mireille Enos (she stars in the TV series, The Killing) is the perfect actress for his wife in the movie.  If Angelina Jolie had been in it, you would have expected her to go after the zombies and kick some real butt.  Not so with Mireille.  She’s the perfect mother hen who watches out for her children, praying her husband will return alive to protect them.I can’t comment on the extended version of the film on Blu-Ray, or the extras that are on the disc.  I do want to see them, but I need to get a Blu-Ray television for that.All in all, I was surprised at how much I loved this movie.  I want to watch it again and see if I feel the same way.  Other people have told me that I’m crazy; but hey, the movie did make over 500 million at the Box Office, so somebody must have liked it besides me.
summary: For me, this was a great zombie film!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: The movie has absolutely nothing to do with the book. Narrative is different and the "solution" in the movie is not present in the book. Also, the geo-political themes in the book are down played quite a bit in the movie. Overall, it's "just" an action movie, and not terrible at that. But if you loved the book, the movie will be somewhat of a disappointment.

reviewText: If you want action, drama, or edge of the seat suspense, this will leave you wanting. The plot is somewhere between  "I Am Legend" and "Outbreak." It manages to fall short of either. I was amazed that Brad Pitt even TOOK this role. I hope they paid him well.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: If you're looking for something completely unique by way of zombie movies, there's little to be found in World War Z that hasn't been done before other than the very intense manner in which the Zombies move like ravenous insane hyper-cockroaches.  World War Z definitely has it's moments.  There are also a few other elements of Z that make it stand out from the crowd of ubiquitous zombie movies.  Is it the ultimate zombie movie?  I'll leave that for others to decide, but I personally have to say, I don't think so.  Is it entertaining?  Absolutely.  The zombies in Z are often truly frightening in the way they move and act and charge en masse.  There are also, as is normally the case with zombie movies, huge plot holes and logical problems that go unanswered, but this is probably to be expected.  After all, who wants to watch an analytical zombie movie where everything is explained in minute detail?  Who gives a rip?  We go to zombie movies for the gore and the spectacle and the inevitable hero, which, true to form, Brad Pitt does very well.  The "final solution" in Z, while unique compared to other zombie movies, is also somewhat lame, but, in the end, you have to have SOME way of dealing these nasty critters.  So you must simply go with the flow.Having said all of these mostly positive things about it, I did find that the World of Z lacks a certain "charm" (if that is the appropriate word) of some of the earlier zombie films, particularly those of George Romero (with Dawn of the Dead being, perhaps, my favorite). There is little or no fun in Z here.  It is a considerably different experience here.  This is not a film you can smugly chuckle at as you watch it.  It is far too serious for that.  When all is said and done, I liked the World of Z and can recommend it to those of you who enjoy this kind of movie.  I would definitely not recommend this flick for young kids; you stand a very good chance of giving them nightmares for some some time to come. There is some pretty intense stuff in this one so if you are squeamish about such things, you might want to stay away yourself.  For the rest of you zombie fans, go see it.
summary: Not new ground here but very entertaining and some great Zombie effects
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Nothing unexpected here.  Brad Pitt is, of course, the hero.  He scrapes through everything by the skin of his teeth.  Very predictable plot and unrealistic.  All the great minds of medicine can't figure out an answer to solve the problem, but 'he' does!  Filled with action.  After all, he's consumed with saving his family.  Brad wanted to make a movie his children would probably like, and he did.  No award nomination here, though.

Title: World War Z

reviewText: Hollywood has decided to build a franchise around World War Z which on it's own is great, unfortunately the effort is both obvious and clumsy.the good: zombies are fast, simple, hard to kill, insatiable, the story encompasses the world, it's epic, and why we are losing makes sense while adding the needed tension.the bad: their is no introduction, the Zombie war just starts, and to be clear this was totally unnecessary in a story that is going to span multiple films especially when the source material laid it all out for the script writers to follow.a hint of where it started using Brad Pitt as the guide, the growth of the threat through Brad Pitts eyes, how it's spread, the moment when it's realized this isn't going to be containable, the distracted institutions pre-occupied in their own affairs... their was a chance here to build a franchise from the ground up that would have been epic.  but alas none of that, one day the Zombies are everywhere and everyone is running or dying, an empty comment is made to explain how the Zombies got everywhere that could just as easily have been missed.how did they suddenly get everywhere without being noticed, it's not like Zombies are stealthy. Thursday all good, Friday the world is doomed.the "solution" is agony incarnate and incredibly premature in a movie that is kicking off a franchise.  the discovery process, absolutely ridiculous!while "the building" was great, getting intimate with zombies undermines the menace of zombies.  WWZ by this point is growing boring which isn't so bad because instead of misleading the viewer into thinking the ending is open they decided to close it making the whole idea of a franchise pointless."look mom, I'm not scared of Zombies anymore"could have been worse but not by much given the money invested. (and yes a simple change will allow them to pump out a dozen films if they so desire but after this one I won't care)
summary: it's a rushed & overdone pilot, not a movie.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I am not a Zombie movie lover anymore, since Psychomania or Night of the Living Dead, but when I saw that freaky scene with all the bezerk infectees climbing the wall around Jerusalem, I thought it might may a good viewing.  Luckily, it was on Prime, so I viewed with no regret.  Decent action, realistic effects and no awkward sex scenes.  The infectees run on high energy, so you might get vertigo at times. reviewText: Was ok, good movies to watch at least once, If you a Brad Pitt fan that helps, good effects and the story was good.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Remove the CGI set pieces (which are over-the-top stunning), and what’s left?  A script that is weak (for non-zombies) and mostly a retread.  The plot ranges from hard to follow to coincidental nonsense.  Simulated action via close-up framing and quick-cut editing rather than in-camera directing.  Tired acting and tired-looking actors (the adult leads are over the hill and show it) mostly phoning in their lines—except for the zombie leads who deliver by far the best acting and most/all of the acting energy.  The sound field is nothing great; camera work is OK (as it appears on video disc); and the film score is fine, but not exceptional.  WILLIAM FLANIGAN, PhD.
summary: More of a disastrous movie than a disaster movie
Title: World War Z

reviewText: After watching and reading about how much of a disaster this movie was going to be, I was pleasantly surprised.  It was a very interesting story about how the world would potentially react to a global crisis.  I thought it was a compelling look at how humans would respond in the face of death caused by a global pandemic.  Ultimately, everyone's survival instinct kicks in.  There are no standout performances.  Brad Pitt was good enough.  I think I liked the performances of all the zombies best, as well as the music.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Not bad as a piece of work.  But, by the 2/3 mark, I'd ceased to even care, watching the special effects instead.  The interplay between the Jewish woman and Brad's character was down played to the point where it didn't mater anymore.  A man with a hole through his belly and out the other side doesn't just walk 20 miles to get to the WHO.  Why isn't he being carried in a travois instead. Then it would have been believable.  It offended my desire to believe in the movie.  Special effect were top-notch, so I gave it a 4 star on that alone.  If you can escape the obvious to "believe the plot" it wasn't bad.  But it escaped my sensibility, so I couldn't give it that last star.  I never realized how frightening chattering teeth could be.
summary: Could have done so much more
Title: World War Z

reviewText: World War Z. The ONE thing that drew me into this was the fact Brad Pitt is in a zombie movie -- so almost by default the script MUST contain something "different" in terms of a zombie flick - right? Well, largely no. The end (spoiler free) had a different ring I suppose but the movie played out like bullet points of a zombie flick, complete with generic military installations. The characters were dull, and while there were a couple of "big moments" (you'll see) it's not quite enough to make up for the lifeless characters and been there done that script. I still don't see what made Brad Pitt do this movie. 6.5 out of 10 (will not purchase on Blu Ray)
summary: Why did Brad do this movie?
Title: World War Z

reviewerName: Wilmar Luna "Author of The Silver Ninja"
reviewText: I'll try to keep this short and sweet.This movie sucks, but it's not exactly boring and it's not exciting. It's below mediocre.Why?In the beginning, the editing and scenes are done so quickly you have no time to develop any attachment to the characters. They try to make Brad Pitt seem like Mr. Likeable stay-at-home dad, but once they hit Philly the zombies start attacking right away. There's no build up or moments that make you go "Oh no! I can't believe this is going to happen to that person!"The family is present throughout the beginning of the movie and then quietly disappears from the middle to the end. So by the time the family gets into its contrived plot conflict, you really don't freaking care. You know why? Because Brad Pitt is already near the end of the movie and there's no way anything else is going to happen to the family.The movie just fails time and time again to make you care about the characters. It fails to scare you, fails to get you invested, and fails to even give you a decent storyline.However, it's not really -that- boring which is strange. There were some scenes in the movie that were actually nicely done and made me pay attention to what was going to happen next. I was very invested when a zombie was found inside an airplane and I definitely wanted to know how the problem was going to be resolved. So when it came to turning a mundane situation into a terrifying one if it happened in real life, the movie did that well.Anything else that involved caring about the human beings going through this ordeal, that's a big fat fail.The zombies are creepy, the make up is well done, the CGI looks fake but is fun to watch, and I didn't hate the movie all the way through.But can I recommend you actually sit down and watch it?The answer is no.
summary: A movie that just goes through the paces.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I don't normally like zombie movies, but this was not bad. it made alot of sense not just a story of zombies out of no-where.. and brat pitt always performs great.. i am a big fan
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I am, however, a fan of good acting, believable characters, and bottomless CGI budgets. And strong, cute women like that buzz-cut Israeli soldier. Oh, it had its weak spots, but pretty much the ones you'd expect of any zombie movie. And I don't think any modern lab dealing in BSL3 agents would take such a casual approach to their storge and access. And ... well, even Shakespeare requires some suspension of disbelief on occasion, so I can't call that a dire flaw.I went in looking for some good summer entertainment and a spot in the air conditioning. I came out impressed by one of the better movies of the 2013 summer season.-- wiredweird, reviewing the release to theaters
summary: But I'm not a zombie fan!
Title: World War Z

Title: World War Z

reviewText: The movie follows the book in a way that it covers a vast space and shows how different areas are handling the epidemic.  It does well in that it doesn't try to recreate the book and takes a more personal story.

reviewText: The ONLY zombie movie worth watching.  It's scary because these zombies are FAST!  Plus, there's a good mystery in it, and plenty of twists.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Trite. Predictable. Thin sentimental plot. Very little suspense. All of the actors and actresses seem totally bored and their characters never develop into anything more than cardboard cut-outs. Sure, Brad Pitt is still nice-looking, but even HE seems lethargic and has giant bags under his eyes. And what a waste of talent to cast the marvelous Mireille Enos in the ridiculous do-nothing role of the faithful stand-by-your-side wife and mom. The entire cast really could have been filmed with low-budget actors because NOTHING and NO ONE could breathe life into this messy ordeal. Honestly, I should have seen this film on the big screen rather than wait and watch it at home--the theater experience always seems to magnify everything and make it more impactfull--almost always, that is.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Is another Zombie movie that has a plot that keeps you engaged if you are into sci-fi movies. Brad Pit does a good job.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I went to see this film the first day it came out, I also saw it in 3D.I'd seen the previews of it on TV and already had a bad feeling that it was going to suck, and it did.All the best scenes if you can call them best are in the previews for the movie.There was little if any blood shown at all and I'm not a gore freak.There were NO ZOMBIES in this film, a zombie is a dead decomposing, rotting human. The so called zombies in this movie were "I Am Legend" CGI Infected people who ran faster than cheetahs.This movie has the wrong title, it should have been World War B (for bad).The very worst episode of the Walking Dead was 10 times better, had more story and suspense than this entire movie had in it, thank Odin I never read the book this piece of trash was based upon, from what I've heard the book was great. I would have been very disappointed if I was expecting it to be that good.This had to be the most predictable story I ever saw.Spoiler alert, Brad Pitt saves the world, what a surprise.TOTAL WASTE OF MONEY TO MAKE AND PAY TO WATCH.Wait for it to be shown in prime time on TV uncut because it should have been rated PG instead of PG13.Hail Odin!!!!!!!!!
summary: worst zombie film ever and should never have been called World War Z.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: The movie was great. Watched with my son and we commented often about what a good job they did. I wont spoil it, and to be blunt we only had an issue with 1 scene. Acting, plot, zombies et al where very realistic and well thought out. I must add that I know nothing of the book. My son did and did not mind this adaptation at all. So go ahead and watch it if your a zombie, sci-fi, end of the world kinda fan. Last comment, almost every time we'd say "you know this would be great if", they beat us to the punch and had it there. Hope you enjoy - Don't recall any gratuitous scenes or some of the more questionable concerns. Not for young kids!!! BTW we rented the uncut version.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: After I finished watching it, I wondered why I had. Brad Pitt maybe? I am usually easy to please. I watch for enjoyment. But this movie gave me none. In my opinion, someone floated the idea of zombies who can out run an Olympic 100 yard sprinter. Okay, that's okay. But usually zombies are slow menacing things with gruesome bodies and faces. What I am getting at is that the zombies of WWZ were a blur. I know this will sound odd, but they had no character. Except for one or two faces shown up close, the rest were running so fast became cyphers, nothing. In the very last fourth of the movie they take on some slow moving qualities, especially when Pitt has to get something from a laboratory. But other than that, this was a one trick dog and pony show that left me thinking that I could have watched the Walking Dead, instead.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Vultures have been circling the lumbering mega-budget production of World War Z almost since the film went into pre-production. First, fans of Max Brook's highly-regarded novel were up in arms when it emerged that the book's multiplicity of survivors' tales was to be distilled into a star vehicle for Pitt. Then news leaked of multiple drafts from various writers being rejected (the film has writing credits for four different scribes). Early trailers were ill received. It emerged that the entire last act of the film (an epic battle sequence) had been junked and fanboy kryptonite Lindelof brought in to write an entirely new ending.With the mood on the blogosphere toxic, the trades and mainstream press piled in as the smell of blood in the water grew stronger. Paramount eventually stopped even pretending the film was not troubled, allowing Vanity Fair to publish an astonishing account of the difficult production - further increasing speculation that this was a $200 million dollar plus vanity project for Pitt and his production company, Plan B.Now World War Z has finally arrived,and if the narrative behind its making is as compelling as that of any of 2013's blockbusters, the unexpected twist ending is the year's most shocking. Spoiler... the movie is good. In fact, it's not just good - it's great.Pitt plays Gerry Lane, a former investigator for the United Nations living with his family in cheerfully chaotic domestic bliss, economically sketched out in an opening breakfast scene that is almost the only moment of calm for the next 100-odd minutes - save that the TV in the kitchen is running disturbing news footage of social disorder breaking out in locations across the world. Driving his family into the city, Gerry gets stuck in traffic gridlock and BOOM! All hell breaks loose as the whole world goes to s***in what seems like five minutes flat and director Forster slams the pedal to the metal for the first of many stunning action sequences.The subsequent globe-trotting story has Lane is drafted back into service for the United Nations to search for the source of the "zombie" plague that within days has brought the world to the brink of apocalypse. The pace is blistering, honestly comparable to Gareth Evans' The Raid, and the scale is as epic as hundreds of millions of dollars can provide. What makes World War Z really work is humanity of its characters. Pitt himself is at the heart of this. To make a film like this commercially viable, it had to have a major star. But Lane is no superman (or Superman). He isn't James Bond, Jason Bourne or Ethan Hunt - in fact, he spends most of the film running away from stuff. Pitt really sells the notion that Lane is a common man in extraordinarily uncommon circumstances, motivated by love of his family to put himself ridiculously in harm's way. I struggle to come up with another male star of his stature that could have pulled this part off.Pitt is in every scene, but around him are a rapidly-changing collection of characters who join only for sections of the narrative. However by canny international casting characters who often have mere minutes of screen time register memorably. Especially good are Enos (from TV's Big Love and the US version of The Killing) as Lane's wife, and Israeli actress Daniella Kertesz (in a nearly dialogue free role). Nowhere is it more clear that the film has been substantially shaped in the editing room, than from the fact that the highly-billed Fox is essentially a blink-and-you'll-miss-him featured extra. Before remarking on Forster's skills remember that when Terrence Malick does this, he's called a genius.Where the film really scores is that despite the fact that it is a "zombie" movie (and unusually one where the reason characters use that term is because they have seen zombie movies), the environments and human characters feel real and convincing. The action has a gritty verite feel while never being less than spectacular. While the threat is fantastical, like Romero's best zombie films World War Z takes place in a convincing world - in this case a distinctly post 9/11 one. One sequence in particular is sure to inspire debate over the presence or not of a geo-political subtext, but I'll leave that for you to discover.World War Z is also often very frightening; despite the lack of gore, this is an extremely intense film and one which parents should be very careful about bringing children to. At the time of writing no BBFC certificate had been announced, but it has received a PG-13 in the US - meaning a 12A is quite possible. This is absolutely not a movie for under-12s, and if you take them, prepare for sleepless nights.The breakneck pace and sheer shock-and-awe of the film's scale paper over a few cracks. What exactly makes Pitt's character the UN's go-to guy is never exactly made clear, and some of the plot mechanics that propel the story from one part of the globe to the next don't quite hold up to intense scrutiny. However, in my view, one would really have to be committed to not having a good time to find these elements overly troubling. This is widescreen filmmaking at its best.World War Z is a compelling reminder that for every troubled production that produces a Bonfire of the Vanities or Island of Dr. Moreau, there is Casablanca, Apocalypse Now, or Blade Runner. I'm not putting WWZ quite in that category - only time will tell - but against all the odds, this is the best blockbuster yet seen in the 2013.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I know I'm watching a good zombie movie when I'm watching the movie and I notice I'm at the edge of my seat and perspiring. World War Z met this litmus test. I had not read the book, and I know many who did were disappointed in the film. But I felt it was a pretty good story line, convincing special effects, and Brad Pitt turned in a good performance as well. It will be interesting to see if they decide to produce a sequel.
summary: World War Z met my Zombie litmus test
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Not a action packed action flick.  It actually has a story and character development.  It is a zombie movie so you have a lot of the same story lines like you would expect in a zombie film.  But it does have its own twist on the story.  And Brad pitt as always great job acting in this movie.  Worth a watch.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I did not expect a zombie movie this good.  I took a chance and got rewarded.  So should you.Cons out of the way first.  Here's the thing: Pitt was the wrong guy to be cast as the lead, in my opinion.  Not because he is not CAPABLE, but because he failed to show any emotion in this flick.  Why?  I have no idea.  The movie provides a few truly frightening scenarios, yet Pitt has that blank stare on his face.  His character is witnessing things that really are thrillingly frightening!  You, the viewer, will be scared.  Pitt?  Blank too-much-Xanax stare.  Someone needs to remind him to PRETEND.  They call it ACTING, Brad.  Remember how excellent you were in Interview with the Vampire???  Fight Club?  Troy?  What happened?The only other con is the family.  They were boring, but they serve as leverage to get his character to act on behalf of humanity.  As with my first complaint, Pitt does not act like a father who is about to lose his children.  A few times he almost loses them, but no tears, no anxiety, no freaking out, no rage?  What the heck is that all about?Other than that, the movie was fun.  The gore level is low, but surprisingly it has no effect.  There's blood.  The undead are insanely vicious.  They act out in ways you have not seen before.  I promise.  The zombies are scary.  Plain and simple.  The trailers did not do them justice.  The CGI is only a part of the experience.The way Pitt's character has to overcome the threat to humanity by observing his encounters with the "Zekes" and putting the puzzle together is inventive.  The setbacks he encounters all involve zombies, and they all are nail-biters.  He has to piece clues to the origin together.  In the process, he discovers a tactical biological advantage over the zombies that is sickening, scary to use, and quite novel.This movie does EXACTLY what a zombie movie is supposed to.  It puts mankind on a hopeless path.  Zombies are everywhere.  Nowhere is safe for long.  Everywhere he goes, zombies are a serious danger.  Every thing he has to achieve--zombies are in the way.  The pacing is like a roller coaster ride: a slow, thoughtful rise to a drop during which characters contemplate and plan and converse, then a swift drop into hellish scenes during which plans go wrong, fail, and things turn WORSE.  Then repeat.In fact, the tale is far from over.  The world is far from safe.  The movie deserves a sequel.  Maybe with a few more committed actors taking the lead.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Fans of the James Brooks novel of the same name might be disappointed that the movie doesn't follow the book closely, but it is a pretty exciting story. I was impressed by Brad Pitt in this film, but there are a few points in this film that leave your head scratching (I.e. a badly timed phone call). I appreciated having the X-Ray feature while watching the movie, which gave some background on plot changes. Basically Pitt plays Gerry Lane, a UN expert who is tapped to figure out why a zombie apocalypse has occurred. Lane races around the world desperate to find the source of the plague in the hopes of finding a cure. His family's safety hangs in the balance in this race against time.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: If you are looking for a good scary movie for Halloween, this might be the best choice.  You will be rivited to your seat in suspension for most of the movie.  The Z stands for Zombie, though they have another name for them in the movie.  Not as much blood and gore as you might expect, but the film doesn't need it.  Go Brad Pitt!!!
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Good story line and well acted and directed.  Great Cinematography.  Without Brad Pitt the movie probably would have found an audience but the other acting was up to par so don't be concerned about it being cheesy.  The concept is as old as I am and it seems the world may someday be consumed by the un-dead but thankfully for guys like the Brad Pitt character the world will always be saved.  There are a few subtle political overtones that someone wanted included in the screenplay but that's okay, what movie today doesn't have an agenda?  I give it three stars because the movie has no redeeming value, (my life isn't better off for seeing it).  It gets a little mundane after a while with the mass number of zombies and there are a bunch, its worth a watch especially since its free with prime, but I wouldn't buy it or care to see it again.
summary: Zombies!!!! Who Doesn't Like Zombie Movies
Title: World War Z

reviewText: This thing is a b minus movie.  The only reason I watched it was because it starred Brad Pitt.  Looks like the movie was based on hiring a name brand lead actor then hoping for the best.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: I was really excited to get this but frankly was not all the hype made it out to be. Would wait and buy at the pawn shop for 3 bucks if I were you. Its worth a look just not 15 bucks worth.
Title: World War Z

reviewText: Yes, I read the book first.  I read the book years ago and it to this day it remains one of my favorite books of all time.  When I heard it was going to be made into a live action movie I was very excited!  If you're expecting to see an exact replica of the book on the big screen, you're in for a disappointment.  The book itself is a sort of anthology, and putting an anthology on the big screen is hard to do in a two hour block.  That is unless you're making "Creep Show"***SPOILERS***  ***SPOILERS***  ***SPOILERS***Brad Pitt does an excellent job acting and the character he plays is relatable and interesting and through the entire movie you're rooting for him to make it out alive and get home safe to his family.If you look closely in the movie you'll see subtle references to the book "The Zombie Survival Guide" that Max Brooks wrote before he did World War Z.  Like when the doctor holds up an ax and a baseball bat and says "Both has it's merits."  There are also references to the book World War Z, like the guy in Israel who talked about the 10th person disagreeing with the other nine because it was his duty.The overall story was good, but there were a few things I didn't like.  Such as making the zombies running zombies and having them shrieking like creatures from another planet.  What was wrong with just making them moan?  They moaned in the book and people loved the book, why fix what isn't broke?  Plus, twelve seconds to turn?  In the Zombie Survival Guide they stated that from bite to reanimation it took a full thirty hours.  But then again I guess that wouldn't make for a very thrilling action movie.Also I was really hoping to see the Battle of Yonkers and the Battle of New Hope.  They were in the book and if you ask me they were the two most interesting parts of the novel.  Plus the movie doesn't really end, it just kind of stopped.  Like they ran out of story and just threw a voice-over in and called it a day.Plus why didn't Brad Pitt just tell his UN buddy what his idea was and then that way they could try his idea out at a facility that wasn't half overrun with zombies?  Not to mention, no one else thought of this idea?  Not a doctor, not a biologist, not a virologist, no it was this guy, a former war correspondent.Moving right along, the Israelis know that the zombies exist and they know they are dangerous.  But they didn't know that noise attracts them?  This didn't come up during the construction of that massive wall?  While running those massive construction machines, they  didn't attract any zombies at all?On top of that there is no way on Earth that the zombies would be able to climb/stack up like they did and get over that wall.  Not to mention that when they fell over the side of the wall that the resulting impact would shatter like every bone in their bodies!  They wouldn't have been a threat to anyone!***END SPOILERS***  ***END SPOILERS***  ***END SPOILERS***There are just a bunch of parts of this movie that don't make sense, but there are a few parts of the movie that are pretty good and they make it worth checking out.  If you are a huge fan of the book, you may be disappointed, but if you're looking for an action zombie movie, you'll enjoy this one.
Title: World War Z
